story:
In this juke-box style pop opera, we meet Adam, a young man who is dealing with his sexuality, and join him on his journey of love, loss, and acceptance. Told through pop hits from Madonna to Rhianna, the story is sure to keep you on the edge of your seat and is filled with issues that any audience can relate to!

To tell this powerful story, we need your help! Throughout the next several weeks our cast and production team will be coming together to create this emotional journey.

Please join our efforts to use live arts as a means to promote acceptance. Gay, straight, bi, black, white, or mixed, people are people. And it's time we start to realize that!

Your donation will go towards our venue, props, costumes, and of course our talent and design team! Please help us reach our goal!

story:
NoHatStand are a newly established theatre company, our name originates from a famous quote by the Epic theatre practitioner Bertolt Brecht, who famously stated, "audiences hang up their brains with their hats in the cloakroom". We don't want our audiences to do this, we want to create dynamic and engaging theatre, which not only entertains, but provokes thought and forces the audience to question and contemplate the world in which they live. 

'The Accidental Artist' is our first production as a theatre company. 'The Accidental Artist' is a dark comedy which challenges and explores the contemporary world of art and provokes such questions as; what is art? How is art defined? How is art interpreted? What is its significance? What does it mean to be an artist? How can one maintain artistic integrity while in pursuit of fame and fortune? Can an artist have complete creative control within the current industry? 

The synopsis for the play is as follows:  One morning a struggling artist awakes to find his prize painting mysteriously destroyed, with no recollection of the previous night, he panics, aware that there is an art exhibitor due to view it with intention of displaying it in his gallery. Unable to salvage the painting he admits defeat and allows the art exhibitor to see what's left of his work, however, the art exhibitor holds the artist as a creative genius, a revolutionary, to the artists shock and surprise. The torn canvas rockets the artist into the lime light, though is he truly happy with the recognition he is receiving? Or does he long to recapture the beauty he once had in that painting?

We plan to have this play produced at the White Bear Theatre in Kennington, either mid September or early October. This theatre is famous for debuting new writing, in order to perform at the White Bear we will need £800 to cover the cost of the venue hire which will be for a full weeks run, including evening performances and some matinées. We will need an additional £200 to cover the cost of set, props and costume which we will be sourcing ourselves. The play is one-act with the approximate run time of an hour. 

We want to have this play produced as we believe strongly that it is both an original piece of theatre and extremely relevant to the current industry. Please support this project if you have ever found yourself questioning any form of art and have pondered over its relevance or significance to the world. 

Risks and challenges

The biggest challenge we would face with this project would be in terms of set, although this play is only one-act long, there are three different locations in which the play takes place. We will need to think of a cost effective, spatially aware and practical way to make these scene transitions both stylized and seamless. However members of our theatre company have set and theatre design experience, so I am confident that we will be able to find a logistical solution. Another possible complication could lie within not being able to draft in a large enough audience for a week of performances, as we are a newly established theatre company, however, from now until the estimated date of our production we aim to raise both the profile of our theatre company and push forward advertisement of the play. We will do this in several ways, by producing a series of conceptual/teaser trailers that will be posted online (those that donate a specific amount to our project will be part of these trailers), by contacting local press and inviting them to a scratch performance of the play (which is most likely going to be performed at Middlesex University), by making the world of social media aware of our presence as a company (currently we have a twitter page @NoHatStand) and promoting the production throughout London through the use of flyers and posters. Of course the White Bear theatre will also play a large role in promoting our production. In all honesty, we are not looking to make a huge profit with this performance and are not driven by the prospect of money, we just want people to see the show and offer theatre goers something that they've never seen before.

story:
FUNDRAISING EFFORTS CAN NOW BE FOUND AT FRACTURED ATLAS

click here to: RSVP on Facebook, and buy your tickets here.

Bikers in Camelot will have its premier in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, chosen by Condé Nast as the “Best Small City in the World.” With a highly sophisticated international population and a large influx of tourists, San Miguel is an ideal testing ground to prove that Bikers in Camelot, with its universal themes and rich musical score, has the potential for a successful future, both in New York and internationally. Ken and Wendy are experienced theater people. After performing her one-woman shows in NYC for over a decade, Wendy received a Masters degree in music theater writing from NYU on full-fellowship. Since then she has written three musicals, two on commission, one by the Public Theater, and an opera. Ken played and conducted many Broadway shows, has a Drama Desk Award and a Virtuoso Award from the Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. 

The show will be staged with all the sparkle of a Broadway production. They have a talented team to realize their vision, including actors Santa Claire Hirsch and Joshua David Cavanaugh, from New York; Magnus Kjeldal from Norway and Clara Dunham from Mexico. The brilliant Canadian director, Ken Albanese, specializes in developing new musicals. But even though production costs are lower than in the US, so are ticket prices. That’s the reason your help is needed to produce the show. It’s scheduled to open at the San Miguel Playhouse on February 20th, and can’t happen without you! Please join the Bikers in Camelot family and donate whatever you can – AND just as importantly, let all your friends, especially musical lovers, know about this Campaign . . . and about Bikers in Camelot.

The Story

Bikers in Camelot  is a four character musical romp, a classic fable . . . with a twist. When Michael, who writes biographies of Victorian women, proposes to Holly, who writes chivalrous sci-fi fantasy, but is suffering from writer’s block, all hell breaks loose. In the throes of a nasty fight, they inadvertently materialize the characters they have written – with whom they have unconsciously been in love all along. What ensues is a crazy – and enlightening night, in which they learn the old adage, “be careful what you wish for.” Of course they rediscover each other . . . but their dream lovers aren’t going anywhere. 


The Cast

Clara Dunham; Magnus Kjeldal; Santa Claire Hirsch; Joshua David Cavanaugh 

Watch a Rehearsal


 

What We Need

While many of us have already invested a great deal of love and money in the show, even with a sold out run, it will be impossible to break even. That’s why we need your help. This Indiegogo Campaign has been created to cover the shortfall between the remaining production costs and ticket sales, figured at 70% capacity for the run, based on an average ticket price of $20. Production costs include: sets, props, costumes, airfares and transportation, per diem, housing, marketing campaign, printing costs, sound equipment rentals, rehearsal space, theater rental . . . and the personnel. It is a major goal of the production to provide fair salaries for the people who are providing their artistry, time and enthusiasm to Bikers in Camelot – the director, musical director, choreographer, four actors, six musicians, set designer, stage manager and assistant stage manager, props mistress, sound and lights technician, production assistant and stage hands. It’s quite a team! The period from the beginning of rehearsals until the end of the run is nine weeks, plus preparation prior to showing up. It is not possible to even come close to paying these professionals what their services are worth, but with your help, they will be paid a living wage.

(For those of you who would like a receipt for your taxes, please check the FAQ section.)

Social Impact

Fantasy in relationships is a topic that is much discussed. We live in a world in which everybody wants a beautiful wedding, but most marriages don’t make it; a world in which we create social media and dating profiles with unrealistic versions of ourselves, based on fantasies. If we’re in a relationship, we often hold our partners up to impossible standards because of our fantasies.  Bikers in Camelot  tackles the subject of fantasy in relationships with wisdom, compassion and lots of laughter. It speaks to all of us, from twenty to ninety, because everybody has been there.

Challenges

Apart from the thrill of seeing the show in full production for the first time, audience responses will help us develop it for future productions. Because of ticket prices, it’s not possible for a musical with high-quality production values, to break even. Our standards are high and we believe the community will be very appreciative of the caliber of the production. But we’re not being extravagant. Ken Bichel, co-producer and musical director, ran a NYC music production company for decades. He keeps a tight rein on a budget.

San Miguel de Allende has a powerful history of support for the arts. There are patrons for opera, classical music and jazz.  But we’re the first musical to ask for help. We’re actually the first original musical headed for New York to ever premier here. We believe that the richness of the score in Bikers in Camelot  will appeal to classical music and opera lovers, as well as fans of contemporary music. We hope that everyone who loves musical theater will get behind us so that other new shows will consider San Miguel as a location for premiering new works.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you can’t send us funds. That doesn’t mean you can’t help. Share! Share! Share! By sending this link to anybody you think might be interested in what we’re doing you’ll grow the campaign. COME TO THE SHOW with large groups of people – teams and committees and tribes. Tell everybody you know – Good friends bring friends to Bikers in Camelot!

story:
About the show

"I've been trying to tell some classic jokes." 

Brandi Alexander is part spoken word, part stand-up comedy gone radically wrong.  The show is an assault on rape and a cry for righteous anger as it demands to have the word rape horrify once again, instead of lull us back to the everyday. It allows space for a women’s rage, instead of asking her to forgive. It demonstrates what it might mean to have a woman playing a man’s game. And it explores how so much anger might be necessary to get to the laughter, or vice versa. 

Sexual assault and harassment have been normalized in today’s society. One in five women in the US will be raped at some point in their lives. In 8 out of 10 cases of rape, the victim knew the perpetrator. 63% of sexual assaults are not reported to the police. (Statistics from National Sexual Violence Resources Center). In the end, it’s the victim that is swept under the rug as the aggressor moves on and up through life – Donald Trump, Bill Cosby, Casey Affleck, Brock Turner, Woody Allen, etc. Even with the response of the recent #metoo movement, we have yet to see how this will permanently alter the perpetrator’s career and overhaul working conditions for women. Brandi places the victim front and center and gives her the mic, the power and the ability to rewrite a victim’s narrative to become the victor.

The Seattle-based team includes Tatiana Pavela (writer and performer), Maggie Rogers (director and sound design) and Bryce Bartl-Geller (lights). The original Seattle production was developed with a 2017 GAP grant from Artist Trust. This current iteration is backed by a kick-ass producer covering venue and marketing costs and a top-notch UK publicist to help make a splash. 

Since its debut in Seattle May 2018, the show has gone on to perform in Louisville, Minneapolis and NYC. Edinburgh will be the first trip across the pond for Brandi, and she needs more than a passport. This is a vital, angry and necessary show for our current moment – help support the loud voice of women on a global stage.  

Read press for Brandi here, here and here. Or just read these highlights: 

"Pavela is funny, crass, heartbreaking and so raw in her performance that by the end, we are made to feel as if we have come into so personal and revealing a moment as to question whether we have any business being there." Arts Louisville

"It’s an exploration of sexual assault, misogyny and self-loathing, forged in fury." City Arts

"She may almost be too compelling for some people to take - and believe it or not, that’s a compliment." Single White Fringe Geek

Why Edinburgh?

"What was that joke? He's still got a career! What's the punchline?  I'm opening for him, still opening for him! Forced, ripped, splayed, battered and fried."

The short answer – this show deserves a global audience. 

The long answer – Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the largest arts festival in the world.  In 2018, 30,000 artists participated in over 3,500 shows. Many, many respected artists got their start at the Fringe and have made leaps in their careers by getting their work seen by global producers and programers during the festival. 

Brandi Alexander is a visceral, unapologetic show that needs to be seen.  And Brandi didn't come to play.

What We Need 

"How's this outfit working for you all? The last time I was all dolled up, some well-meaning gentleman told me I looked like Dustin Hoffman in Tootsie."

The short answer – $8,000. 

The long answer – any money you give is going towards an apartment for the team during the month of the festival (almost half the budget), flights, graphic design, artist stipends, props, rehearsal space, board op, and a back up costume in case the zipper gives (you've been there, admit it). 

Even if the entire goal isn't reached, any funds received will be used towards the festival costs.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just don't have the money, honey? We've all been there. Here are some other things you can do to help this show soar: 

  • Spread the love – pass along the campaign and show on social media. 
  • Come see the show! We run from July 31 – August 25th and you can buy tickets here. 
  • Tell others to check out Brandi. She's an extrovert and is looking for a large audience for her comeback tour! 

Thank you all, you beautiful generous people. 

Images by Peter Fedorchuk and Marcia Davis.

story:
Shake well.  Watch where everything falls.

'SNOWGLOBE' explores the fault lines in the very confined universe of a scientist and a believer and whether their world can survive when shaken.

The MacKnight Foundation is moving up a creative notch in Philadelphia Theatre. In SNOWGLOBE, a brilliant new work by one of Philly's best playwrights, two of the region’s top actresses are featured in this comedy of ideas & ideals set in a 12 foot x 12 foot snowglobe. 

We need your help to do it. Give what you can please! Money (of course) is welcome - it's an ambitious project. We have a professional cast - Amanda Schoonover and Charlotte Northeast - who rip apart a fascinating set each night, a set created by local team Rick Miller and Chris Madden.

But if you don't have the cash - spread the word about the show! The ticket link is https://macknight.yapsody.com - tell your friends please. Email, txt, Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, G+ - whatever you can.

And thank you!

SNOWGLOBE 

Written by Nicholas Wardigo
Directed by Bill McKinlay
Featuring Amanda Schoonover and Charlotte Northeast

Dates: January 23 - February 9th 
TICKETS: https://macknight.yapsody.com
Thu-Sat - 8PM
Sun - 7PM
The Shubin Theater, 407 Bainbridge Street

story:
What Is Songfest?

Great Question! Songfest is a year long philanthropic competition put on by the Greek community at UC Irvine. Sororities and Fraternities put on 12 minute musicals and raise money for a different cause each year.

Songfest brings musical theatre to those who might never have experienced it, and raises money for a good cause. The philanthropy this year, The Child Abuse Prevention Center is a partner close to home and we want to be able make a difference for them through this event.

This year Alpha Chi Omega, Pi Kappa Phi and Sigma Alpha Epsilon are teamed up to put on the musical All Shook Up. Our show is complete, but we need your help to make our show the best it can be! We want to be able to build an epic set for the show, and get our cast some rockin' costumes, but we can't do it without your help. We need your support to push our show to the next level and prove it's not the length or scale of a show that makes great theatre, but the love of the people behind it. 

The Show

All Shook Up is a jukebox musical of Elvis songs with a book by Joe DiPietro. The plot is loosely based on Shakespeare's Twelth Night, when a girl pretends to be a guy and hijinks ensue. If you want an easier comparison, just think of the show as She's The Man with Elvis music. 

What Are These Donations For Anyways?

All donations are going to go to 3 main areas:

  • Buying materials and set pieces for our show! We want our show to have three settings that follow the arc of the show, but we won't be able to make that happen without help.
  • Buying costumes for our show! We also want the ensemble to have three costumes over the course of the show. There are 12 people in the ensemble which means roughly 36 costumes, and while we can get some things from our closets, we want everyone to be matching on other things. 
  • Donating to the Child Abuse Prevention Center! Once the price of our set and costumes have been covered, any extra funds will be donated to the Child Abuse Prevention Center!

Other Ways You Can Help

Are you a poor college student too? None of our perks seem worthwhile to you? Here are some other ideas for how to help:

  • Share our campaign with your friends and family! 
  • Buy a ticket for Songfest and put AXO as your referring chapter! 
  • Share our page on social media to help spread the word!
story_txt:
What Is Songfest?Great Question! Songfest is a year long philanthropic competition put on by the Greek community at UC Irvine. Sororities and Fraternities put on 12 minute musicals and raise money for a different cause each year.Songfest brings musical theatre to those who might never have experienced it, and raises money for a good cause. The philanthropy this year, The Child Abuse Prevention Center is a partner close to home and we want to be able make a difference for them through this event.This year Alpha Chi Omega, Pi Kappa Phi and Sigma Alpha Epsilon are teamed up to put on the musical All Shook Up. Our show is complete, but we need your help to make our show the best it can be! We want to be able to build an epic set for the show, and get our cast some rockin' costumes, but we can't do it without your help. We need your support to push our show to the next level and prove it's not the length or scale of a show that makes great theatre, but the love of the people behind it. The ShowAll Shook Up is a jukebox musical of Elvis songs with a book by Joe DiPietro. The plot is loosely based on Shakespeare's Twelth Night, when a girl pretends to be a guy and hijinks ensue. If you want an easier comparison, just think of the show as She's The Man with Elvis music. What Are These Donations For Anyways?All donations are going to go to 3 main areas:
Buying materials and set pieces for our show! We want our show to have three settings that follow the arc of the show, but we won't be able to make that happen without help.
Buying costumes for our show! We also want the ensemble to have three costumes over the course of the show. There are 12 people in the ensemble which means roughly 36 costumes, and while we can get some things from our closets, we want everyone to be matching on other things. 
Donating to the Child Abuse Prevention Center! Once the price of our set and costumes have been covered, any extra funds will be donated to the Child Abuse Prevention Center!
Other Ways You Can HelpAre you a poor college student too? None of our perks seem worthwhile to you? Here are some other ideas for how to help:
Share our campaign with your friends and family! 
Buy a ticket for Songfest and put AXO as your referring chapter! 
Share our page on social media to help spread the word!

story:
Short Summary

Starting in March of 2002 Chromolume Theatre has been creating theater for 12 years, in fact we just celebrated our anniversary on March 22. We were a nomadic theatrer company for our first three years, putting up shows around the city of Los Angeles. In 2007 we took up residency at Theatre/Theatre with our NAACP award winning production of, Do Lord Remember Me. We are a smart company and when we were in over our heads we took a hideous and closed our doors in order to pay back our debt before we continued. When we were able to pay off the $60,000, we reopened our doors. We took over the Attic Theater & Film Center in Los Angeles in May of 2012 and since then we have been able to produce a large amount of shows. When we took over the Attic we knew we wanted to help renovate and make it a better place of business, so at the beginning of this year we started our renovations. We have about 10 phases we will be going through until we feel it will be a complete renovation. We started by turning our old rehearsal space into a Dance Studio. We are so very pleased with the end result. We will be moving on to renovate our dressing rooms, house, and lobby as well as creating a new dressing room and workshop space in the area directly behind our building. All of these renovations are very positive additions to our company. The Chromolume Theatre 2014 season is kicking off on April 4th with our production of AltarBoyz, but because of of the renovations we have started to do, we are not able to afford the necessary microphones for our production. We are asking you to make a donation of any amount to help us raise the $2000, we need, to purchase the 5 wireless microphones, 16 channel mixer and enough cable and accessories we need. Our actors and creative team bring more than enough talent to the show, but it won’t mean as much if the Actors aren’t being heard over our 3 piece live band

Our production of AltarBoyz, really can't be done without wireless microphones. We have been working with an amazing local sound company to find affordable, yet, quality equipment for us, after all of they have done to help bring their cost down to help us the lowest cost they could quote us is around $2000, which is amazing but still too much for us at this time.

Musical theater is such an important part of our culture, and we really want to keep producing more. Our production will be running for 6 weeks with 3 shows a weekend, and that is simply too much for any actor to be able to continue to sing without overusing their voice, unless they are using microphones, especially because we will have a live 3 piece band on stage with them.

Your contribution would help us be able to afford the right equipment and would help us put on our show in the best way possible.

Here is a link to the promotional video we created with our cast lip syncing to the Original recording. Just further proves the talent we have in our cast.

http://youtu.be/SazP4BrcdBM

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2000, this money will help us afford to buy 5 wireless headset microphones, the microphone packs, receivers, enough cable to connect them and the proper 16 channel mixer. This is all of the equipment we need to be able to "mic" each of our 5 actors to amplify their voices while dancing, singing and acting in our theater.

If you donate:

$5 Receive a thank you in our program!

$20 Signed photo of cast!

$26 Chromolume Theatre T-shirt or Sweatshirt (featured in the video)

$40 Two Tickets to any AltarBoyz performance (4/4/14-5/11/14)

$75 Two Tickets to any AltarBoyz performance & 2 free Chromolume Dance Studio dance classes

$100 Two Tickets to any AltarBoyz performance, 2 free Chromolume Dance Studio dance classes & Chromolume Theatre T-shirt or Sweatshirt

If we don't reach our entire goal, your donations will still go to help our production of AltarBoyz. We are cutting corners in other areas to be able to get the best show we can with what we have.

The Impact

We have been making musical theater for so long and have been successful at it because we make theater we believe in. Every production we do, is created by a strong team of people and everyone believes in the common goal of making amazing musical theater together. From our production team to our cast, everyone is in it for the end result of making musical theater that can make a positive impact in someones life.

Our amazing cast of AltarBoyz, is talent enough to make this show fabulous, but the added benefits of costumes, sets and lighting is just a bonus. None of that can mean anything if the audience can't hear the actors. We need to be able to do our production with microphones.

We have not had to do a fundraising campaign of this type before, and we are only doing one now because we know we need to be able to provide our production with these microphones.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to help us financially through this campaign. Help spread the word with us. Hopefully you can come see the show, you can check us out and see what we are all about at our website. www.crtheatre.com 

remember you can sacrifice one drink at your favorite coffee shop and use that money to help us make musical theater.

You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word and tell your friends and family about our campaign. 

Thank you from everyone at Chromolume Theatre for helping us in any way you are able to!!!

story:
The Black Box Project is an accessible platform for emerging Black playwrights to develop new work and provide quality, culturally relevant theatre to the Black community.

With a love for Black people centered in everything we do, the Black Box Project seeks to ensure the growth and vitality of theatre by Black dramatists for generations to come. 

We are a group of theatre-makers who started The Black Box Project when we saw a lack of institutional support for emerging Black theatre artists in New York City. We’re leading a self-organizing movement to support our artist and their work, and to bring critical to new work to a stage it can call home.

To achieve our mission, every three months we produce a semi-staged reading of 1-3 excerpts, short, and full length plays written by Black early-career theater-makers. These artists not only get to show work at our public readings, but have the opportunity to receive feedback from their peers and established playwrights at invite-only pre-rehearsals. At the readings, they will also have an opportunity to connect with audience members, ask questions, and receive notes during a facilitated talkback. Finally, to establish a loving, connected community, we host a mixer that allows Black artists and theater-lovers to engage with each other, network, and dance the night away! We need community support to give Cycle 2 the same love our fabulous launch event got.

Our Goal

Our funding need for this cycle are $6000, covering:

-Compensation for readers and actors during our public readings and rehearsals.

-Renting rehearsal space.

-A new fundraising event in December aimed to increase our programmatic capacity in the new year.

-Printing and office supplies for our readings.

-Props, supplies, and refreshments for the event.

-Promotional materials, including videography support during our event to capture the amazing work and create a trailer for the organization to help tell the BBP story to a wider audience.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate right now? Trust us, we get it. If you can't support us with money, we would love it if you could:

-Follow us on facebook (The Black Box Project NYC) or instagram @theblackboxprojectnyc

-Share this campaign as well as our Patreon page (https://www.patreon.com/theblackboxnyc)

-Look out for our events. Come through, bring your friends, and spread the word to other Black theater-makers!

story:
Project Background: For more than three years, Catherine Gigante-Brown has been working with director Susan Einhorn to transform Catherine’s novel “Different Drummer” into a musical. With Susan’s guidance, Catherine adapted the “book” for the stage. After a long search, she and Susan compiled an amazing songwriting team—Hannah Hickok (the “Hannah” of “Hannah and Maggie”) and Vinnie Corbo (lead singer/songwriter/founder of a seminal punk band).

What We Need from You: The team is now ready to present a staged reading so “Different Drummer.” But it takes funding to hire a large, professional cast, a musical director, casting director and general manager to make this happen. That’s where you come in!

The Storyline: “Different Drummer’s” lead character Cara Funk (neé Carol Finkelstein) is an enormously-talented, singing female drummer, desperately striving to “make it” in the bizarre, male-dominated music world. It’s set in 1979 New York City, amid graffiti-infested rock clubs, glitzy and garish catering halls, claustrophobic basement rehearsal spaces and state-of-the-art recording studios. Like “Alice” in a grungy “Wonderland,” Cara is helped and hindered by a revolving cast of characters—her mother, her on-again, off-again boyfriend, corrupt bandleaders. Rapidly approaching 30, this is Cara’s self-imposed last chance and she’s willing to sacrifice everything—friendships, relationships, family, her ideals—to succeed. Will she ultimately triumph, crash and burn, or just fade away?

Why This Project is Important: “Different Drummer’s” powerful story needs to be told. Its heroine Cara is the quintessential underdog struggling to succeed against all odds. Her challenges mirror our challenges…anyone who was ever told they weren’t good enough…anyone who was lied to, cheated and beaten down yet still has the strength to rise up, fight and believe in themselves.

story:
What I'm Doing

 I am self-producing my own cabaret, with your help!

Who I Am

My name is Ben Watts. I’ve worked as an actor in St. Louis for the past 6 years.  Recently, I took a cabaret workshop taught by Tim Schall, the Executive Director of the Cabaret Project of St. Louis.  It was an 8 week intensive where we learned about the art of cabaret, the importance of song choice, and how to interact and hold a conversation with your audience, among others things.  We narrowed down song choices, turned our personal stories into “patter” for the audience, rehearsed our sets, and finally each student put together a short four song showcase, which we performed at the Kranzberg Arts Center in January.  (You can see clips of my performance above!)

I had never done anything with cabaret up to that point, but the outpouring of compliments and support I received after the show from friends and family and strangers alike, was overwhelming.  Something felt very natural to me when I was up there performing.  It was all very new and very scary, but something clicked for me.  I knew I wanted to do it again.

But bigger.  And better.  And by myself...

Why I Need Your Help

I want to take everything I learned from the workshop/showcase and put it to the test in a full-length show! But that means taking on this project by myself, without the guidance and benefit of a classroom or a curriculum.  And it takes a lot of time and money. 

In addition to rehearsing the show, I’m also dealing with the business end of things, such as renting a venue, hiring a director and accompanist, and promoting the show.  I need your help to fund this project, so I can put on the best show possible (and have one less thing to worry about!)

What I’m Asking For

I need $2000 to make this happen.  All of the money will go to paying the director and accompanist, renting the venue, and lights, sounds, equipment, etc.

  • $1400—Rehearsal time with the director, Tim Schall,  and music director and accompanist, Carol Schmidt, including performance fees
  • $350—Rental fee for the performance venue
  • $200—Lights and sound, recording equipment
  • $50—Promotional materials

Not meeting this goal means I have to make cuts, which would most likely come out of the rehearsal budget.  Less rehearsal money means less rehearsal time and that leaves me with an underprepared, unprofessional show.  I don't want this to happen.

What You Can Do

  1. Donate!  Anything you can give will help!  Check out some of the perks.  I'm giving credits in the program, DVDs of the performance, and free tickets! And more!
  2. Share! If you can’t donate, please, share with people who might be interested. Pass it along!  Tweet!  Post on your wall! Email your family!  Text your friends!
  3. Come see the show! May 30th, 2015.  8PM at the Kranzberg Arts Center.  More information on tickets to come!

Why It Matters

Cabaret is a strange art form.  It’s part-singing, part-storytelling, and part-therapy.  It’s more personal and down-to-earth than a play or musical, but there’s still a sense of heightened electricity.  Cabaret is intimate entertainment.  

And it’s something I think I’m good at, and something I’m set on pursuing further.  I’ve got plans to attend a cabaret conference this summer that this show may help me qualify for.  

So, please, donate and share, and help me make this scary little dream of mine a reality!

story:
Short Summary

Millions know the name Ragan Courtney from the musical "Celebrate Life!" which he wrote with his friend, the late Buryl Red.  Produced in churches around the world, it set the standard for a new kind of Gospel musical and opened the door to other Courtney-written musicals, including "Bright New Wings," "Lottie D.," and many others.  His career as a playwright began with the musical "The Earl of Ruston," which played all over the South and on Broadway at the Billy Rose Theater.  Mr. Courtney is also acclaimed as a poet with six books of poems published. 

Now, Ragan Courtney is preparing three new one-act dramas for production.  "Keys to the Kingdom" features a father whose dreams have been shattered pouring out his heart to his developmentally-disabled son.  Does the young man understand or even hear?  "Shabby Gentility" reveals the long-suppressed secrets between two women, one white, one black, who've known each other their whole lives.  And "The Gospel According to Ms. Flowers" brings together a priest and an unusual visitor to the confessional.  Questions of gender identity and grace lead to a shocking ending.

To lead the workshop stage of the development of these plays, Mr. Courtney has entrusted the scripts to his former student and teaching colleague, M. Christopher Boyer.  Mr. Boyer has had a long career in professional and academic theatre, learning the new play development process during his time on staff at Actors Theatre of Louisville where he coordinated guest logistics for the Humana Festival of New American Plays, served as a script reader for that festival, and directed plays for the ongoing new short play work.  He went on to direct new play development as part of his work at A.D. Players as well as encouraging the production of new work in three companies where he served as managing director.

This one-week workshop process is a critical step in preparing these new scripts for production.  Mr. Courtney will have the opportunity to hear professional actors read and rehearse the plays and make changes based on what he and they learn together.  At the end of the week, an invited audience will also hear the plays and respond, giving yet more valuable input.  Given Ragan Courney's popularity, these issue-oriented plays have the potential to touch thousands of lives as he uses his dramatic gifts to examine situations of disability, racism, and gender identity.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this process as effective as possible for the playwright, Mr. Boyer is gathering a cast of professional actors in one of the finest theatre cities in the country.  These artists and their stage manager will be paid at union rates to ensure that the best actors can participate.  Thanks to a generous donation of stage time, these stipends and lodging for Mr. Courtney in Seattle are the primary expenses of the project, estimated at $3,000.

  • Donors at the $50 and higher level will receive electronic copies of the finished scripts.
  • Donors at the $100 and higher level will receive invitations to the final reading of the workshop in Seattle as well as copies of the finished scripts.

The Impact

Because Ragan Courtney is a trusted artist in the evangelical community, these scripts give us the opportunity to open dialogue on issues of disability, race, and gender issues in venues where such conversations might not otherwise happen.  The successful development of these plays can provide a powerful tool in the ongoing work to build "the Beloved Community."

Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to contribute? That doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Check out and use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for considering our project!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Millions know the name Ragan Courtney from the musical "Celebrate Life!" which he wrote with his friend, the late Buryl Red.  Produced in churches around the world, it set the standard for a new kind of Gospel musical and opened the door to other Courtney-written musicals, including "Bright New Wings," "Lottie D.," and many others.  His career as a playwright began with the musical "The Earl of Ruston," which played all over the South and on Broadway at the Billy Rose Theater.  Mr. Courtney is also acclaimed as a poet with six books of poems published. 
Now, Ragan Courtney is preparing three new one-act dramas for production.  "Keys to the Kingdom" features a father whose dreams have been shattered pouring out his heart to his developmentally-disabled son.  Does the young man understand or even hear?  "Shabby Gentility" reveals the long-suppressed secrets between two women, one white, one black, who've known each other their whole lives.  And "The Gospel According to Ms. Flowers" brings together a priest and an unusual visitor to the confessional.  Questions of gender identity and grace lead to a shocking ending.
To lead the workshop stage of the development of these plays, Mr. Courtney has entrusted the scripts to his former student and teaching colleague, M. Christopher Boyer.  Mr. Boyer has had a long career in professional and academic theatre, learning the new play development process during his time on staff at Actors Theatre of Louisville where he coordinated guest logistics for the Humana Festival of New American Plays, served as a script reader for that festival, and directed plays for the ongoing new short play work.  He went on to direct new play development as part of his work at A.D. Players as well as encouraging the production of new work in three companies where he served as managing director.
This one-week workshop process is a critical step in preparing these new scripts for production.  Mr. Courtney will have the opportunity to hear professional actors read and rehearse the plays and make changes based on what he and they learn together.  At the end of the week, an invited audience will also hear the plays and respond, giving yet more valuable input.  Given Ragan Courney's popularity, these issue-oriented plays have the potential to touch thousands of lives as he uses his dramatic gifts to examine situations of disability, racism, and gender identity.

What We Need & What You Get
In order to make this process as effective as possible for the playwright, Mr. Boyer is gathering a cast of professional actors in one of the finest theatre cities in the country.  These artists and their stage manager will be paid at union rates to ensure that the best actors can participate.  Thanks to a generous donation of stage time, these stipends and lodging for Mr. Courtney in Seattle are the primary expenses of the project, estimated at $3,000.

Donors at the $50 and higher level will receive electronic copies of the finished scripts.
Donors at the $100 and higher level will receive invitations to the final reading of the workshop in Seattle as well as copies of the finished scripts.


The Impact
Because Ragan Courtney is a trusted artist in the evangelical community, these scripts give us the opportunity to open dialogue on issues of disability, race, and gender issues in venues where such conversations might not otherwise happen.  The successful development of these plays can provide a powerful tool in the ongoing work to build "the Beloved Community."
Other Ways You Can Help
Not able to contribute? That doesn't mean you can't help:

Please help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
Check out and use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for considering our project!

story:
What is This, and Why Should I Care?

"The Marvelous Red Balloon" is a piece of devised theatre about two scientist-lovers ripped apart from each other by nature, and their long journey to find each other. Devised theatre is a process of making new plays by filling a room with theatre artists to brainstorm and improvise together until a story, collaboratively created and edited by all, exists in a fixed form to be shared with an audience. 

By design the story has very few predetermined elements outside of what's stated above, so that the final story is a reflection of each deviser as an individual and as a member of this group. We chose this process as a means to make more inclusive, equitable theatre.

Theatre at all levels is deceptively and cruelly expensive, and our plan to have hot air balloon companies sponsor us as an (admittedly) indirect means of advertising their business fell through faster than their crappy air balloons. So we return to you, our audience, asking that you help us so we may give back to you.

So, Who are You?

Red Dice Collective are three people: Andre Johnson Jr., Miranda Shunkwiler, and Mason Tyer. We all met a Iowa State University and, once finished our time in school, we went to work professionally in Minnesota's Twin Cities. We were taken in by some of the most caring and intelligent theatre artists we've ever met, and eventually we realized what elevated them from their peers: rather than try to be the best person in the room, they were dedicated to creating beautiful living moments for every audience member possible.

These people are rare, however, so we set to put ourselves in leadership positions in order to follow their example. From this love for the audience, Red Dice Collective (RDC) was born. While we continue professional development by working with other companies, our work as RDC is where we can pay it forward artistically to an audience.

In the Case of "The Marvelous Red Balloon", we're joined with our stage manager Sarah Maxwell and our perfomers Laura Mason, Kasey Manche, and Michael Weingartner.

What Would My Money Buy, and What Do I Get?

We're a frugal bunch at RDC; no 401(K)s or international research trips for us. What we're asking for is the minimum to make this thing happen.

$700 is for all the artist stipends: three performers, our stage manager, our director, and our designer. This show is planned to be very performer-focused, with very few set pieces or design accouterments, so they'll need to work hard. Thankfully we have some very skilled professionals, and they deserved to at least afford to buy a sandwich with chips AND a soda.
 
$200 is for all the production needs. As minimalist a concept as we're going for, this is a world of Victorian fantasy: yelling on stage "THEY FLEW AWAY" isn't nearly as interesting as showing it. Set construction supplies, props, band-aids, paint, marketing all falls under this. Miranda is handling all of this, so she'll make $200 look like $452.17 (specific, yes, but so is she).

$100 is for the emergency. What emergency? Exactly: we don't know, but we want to be ready for it.

That totals our goal of $1000. Two scenarios to outline:
1. We don't make our goal. We will triage to budget areas most important, with the first being to pay our artists (remember, sandwiches cost money) and then followed by production needs, with an emergency fund being last. It'll be tough, but every penny will count.

2. We overreach our goal. You studs. Some funds will be used to reimburse expenses that we considered donations (Andre is currently drowning in his bedroom from all the props he had to purchase and store there). Some funds will be passed along to actors (MORE SANDWICHES) because honestly they're working for us at bargain-bin prices and we know it. Finally, some funds will be used as a springboard for our next production already in the works.

Other than those soft gooey feelings you get when you give selflessly to others, we want to rewards those who believe in us. Check out our available perks!

Big Talk, But Can you even Make this Happen?

Oh baby, can we.

Though we are are early-career artists, don't mistake that for amateurs. Between the three core members of RDC, we have over 15 years of professional experience and easily over 20 productions in the three years we've all lived in the Twin Cities. We've been directors, actors, stage managers, set designers, sound and lights technicians, musicians, choreographers, teachers, and stage hands. Add that to our production's performers and stage manager, and you're looking at a whole bunch of bases double- and triple-covered. We got this.

Additionally, Arts Nests is comprised of very experienced professionals more than willing to be or find the unexpected resource we may need. They specialize in helping other companies bring productions to life, and they're ready to be hands on deck for us.

I would love to give you my life savings, but I can't. Is there some other way I can help?

Well of course, leading question! If you can't donate money, donate your time by taking a moment to spread the word about the campaign and our company. Share the campaign on your social media with a message about why you're sharing it ("This project looks cool. Let's help it out!" or "What pluck and vigor these folks have! They should know we believe in them" or "ARTISTS DESERVE SANDWICHES TOO"). 

For those of you who already connected to IndieGoGo, there are some nifty sharing tools that make all this even easier.

Will You Shut Up so I Can Help?

Absolutely. Thank you for helping us, however that may be!

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name's Sarah Martens and I'm very excited to share with you the reason why I'm here. Having a background and passion for theatre, dance and yoga therapy drew me to drama therapist and anthropologist Dr. Sue Jennings inspiring book, Theatre, Ritual and Transformation. Feeling so grateful for the way in which she shared her time living with the Temiar people along with her young family compelled me to reach out to Dr. Jennings to thank her. A day later, she wrote back asking if I'd like to come to Malaysia with a small study group to learn about her drama therapy approach and experience  first hand how the Temiar people have informed her research and life's work.

Jennings developed her approach to therapy, Neuro Dramatic Play,by witnessing the strong bond that the Temiar women develop with their unborn children. The Temiar society also influenced her theories around non-invasive approaches to child rearing. The community has maintained their strong connection to traditional dance, song and guided trance ritual. Traditional doctors in the village use ritual to nurture a state of harmony and balance in the individual which ripples out to a healthy, peaceful society. An all night ritual of song, dance and trance has been planned during our stay with the Temiars, which I must confess intrigues me as much as it has me a bit nervous.

My fundraising goal includes aeroplane ticket cost, which from my findings is between $ 1,400-1,600 cdn depending on the day and flight time into and leaving from Kuala Lumpur. The tuition for the workshop and study group is 2,400 cdn, transferred from the British pound. So, my total goal is to raise 4,000 ( about 3000.00 US) in 30 days or less, which is a bit pressing!  Any extra will go toward food not covered during the trip (most is), late fees I will need to pay after March 2, (coming up quickly!), and if there's still extra ( dare to dream), I will put it towards my continuing creative collaboration with local theatre and felting artist, Marjorie Campbell, as we continue to explore the relationship between movement, wool felt and the participants connection with self and others in a movement therapy and performance type setting. 

Looking beyond this adventure with Dr. Jennings, my goal upon returning to Canada is to incorporate all I've experienced and allow it to inform my work as a yoga/movement therapist, and artist. I feel that this time spent in Malaysia is a huge piece of a puzzle that is starting to take shape after many years of bringing it into focus. I am very interested in developing this therapeutic approach to work with people struggling with addiction, children with learning and behavioural issues, people with dementia as well as refugees living with post traumatic stress. 

If you are interested in donating, please check out my perks. I apologize for those outside of Toronto who can't make it here to collect your perk, but please let me know if you ever do come to town.For those of you who would like to donate, but can't right now, not to worry, you can still help out a ton by sharing my Indiegogo campaign on social media and email to people you know who may want to support my fundraising goal.

Thank you mighty friends who've encouraged me to take this leap into the possibility of this opportunity becoming an actuality.

story:
This August my play Make Your Acquaintance will go up at the New York New Works Festival. This show means a lot to me. It is about terrible people having lunch. Some of them die; others fall in love, one with a pair of pants. I'm excited for people to see it. 

In the past few weeks, I've been floored by how talented a staff and how funny a cast we've assembled. The script makes me laugh, but now that I somehow got these people to do it I am sure it will make other people laugh too. 

Your donations will help us:

  • build our set
  • cover festival fees
  • rent rehearsal space
  • buy props and costumes
  • provide stipends to the cast and production team

It's exciting for me to have Make Your Acquaintance make its New York premiere, but it's especially exciting to have one of many new works in a festival devoted to new work. 

If you're able to come to our show on August 17th, we'd love a shot at making you laugh. And if you're able to give, I can't thank you enough for making our play the best it can be. 

 -Davis Alianiello

***
From NYNW: The 2nd Annual New York New Works Theatre Festival will begin this coming August the Times Square Arts Center in New York City.  The NYNW Festival is a one of a kind theatre competition in which the audience and the NYNW Panel select the best play of the season. All submitted plays are reviewed by the panel, which is comprised of Tony Award Winners, Emmy Award Winners, Broadway Producers, and leading entertainment industry executives.  
***
The Make Your Acquaintance team is: Alex McKhann, Becky Heisler, Davis Alianiello, Eleonore Condo, Emily Baldasarra, Jeffrey Robb, Samantha Turret, Stephen Buckley, Steve Bauder, and Tom Bishop.

story:
We produce theatre performances of new ideas including new writing, devised work and adaptations. Working with professional directors and actors, we provide the writer with the opportunity to stage their idea for the first time ever and in doing so gain valuable feedback from audiences and industry professionals to help that idea springboard onto its next natural stage of development.

To build our following we want to permanently house First Draft at one venue, The Hope Theatre. This year we need to raise funds to produce three short productions which will help creative professionals develop their skills in new writing, devised and adapted Theatre and two workshops for anyone wanting to learn.

For each of these productions we will work using the First Draft format: rehearse for three days and perform for two nights. The process is fast and instinctive; a joyful leap into the possibilities of an idea. For the writer, deviser or adapter, First Draft affords the opportunity to see their idea at an early stage, to receive feedback, and review the work for further development on the London fringe and beyond. For the audience the result is an exciting, energetic and compelling piece of new work and a glimpse into the genesis of a theatrical idea.

At First Draft our focus is to keep new ideas on the stage, and to create a number of opportunities and encourage talent in the theatrical world. Having an action packed year lined up allows First Draft to offer a substantial number of paid opportunities and exciting new work to the arts.

We want to attract a number of different writers, actors, directors and stage managers, designers etc. to First Draft and working on a number of productions and workshops enables us to do this. Our workshops will be open to anyone that has a passion, in particular those who are unable to afford a drama school training or who do not wish to go down the university route. First Draft has a proven track record of producing commercial and critically acclaimed work and developing the minds and skills of all the creatives we work with. In order to continue our activities we feel that First Draft needs a regular 'Home'. We have been asked to become resident theatre company at The Hope Theatre in Islington, a trail blazing new theatre where all performers are paid a legal wage through a house agreement with equity, the UK's largest performers union. In order for First Draft to continue working and developing our audiences and creative associates this resident company project at The Hope is necessary.

All the funds we raise will go into paying creatives a legal wage and to produce high quality theatre. Any help you can give us makes a huge difference into making all of this a reality. Thank you!

www.firstdrafttheatre.com

story:
“Before you start with your idea… Who are you?”

My name is Dane Eissler. I’m a Chicago-based image-driven theatre and performance artist with a focus on the macabre quirks and absurdities of those considered “other”, fostering the discovery and understanding of the “other” in oneself. Recently graduating from Rowan University (BA in Theatre), I started my artistic career in the Philadelphia theatre community, Associate Directing the Philadelphia Premiere of Tennessee Williams’s Stairs to the Roof (EgoPo Classic Theatre) and Assistant Directing Rowan University's original dance-theatre production They Slice the Air, as well as appearing in Stephen Karam’s Speech & Debate (Azuka Theatre) and Fernando Arrabal’s Fando y Lis (Neighborhood Fringe Festival). I am also a writer of original works, including I Love You, Jane Doe and Violet of the Garden of Eden.

“So what exactly are you looking to fund?”

Dane Eissler’s FOREVER FETAL, part of the “f*cked up fable” series+

All it takes is one brief taste of the outside world to send a scared fetus, Junior, and his ingrown twin, Junior, Jr., back into the womb… but when Junior, Jr. goes off to explore the outside world, Junior must face his fears and go into the unknown to find his twin. FOREVER FETAL is a part-puppet, part-found object theatre fable about the discomfort of change and new responsibilities, and the power we find in ourselves to overcome any obstacle.

+ The “f*cked up fable” series is a series of theatrical works in the style of fables or children’s theatre… that no child should be able to watch. With this series of theatrical works, I aim to start important intellectual and sociological discussions about human needs and desires by aesthetically reinvigorating playful, childlike imagination of adult audiences.

“That’s really cool. But why?”

I’ve been dreaming of producing this piece for about a year and a half now, but I’ve never felt it was the right time – until now. I moved to Chicago about two months ago with a mission to break out of the comfort of my hometown and explore the country, my art, and my own being. In the time I have been living with this nugget of an idea, FOREVER FETAL has never resonated so clearly. The time is NOW!

“How much money are you looking to raise?” 

$1750... 70% of which will go towards paying our incredibly talented artists, performers, and production team. The remaining 30% of money raised will go towards our production budget, including costumes, set, props, puppets, flashlights (huzza flashlight lighting!), marketing, photography, and Indiegogo Fees.

And don’t forget to check out our AWESOME PERKS for those of you so inclined to donate!

*No matter what amount you donate, your contribution will be credited in the program for the show!

“Dane, what if FOREVER FETAL doesn’t meet its fundraising goal?”

Great question. In the event we don’t reach our fundraising goal, whatever money we do receive will first and foremost go towards the artists. Their well-being comes first, so they will be paid first. In terms of designs, they’ll just have to change. That’s life. Whatever gets thrown at us, we’ll make it work, and FOREVER FETAL will be great.

“Aw man, I like your spunk. I’d love to help out, but I don’t have any money…”

No worries, friend. Another way you can help is to SPREAD THE WORD about this project and this campaign. I’m new to Chicago, so I need all the help I can get getting this show out there. Any help at all is greatly appreciated!

Thanks for visiting my Indiegogo Campaign! See you at the show :)

(BA in Theatre), I started my artistic career in the Philadelphia theatre
community, Associate Directing the Philadelphia Premiere of Tennessee
Williams’s Stairs to the Roof (EgoPo Classic Theatre) and Assistant
Directing Rowan University's original dance-theatre production They
Slice the Air, as well as appearing in Stephen
Karam’s Speech & Debate (Azuka Theatre) and
Fernando Arrabal’s Fando y Lis (Neighborhood Fringe Festival). I
am also a writer of original works, including I Love You,
Jane Doe and Violet of the Garden of Eden.
“So what exactly are you looking to fund?”
Dane Eissler’s FOREVER FETAL, part of the “f*cked up fable”
series+
All it takes is one brief taste of the outside world to send a scared
fetus, Junior, and his ingrown twin, Junior, Jr., back into the womb… but when
Junior, Jr. goes off to explore the outside world, Junior must face his fears
and go into the unknown to find his twin. FOREVER FETAL
is a part-puppet, part-found object theatre fable about the discomfort of
change and new responsibilities, and the power we find in ourselves to overcome
any obstacle.
+ The “f*cked up fable” series is a series of theatrical works in the
style of fables or children’s theatre… that no child should be able to watch. With
this series of theatrical works, I aim to start important intellectual and
sociological discussions about human needs and desires by aesthetically
reinvigorating playful, childlike imagination of adult audiences. 
“That’s really cool. But why?”
I’ve been dreaming of producing this piece for about a year and a half now,
but I’ve never felt it was the right time – until now. I moved to Chicago about
two months ago with a mission to break out of the comfort of my hometown and
explore the country, my art, and my own being. In the time I have been living
with this nugget of an idea, FOREVER FETAL has never
resonated so clearly. The time is NOW!
“How much money are you looking to raise?”  
$1750... 70% of which will go towards paying our incredibly talented
artists, performers, and production team. The remaining 30% of money raised
will go towards our production budget, including costumes, set, props, puppets,
flashlights (huzza flashlight lighting!), marketing, photography, and Indiegogo
Fees. 
And don’t forget to check out our AWESOME
PERKS for those of you so inclined to donate!*No matter what amount you donate, your contribution will be credited in the program for the show!
“Dane, what if FOREVER FETAL
doesn’t meet its fundraising goal?” 
Great question. In the event we don’t reach our fundraising goal, whatever
money we do receive will first and foremost go towards the artists. Their
well-being comes first, so they will be paid first. In terms of designs, they’ll
just have to change. That’s life. Whatever gets thrown at us, we’ll make it
work, and FOREVER FETAL will be
great.
“Aw man, I like your spunk. I’d love to help out, but I don’t have
any money…” 
No worries, friend. Another way you can help is to SPREAD THE WORD
about this project and this campaign. I’m new to Chicago, so I need all the
help I can get getting this show out there. Any help at all is greatly
appreciated!
Thanks for visiting my Indiegogo Campaign! See you at the show :)

story:
Short Summary

I'm Carolyn Gage, a lesbian-feminist playwright, and this is a campaign to fund the production and videotaping of one of my newest plays, Planchette, for it's performance at the Fresh Fruit Festival in July. The play is going to be directed by Nicole Kontalefa, who did such an outstanding job with my play Black Eye at the Festival last year. In fact, it won "Judge's Pick." Planchette is a 40-minute play set in Portsmouth, New Hampshire in 1879. During a nor'easter two fourteen-year-olds share their secrets about trauma they have survived and the deeper secrets about their sexual orientations and gender identities.

This is a play about the strength, courage and resiliency of children who survive trauma and who manage to find their way to alternative identities in a homophobic and patriarchal world... It's about how they know so much more than we imagine they do, how honest they can be before we socialize them for our own agendas, and how much they remind us of what is important.

NOTE: Photo is by Liz Rollins from the Maine Playwrights Festival production, directed by Odelle Bowman. The actors in the photo are Lily Carrigan and Isabel Floyd.

What We Need and What You Get

We need to raise $1500 to pay for period costumes (you can't buy them at Goodwill), rehearsal space in NYC ('nuff said), stipends for the actors and for director Nicole Kontalefa, and for professional videotaping, because we will need a good video in order to market the show for touring after the Festival.

Here are the perks:

$10  A PDF of any Gage one-act play. http://carolyngage.weebly.com/one-acts.html)

$25  A PDF of any Gage full-length play, or 3 one-acts. http://carolyngage.weebly.com/full-length-plays.html

$100 A CD of Carolyn Gage's performance of The Second Coming of Joan of Arc

$200  A paperback of any collection of Gage's plays. http://carolyngage.weebly.com/play-and-short-story-collections.html

If we do not reach our fundraising goal, we will budget for the minimal necessities.

The Impact

What makes this play special?

First, the age of the leads... fourteen.

Second, most of the time when LGBTQ youth are on the stage it is in plays that they have written. They courageously come forward and, often in monologue format, tell their coming-out stories. And often they find themselves "preaching to the choir." This play catches audiences by off-guard. It's a period drama. It deals with New England and Denver history. It looks like Little House on the Prairie. Audiences come to it with a different frame of reference and different expectations-- and suddenly they are sucked into the drama about the vulnerability, the courage, and the honesty of these very young females wrestling with very adult secrets.

Third, the play is a challenge to the LGBTQ community, because in 1879 the concept of a lesbian butch and a trans man were equally moot. The play asks us to enter this 19th-century world and just listen to the characters on their own terms. It was my intention to create a neutral space amid a highly charged and highly polarized conversation.

If you don't know my work, I have written 75 plays, including one-acts, one-woman shows, musicals, historical dramas, comedies, and adaptations. I have toured for more than 25 years performing my own work and lecturing about lesbian culture.

If you're curious about what other people have said about my work, here's a link: http://carolyngage.weebly.com/endorsements.html

I have been deeply inspired by the writings of African American author and activist Toni Cade Bambara. She wrote, "I work to produce stories that save our lives."


Other Ways You Can Help

1) Share information about this campaign.
2) Come see the show!
3) If you belong to an organization or a school that might be interested in sponsoring a performance of Planchette, please let me know!

story:
We had such an amazing time with our production of How I Learned to Drive by Paula Vogel last summer at the Tank and it was all thanks to YOU and your help!

In order to make our upcoming season for summer 2016 happen we are greatly dependent on your generous support again this year. 


Who We Are

G45 Productions is an artistic the collective made up of 20 young artists from New York City, all recent graduates of Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts. We strive to produce actor driven theatrical works of an immense variety including both new works and revivals. 

This summer, G45 is taking on 2 projects that will stay true to its mission and push the group into new territory. 

 1) New Work Development Series

This summer G45 is honored to have a week long residency at IRT Theater which will be used to develop the works of 4 amazing playwrights all under the age of 23. Some works have been brought in, some have been commissioned specifically for this residency, but all are inventive, bold, funny, and incisive stories that need to be told.

The playwrights will go through intensive rehearsals with a cast of peers as well as feedback sessions with actors and artistic consultants from the G45 ensemble. 

They will ultimately present their works in a series of public readings on July 1st-3rd. The readings will be performed, directed and designed by G45 members and friends as we build and include the artists we know and love.  


Here is our lineup of amazing playwrights along with their show dates: 

July 1st 8 PM- Melanin/ Where You Gonna Run To/ Poplar and Rope by Kori Alston

July 2nd 2 PM- Sip//Crash by Samantha Mueller

July 2nd 8 PM- Here be Monsters by India Kotis

July 3rd 2 PM- Black Ice by Max Friedlich

  • When: July 1st-3rd 
  • Where: @ the IRT Theater
  • Click here for ticket and location information.

http://www.g45productions.com/newworksdevelopmentseries/


2) Where We're Born by Lucy Thurber

Our main stage production this year will be Lucy Thurber's acclaimed play Where We're Born at The Flea Theater.

We are honored to be making our Off-off Broadway debut at The Flea Theater, one of the most acclaimed downtown spaces in New York.
Where We're Born is the story of  Lilly Marino a freshman on scholarship at a prestigious liberal arts school in Northern MA. When she returns home on her October break, Lilly’s intellect collides with the culture of the rough and tumble hilltown in which she was raised. Over her week at home lines are blurred, and identities challenged as Lilly questions where she belongs. Bold and explosive, Lucy Thurber’s Where We’re Born explores why it is we can never return home.


Starring:

Sadie Scott- Lilly Marino 

Zeke St. John- Tony Marino

Lucy Consagra- Franky LaRue

Niall Cunningham- Drew Avery

Jarrett Jung- Vin Wright

and Abe Jacobs and Caitlin Byrne. 


Directed by Michael Herwitz 


The show will be fully performed produced, directed, and designed by G45 members and friends.


Where We're Born goes up July 15th - 24th @ 7:00pm @ the Flea Theater


Click here to buy tickets at an "early bird" discount! 

For more information check out http://www.g45productions.com/mainstage2016


What We Need!

We need your help to make this summer happen! We need to make our goal in order to pay for important costs that are essential to making this happen. 

  • Space Rental for performances and rehearsals
  • Insurance for our shows
  • Set materials, props and costumes.
  • Promotional Materials (Printing programs for IRT and WWB, Front of House info)
  • Any additional materials for the playwrights at IRT or designers at WWB.

What You Get!

For your generous contribution you can receive one of our fantastic prizes, all themed for theater! Because its FUN to have THEMES! 

Why

This summer is a big step up for our company. Working on both New Works, a revival of our choosing and doing projects that are personal and challenging for actors, ensemble members and audiences alike is what we strive to do every summer.

We are a young company that is striving to put establish itself in the next few summers so our members will have an artistic sanctuary with a commitment to community and process as they enter the professional world. 

We appreciate any kind of support or donations you are able to give. Again, it is truly your help that makes our dreams and ideas possible. If you have any questions regarding our company, events or just want to say hi, feel free to send us an email at g45productions@gmail.com.


Love, Like, Support

One last thing, if you haven’t yet, please like our Facebook page, where you can find updates and information about G45 productions and its artists.

Check us out here!

Send us some likes and loves here!

Tweets at us here!

story:
Ripple Theatre Project was created to enrich the cultural fabric of Redlands and the surrounding area: creating theatre that encourages empathy, broadens perspectives, and ignites imaginations. Ripple produces unique, intimate dessert-theatre experiences.  In It’s a Wonderful Life, a Live Radio Play, the audience will have a chance to watch the actors create the radio foley sound effects up-close while enjoying a timeless Christmas classic.

Ripple’s Executive Director, Tineke Raak has a Master’s Degree in Arts Administration.  Prior to founding Ripple, Tineke was the Business Manager for Blue Man Group in Chicago.

There is an immediate cash-flow issue at the beginning of each production.  Rent, royalties, costumes, and props all need to be paid for up front before a single ticket has been sold. Additionally, most not-for-profit theatres can only count on ticket sales to cover 50% of their budget.  Regardless of the budget size of the organization ticket sales only go so far.  For example:

  • “As a nonprofit, tickets sales only cover approximately 50% of our costs. We need your support at any level to ensure our continued success.”  - Northlight Theatre, Skokie, IL (one of the largest nonprofit theatres in the Chicago area with over 6000 subscribers, serving audiences totaling over 50,000 each season).
  • “Ticket sales cover only 50% of WHBPAC operating costs... We must raise approximately 1.5 million dollars each year to keep the theatre running.” - Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center, Westhampton Beach, NY
  • “Our ticket sales cover less than 50% of our expenses. For the remainder, we rely on the support of our patrons.” - Riverside Theatre, Iowa City, IA
  • “Ticket sales cover less than 50% of our operating expenses.” - Manhattan Class Company, New York, NY
  • “Ticket sales cover only 60% of our total budget.” - Paramount Theatre, Austin, TX

The goal of this campaign is to raise $5,000 to cover the cost of renting Mission Gables, royalties for It’s a Wonderful Life, a Live Radio Play, costumes, and props.  Covering those expenses now allows the money generated from current ticket sales to secure rent and royalties for the next show, Some Enchanted Evening, the Songs of Rodgers and Hammerstein.  Essentially, this campaign will be a step toward a positive cash flow.

Redlands has such potential to grow into a cultural hub.  People already come to Redlands to see shows at the Redlands Bowl, to buy and sell at Market Night, and to enjoy the other arts and culture located here.  Ripple has already had an economic impact on Redlands as audience members drive in to see the show and have dinner at Redlands’ restaurants beforehand.  There is also the benefit of providing advertising in the programs for area organizations and partnerships with local businesses like Bricks and Birch. Looking toward the future, Ripple is planning to send shows to perform at area schools and other organizations.  Ripple is committed to investing in Redlands economically, artistically, and individually while having a positive impact on the community.

We have big plans but we need some help to get there.  This is the first step – getting to positive cash flow.  This campaign is your opportunity to support us in that goal.  In addition to donating money, we can also use your help getting the word out.  Tell people about this campaign.  Come and see our shows, tell your friends to come see them.

Ripple Theatre Project is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Ripple Theatre Project must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Gilli: Aduri Theater Production's Premier Production

Who We Are...

Aduri Theater Productions, LLC is a Brooklyn based theater company founded by Alison, Baindu and Kari Joy. Our purpose is to connect with the community in order to help usher along transformation by presenting works that: stem from a Biblical worldview, expose struggles within the human condition and offer the opportunity for self-reflection.

Gilli!

Aduri is producing its premier production, Gilli, written by co-founder, Alison Campbell. Gilli, is a portrait of a family in the midst of a breakdown. It chronicles a year in the life of The Fletchers as they deal with the fallout from the mental incapacitation of their shining star. 

By supporting Aduri, you will give us the opportunity to raise awareness on an issue that effects one in four adults in a given year, according to the National Alliance on Mental Illness. 

Our Goal...Your Prizes

Gilli is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit service organization. All of the donations that are given on the Indiegogo campaign are tax-deductible. All of the donations that we receive will go towards our production costs.

Check out the PERKS section on the right! Choose 1 of the perks or give a completely tax-deductible donation.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many additional ways you can support us! 

  • Tell your family and friends about Gilli and Aduri!
  • Like us on Facebook! www.facebook.com/AduriTheaterProductions
  • Become an Aduri Teamster! To volunteer, email: contact@aduritheaterproductions.com
  • Check out our website for updates! www.aduritheaterproductions.com

Thank you for your support!

*********

Co-Founders:

Alison Campbell (Director/Producer)

Baindu Kalokoh (Outreach Coordinator/Producer)

Kari Joy Hinkson (Stage Manager/Producer)

Performers:

Baindu Kalokoh

Bonnie Jones

Correne Bolds

Douglas Walker

Metushaleme Dary

Teniece Divya Johnson

story:
Our Story

In 2008, Porcelain and Miss Rachel Riot started Raleigh, NC's first burlesque troupe: The Demon Dolls. Both are passionate about the art form and would like nothing more than to attend the Burlesque Hall of Fame Weekend in Las Vegas, NV this Memorial Day Weekend. As most creative types know, usually artistic endeavors don't create a ton of extra income-- which is why YOU are being asked to help fund their trip to Las Vegas! Money will be used for plane tickets, room and board, and food. Porcelain and Miss Rachel Riot want to be able to represent North Carolina at the largest and most important burlesque gathering in the United States.

The Impact

Your donations help spread glitter, cheer, and fabulousness from coast to coast. Not only do Porcelain and Rachel Riot get to meet burlesque icons, but Las Vegas gets to meet Rachel Riot and Porcelain as well!


What We Need & What You Get

Our fundraising goal is $3000. Flying on Memorial Day Weekend is going to cost us almost $1000, hotel for four nights, taxi's, shipping costumes, etc. Don't worry-- you get something for the money you donate! Check out our "perks"!


Other Ways You Can Help

SHARE, SHARE, SHARE! Share this with everyone you've ever met, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever.

Our Story
In 2008, Porcelain and Miss Rachel Riot started Raleigh, NC's first burlesque troupe: The Demon Dolls. Both are passionate about the art form and would like nothing more than to attend the Burlesque Hall of Fame Weekend in Las Vegas, NV this Memorial Day Weekend. As most creative types know, usually artistic endeavors don't create a ton of extra income-- which is why YOU are being asked to help fund their trip to Las Vegas! Money will be used for plane tickets, room and board, and food.
