story:
Short Summary

  • The Sons of Perdition are a talent based all male burlesque troupe.
    When they are not peeling off their clothing for eager crowds of people, the guys that make up the Sons of Perdition are:
    Personal Trainers
    Acrobats
    Body Builders
    Circus Performers
    Gymnasts
    Gold Medalists (New Mexico Games 2010-2011)
    Actors
    Opera Singers
    Martial Artists
    Professional Dancers

    Some of our charity performance have benefited: Southwest CARE Center International AIDS Empowerment

What We Need & What You Get


We are hoping to raise $1000 to purchase costumes, pay musicians, stage effects, and props, and other materials necessary to make our show all it can be and to help us move towards the goal of making our troupe successfull and taking the show to other cities.  Currently, we and our unsung heroes backstage not only dazzle you on stage, spend a great deal of time choreographing and rehearsing, and push our creative selves to the limit. We also build our own props and create our own costumes in house.  Reaching our $1000 goal will ease this burden and allow our performers to keep their focus where it should be...on their performance! Even if our total goal is not met, the money raised will still be used for the purpose of helping us grow...every little bit helps!

  • Where is this money going?
    PUBLICITY - $200
    This goes to pay for printing flyers and our graphic designer.

    MUSIC - $250
    We want to provide a fun and authentic atmosphere to help our fans have a great time. This goes to the very  talented Affinity Jazz Combo.

    CHAIRS - $100 Ya gotta have seats, am I right?

    REHEARSAL SPACE - $100
    We are fortunate enough to have access to a beautiful dance studio for our rehearsals and would like to repay our choreographer for this generosity.

    COSTUMES/EQUIPMENT - $300
    This will go towards our costuming needs such as clothing items to be altered, fancy underpants, wireless microphone, athletic tape, aerial rigging, props, etc.

    EMERGENCY FUND - $50
    Cloth tears, glass breaks, things go missing. This money will go to our "Oh, shit!" fund that will help replace things that break/go missing hours before the show.

Other Ways to Help?

     So you can't contribute to our campaign at present but still want to lend a helping hand?  Of course!  There's plenty you can do!  Perhaps you own a business that might want to sponsor us, or maybe you are a local who is skilled at prop making or costuming and would like to lend your skills.  Maybe you can put us in touch with a venue who'd like to book us for a show.  Certainly you can spread the word about our campaign to others...and, of course, come on out to a show and show us your support!  In any case, you have our thanks!

story:
HELP US TAKE OUR HIT SHOW ON THE ROAD!

No Stopping, No Warping, No Dying was a stand-out hit at the 2012 Chicago Fringe and just finished a wildly successful late-night run at The Artistic Home Studio, and now we want to take the show to St. Louis, Minnesota, and New York City!

THE PLAY:

No Stopping, No Warping, No Dying is a two-person, 50-minute play that tells the story of two best friends bound throughout their lives by a mutual obsession with Super Mario Brothers.  As children of the eighties, they build a friendship around the games they play as children that carries them through the trials of adolescence and the challenges of adulthood. On a giant Nintendo that transforms into a couch, captain's chairs, and a bed, this comedic romp with a touch of heartbreak takes theatre and video games to the next level.

THE TOUR:

We're already committed to the St. Lou Fringe June 20-23 and the Minnesota Fringe August 1-11, and we're hoping to make it to a festival in New York for a couple of weekends in July.

THE TEAM:

Ed Krystosek (playwright)

Peter Connor (director)

Charles Askenaizer (actor)

Gannon Reedy (actor)

Meg Eaton (stage manager)

Corinne Bass (set designer)

Dan Carlyon (sound designer)

THE CHALLENGE:

We need to raise $11,667 to cover our production expenses: not only must we send our brilliant actors and stage manager around the country with our set and props, we need to house and feed them when they arrive and pay them when they get home. In addition, we need to build those sets and props and promote the show so that audiences can see their work.

Our budget breaks down as follows:

  • Artists - $3100 - Performance pay for our actors and stage manager and travel per diems for our team
  • Production - $2000 - Sets, props, and festival fees
  • Transportation and Housing - $4750 - Getting there and staying there
  • Promotion - $1000 - Getting the word out in each city
  • Fundraising - $817 - Indiegogo's cut for hosting and handling our fundraiser

THE REWARDS:

For our contributors, there are a variety of perks from which to choose. From t-shirts to above-the-title Producer credits, we've got ways for all of you to show and share your support. We'd love for you to finance the whole thing, but a contribution of just $25 will earn you our undying gratitude, expressed in every playbill for every incarnation of the show to come.  For those who can give more, there are producer credits and opportunities to share the show with your friends.

For our team, your help will allow us to share this show with thousands of lucky audience members in three states, and create experiences and exposure for our Chicago-based actors and stage manager in three other theatre communities.

Spread the Word!

Your financial support is important, but helping us reach others who can also support us is invaluable.  Please link to our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, via email, and any other way you can let others know we need their help.

Thanks!

story:
The cable news networks have 24 hours to fill every day - how is it possible that they all cover the same four stories over and over? When there’s a drought in Texas, a battle over bus discrimination in Ohio, and software innovation in Phoenix, why would they cover Miley Cyrus’ appearance on Saturday Night Live as a news story? 

Did you know the White House created a map of America and forgot the top third of Michigan? If you think Americans have a good opinion of Middle America, take a look at this map: http://www.businessinsider.com/this-one-map-shows-what-americans-really-think-of-each-other-2013-8. Where are the smartest states? Where are the dumbest? The ugliest?

National reporters only seem to visit middle America when it's a presidential election year, there’s severe weather or a terrible crime. 

You can be part of the solution to the problem. We need you to do two things: donate and then share this page with your friends. 

WHY IS THE GOAL NOW ONLY $20,000?

We didn't pad the original goal. But we also didn't make that goal and yet we believe so strongly in the mission of this show and the need for it, that we're not willing to give up. So, until we get sponsors, our team will forego salaries. With $20,000, we can get the show launched and get it on to public radio stations immediately. We'll work out the rest of the funding from there. 

WHY IT’S URGENTLY NEEDED: 

We all have a sense that most national coverage focuses on L.A., D.C., and New York, and the statistics bear that out. In a recent survey of stories on NPR between 2006 and 2011, New York had 331 stories per year, Oklahoma had 14. You could say that’s because of population size, but even with its large size and population, Texas got less than half the national average of stories. 

There was a presidential election in 2008, so states like Ohio and Iowa got special attention. If you take presidential politics out of the mix, the numbers are stark: the middle of the country doesn't get the coverage it deserves. 

This is more than a show. This is the beginning of a revolution in news coverage. 

WHY WE NEED YOUR DONATION: 

We’re doing something that the big networks won’t. In order to do that, we need to launch this show independently, outside of the network system. If we want to maintain editorial control and stick to our core principles (stories only from middle America, partnerships with local stations), then we need to remain independent. 

And that means we need your donation. 

Listen to the pilots:

****************************

WHY WE CAN DO THIS BETTER THAN ANYONE: 

Celeste Headlee spent years reporting from Flagstaff, Arizona and then Detroit, Michigan before she became a national host on NPR and PRI. She knows from personal experience how hard it is to get stories from Middle America on the national shows and she’s heard the terrible coverage that results from sending D.C. reporters parachuting into a city to cover a story. Many people in this business automatically assume that stories from New York and L.A. are more important; Celeste does not. 

WHAT WE NEED: 

A basic studio setup with a mic, mixer, Telos unit for recording phone calls, acoustic foam for the walls and audio editing software. Those are all one-time investments. But we also need funds to pay local reporters for their stories, to pay commentators, and to pay local stations for studio time. 

WHAT WE WILL DO: 

Publish weekly updates for local stations to drop into existing programming. We will partner closely with stations in Middle America, give their reporters a platform and bring attention to the news of their communities. We’ll also publish longer podcasts regularly with the news, politics and culture of Middle America, bringing you the stories that national networks ignore and helping you understand the nation in a way you never have before. 

We will bring your countrymen and women a little closer, let you get to know the people that make this nation unique. This part is guaranteed. 

AND we will choose a home station for the show, a headquarters somewhere in the middle of the country. We will move our operations to that local public radio station and find a national distributor. This is the part we can’t guarantee, but there’s a lot of interest already from both stations and distributors. We just need a boost from you to get it off the ground.

It all starts with your donation.

story:
Who We Are

TE San Pedro Rep offers the Southern California community a unique alternative to the typical L.A. theater experience. A wholehearted celebration of empowered artistic innovation - from every background and medium, TESPR strives to reawaken the creative spirit in each of us. 

True to its name, TE San Pedro Rep is an artistic paradise - a caring, dedicated community fully invested in the work of every inspired craftsman. We joyfully embrace the interdisciplinary nature of performance, utilizing every aspect of human experience to delve further and further into the unknown. Through intelligent and fearless exploration, TESPR is committed to reexamining the fundamental works that have defined performance from Ancient Greece to Modern America. We knowingly stand on the shoulders of giants, casting our vision forward into a new era of American performance.

We remain committed to fueling the next generation of American art, creating visionary work that rattles the foundations of modern performance.

What We Need & What You Get

Your generous contribution will help "Raise The Curtain" on TE San Pedro Rep's production of WOULDN'T IT BE LOVELY?- opening April 4th, 2014!

The Goal: $1,000 for the show's production budget and marketing efforts!

TESPR is giving all supporters of our production a Supporting Cast, Producer or Executive Producer credit - each with it's own perks and levels of recognition.

The Production

From the director of Cymbeline, adapted from George Bernard Shaw's "Pygmalion" and the beloved stage musical "My Fair Lady," Theatrum Elysium San Pedro Rep (TESPR) presents you with the modern fairy tale "Wouldn't It Be Lovely!"

Using our trademark style of unique and immersive theatrical experiences, TESPR celebrates Shaw's dynamic language by innovatively infusing modern dance and music into the heart of the iconic story we all know and love.

"Wouldn't It Be Lovely" is a production that showcases our 2014 Repertory Company of actors, designers and technicians, each providing their own individual aesthetic and artistic prowess. Join us for the next chapter of TESPR's growth in our San Pedro community as we offer a passionate, hilarious and devastating tale that delves deep into the core of the simple human desire to be seen for who we really are.

Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
Cripes! I'm Prime Minister

This will be a rollicking, farcical riotous ride of fun. And might get us asking, if we complain so much about our politicians, why don't we care more about how they get where they are in the first place?

Here is a brief plot description to give you an idea of what you can help me achieve:

Cripes! I'm Prime Minister- from Bojo to PM in one smooth move.

"One year, instead of choosing the head boy himself, the headmaster of a 6th form College in the town of Win Win launches an inter house competition open to boys only. This way, whoever gets the most votes from fellow pupils and staff, will be elected the school Head Boy, or "Prime Minister", as the headmaster Jeremy Axman likes to call it. 

Here is the Noteworth College Song (from the Latin!):

Let the voices of all sing of the best job in the land, giving due praise to the sponsors. Mindful of their benefaction, let us sing together how great were Rupert Murdoch and the Hedge Funders. So long as Capitalism cherishes the shores of England, Noetworth College will flourish.

And here is the Noteworth College Motto (again translated from the Latin of course!):

May The Oligarchy last forever; may there always be cash for questions; may our expenses never be revealed; may God forgive John Major; may we not make distasteful jokes about the North of England; may no person from North of Watford ever be Prime Minister; may the boys of Noteworth College rule ever more.


What We Need & What You Get

We are on a timeline and the musical will be ready to be cast at the end of March 2014. The month of April will be rehearsals and the inevitable rewrites. The month of May is preview time. If it does well, hope to get it put on for a run at an off West End Theatre and take it from there. With Bojo and Mistress Merkel on board, we cannot go too far wrong!

In order to cover rehearsal venues and employment costs of the 10 strong team throughout April and for two weeks of May, we need £3000.

In order to advertise it and get costumes and wigs that sweep you off your feet, we need £2000.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate but like the sound of the project, do get in touch as the more people behind us the better. We are also looking for someone to film the spectacle and make a documentary about the "making of Cripes! the Musical". Then we will send a free DVD to all supporters!

story:
Short Summary

Hello.  I’m Caitlin Hafer, artistic director of DanceLens.  Through Dance Lens, and the creation and presentation of dance films, I make dance accessible to people unfamiliar with or apprehensive of dance in general.  My goal is to make everyone comfortable with viewing dance, increase the audience, and strengthen the art form for the future.   

My newest project is entitled Even A Dead Fish.  

The project uses recognizable and relatable topics, such as conformity and socialization and popular film techniques such as Omnimax, 180 degree presentation, to create a dance performance that is both artistically relevant and easily accessible to all audiences. 

Working with me on this project are Angela Mazziota, Katie Cassady, Colin Epstein, Kelvin Vu.  Each brings a unique viewpoint, both artistic and personal, to the project.  All of the collaborators have extensive technical training and are highly creative artists.  It is an honor to have such a talented and accomplished cast working with me on this project.   

The work draws material from media images of the 1950s and today regarding socialization and the ways in which media depicts “proper” behavior.   Each of my awesome collaborators, Angela Mazziota, Katie Cassady, Colin Epstein, and Kelvin Vu, performs a section in the work depicting a different aspect of socialization.  The project will be presented at The Garage December 19 and 20th and at other, later, events and locations.

What We Need & What You Get

But I need your help to bring these plans into reality. 

Because part of my goal is sustaining the artform, and my collaborators play such a major role in the realization of the work, my first necessity is paying the dancers.  That is what the first $1,000 is for.  The second need is the projectors for creating the omnimax style presentation.  Because many theaters have only one projector we need two more projectors to complete the project.  For this we need another $1,000. 

That’s what we need.  Read on to learn how you can help us reach our $2,000 goal.

Furthermore, your donation is tax deductable through out Fiscal Sponsor Dancers’ Group! Make checks payable to Dancers’ Group (our fiscal sponsor) with Dancelens in the memo line.  Or you can pay online through Pay-Pal.  

The Impact

By helping to fund this project you are also helping to sustain dance as an artform into the future.  While the funding for artist fees relate only to this project, the projectors can and will be used for many projects to come.  Also, this work can be a template for myself and others to investigate other ways that dance artists can create more accessible works to help increase and strengthen the audience into the future.  Thus, by supporting this campaign you are not only funding this work, but helping to support future works and the artform as a whole.  

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways you can help besides monetary donations.  I am accepting donations of SD Camera cards, pudding and Jello mix, and saran wrap.  If you have another an item or skill you think would be helpful, please contact us with your suggestion!

The most important way you can help is to spread the word about Even A Dead Fish.  Tell everyone you know and come to see the show December 19 and 20th at The Garage!!

story:
About Signno

Signno is a nobody. He hates his life and has plans to end it. But then he meets Death, and everything changes. The Irresistible Rise of Signno by playwright and director Indika Ferdinando is the creative component of his PhD research based at Monash University, Australia. Indika’s study looks at the holistic sensory nature of Sri Lankan ritual and assimilates these all-sensory components in theater. The narrative of the play draws from ritual, fairytale, mythology, folklore and Buddhism. The performance incorporates Sri Lankan traditional dance, mask, pyrotechnics, acrobatics and musical compositions in folk fusion. Through its dark humour, the play explores the ever shifting nature of power, greed, desire and faith in the human condition. 


About Director

Indika began his career as a playwright and director at a very young age and received his first state theatre award at the age of 19. He has since received several State Theatre Festival and Youth Theatre Festival awards, including Director and Playwright of the year in 2010 for Colombo Colombo which was subsequently staged at several South Asian theatre festivals. Ho Gaanaa Pokuna (The Singing Pond) marks Indika’s cinematic debut as a screenwriter and director. The film has reached festivals around the world and won the Teacher’s Award Jury Prize at the Chicago International Children’s Film Festival and Best Child Performance Award at the 55th ZLIN International Film Festival for Children and Youth.  


From the Director

Thank you for visiting our page. The decision to produce and perform my PhD production in Sri Lanka was essentially driven by the availability of resources, especially in terms of performers, that are required for a project of this nature. I am delighted to have assembled a team of both experienced and new actors/dancers, who have committed hundreds of hours to achieving the outcome that I expect from this work. Creating exciting theatre experiences has always been my passion and this play will be no exception. By drawing from Sanni Yakuma and Gammaduwa rituals, the play attempts to tap into all the senses of the audience, thus extending the conventional audio-visual theatre experience to one that is far more engaging. We are currently into the second month of rehearsals and look forward to sharing this theatre experience with you in mid-October. 


We need your help 

AUD 5000 sounds like a lot, but it adds up surprisingly fast when it comes to a production of this nature. Everyone in the cast and crew are working for free as we all believe in the show. But the production does provide a small travel stipend to actors and crew as well as refreshments during rehearsals. If you choose to donate, the contributions will go toward paying for transport, the performance space, sets, props, costumes, lights, equipment required to perform pyrotechnics, and so much more. It is a combination of all this that would help us create a compelling theatre experience that simultaneously meets the requirements of the research. 


All of our exclusive donator perks are listed on the right-hand side of this page. Click on the perk to claim it, or simply donate using the link at the top of the page if you don't wish to receive any perks.

Sometimes, you simply can't afford to donate financially, and as artists, we  understand this. But there are other ways you can support us:

     · Like us on Facebook: 

     · Share this IndieGogo campaign!

     · Buy a ticket. Come see the show!

Thank you for being an important part of The Irresistible Rise of Signno, for supporting Sri Lankan theatre and practice-led research.

story:
Catch A Star Theatrical (CAST) Players, founded in 2010, is the community theater in Beaumont, CA. Since our first days in the Beaumont Women's Club Community Center, we  have put up 3 to 4 productions per year of such a quality that our directors, actors and set designer have been nominated for 37,  and won 27, awards for excellence from the Inland Theatre League (ITL). During those years, we also  have improved the live theater experience for our patrons in the community center by employing a "cabaret" seating plan, and by installing new curtains and  a new sound system.  Now, we want to enhance that experience even more.

Our Objective

Toward that end, we are seeking to install fixed theatrical lighting in our performing venue to replace the light trees with the 20th century light “cans” hanging from each limb we have been using since we opened the doors. LED fixtures will not only provide more illumination on and around the stage, but will allow for the use of color combinations, one of the languages of mood creation, all while requiring much less electricity. The new installation will also relieve creaky backs and tired muscles from having to move the old trees in and out and up and down each night of every production! Please help us re-light that stage!

story:
Who are Haste?

Haste Theatre are an international physical theatre company who formed in 2013 specialising in clown, physical storytelling, live music and multi-disciplinary performance. Since forming, we have worked tirelessly to create 3 original shows from scratch, touring the UK, Italy and America, reaching a live audience of almost 6,000 across three countries and winning numerous awards including ‘Best International Show’ (Orlando 2014), ‘Outstanding World Premiere’ (San Diego 2014) and ‘Critics Award for Creativity’ (Rome 2013).

This summer, we are focusing on raising our company’s professional profile in the UK to reach new audiences, showcase our work to a multitude of theatres and producers, making the next important step in our company’s development. After being selected as one of Ideastap’s Emerging Graduate Theatre Companies 2015, we are now focusing on touring two shows, Beyond Cragporth Rock and The Hideout.


What are you funding?

  1. A tour of Beyond Cragporth Rock, in association with director Ally Cologna to five regional venues-
    19th June, Lowry Studio, Salford
    20th June, Bridport Arts Centre
    22nd, 23rd, 24th, June, Exeter Bikeshed
    25th, 26th June, Marlowe Studio, Canterbury
    27th June, Notthingham Playhouse Studio

This is a huge step for Haste as it is our first regional tour to established UK venues! We aim to build positive relationships with venues to ensure future bookings for longer runs, as well as attract other venue programmers to our work for future tours. We will also be reaching a vast new audience to build our already established audience base in the UK!  

2. A tour of The Hideout across the UK Fringe Festival circuit, as well as Rome Fringe and a London run. Dates are:

          31st May - 4th June, Rome Fringe                                                                                                   10th & 11th July, Spread Eagle, Croydon                                                                                       19th & 20th July, Bread and Roses, London                                                                                 23rd & 24th July, Old Joint Stock, Birmingham Fest                                                                 28th & 29th July, Kings Arms, Greater Manchester Fringe                                                     5th - 31st August, Edinburgh Fringe (C Venues)                                                                    

We’ve also just come back from a very successful four-show stint at Brighton Fringe! By participating in these festivals we will take our work to new cultural hubs, as well as building audience base and relations with industry professionals. It will allow us to continue developing The Hideout, as we are constantly working to ensure our work is off the highest standard and never rest on our laurels. 

But are you guys actually any good? Why should we give you our hard earned money?

“Haste Theatre are better than One Direction” – our mums.

But in all seriousness, we have been working extremely hard for two years and have picked up 7 international awards, sold out numerous theatres and had some really nice things written about us. But don’t just trust our mums’ word, here’s what other people have been saying...

Beyond Cragporth Rock-
“genuinely shocking and dramatic, powerful and emotional, awful and beautiful. FOUR STARS” Ruth Gledhill (previously of The Times)

"It was an emotional rollercoaster, and had me in stitches to feeling completely shellshocked." – Audience member

The Hideout

"Fantastical, inventive, funny... a must-see" - SD Reader USA

“Sheer brilliance... courageous, sincere and touching all at once... the company’s energy, commitment and versatility made for an entertaining take on an ancient and often-told story” – Fringe Review

“A raunchy, fast moving cabaret. Unmissable” – Michael Glover, Arts Critic for The Independent

"One of the best things I've seen in ages, you should definitely check these guys out."
"Superb show - a complete joy - clever, imaginative and very very funny! Totally loved it - thank you” – Audience reviews

Other praise:

“HIGHLY RECOMMENDED SHOW; a real delight... endlessly innovative” – Fringe Guru

story:
Short Summary

Hello, friends! My name is Jason Rosenberg and I am a Philadelphia-based theater artist living with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis, Autoimmune Hepatitis, and Ulcerative Colitis. This fall, at The People's House, I'll be premiering a new play in the FringeArts Philadelphia Fringe Festival,  written by and starring me! It's called "Me First: An Autobiographical Comedy about Dying" and it will be a meta-theatrical exploration about what it means to live while you're dying just a little bit faster than everyone else, and how people with disabilities experience the world. 

There's a puppet show, stand up about pooping, a really funny powerpoint, and maybe even a song or two! I want this play to foster conversations between sick and healthy people alike, and to truly explore the barriers of communication that exist between these two groups in a way that engages empathy, not pity. I want to use this play as a way to figure out how I would like to be treated by the people who love me, and to help other disabled people figure it out for themselves. I also want to increase awareness for these diseases and help advocate for the rights of the people struggling every day to be "normal." 

To do all these things, I've assembled a team of truly excellent artists and collaborators (and my best friends) to help me bring this wacky, funnysad play to life! But we need your help! 

What We Need & What You Get

While we are absolutely committed to doing this play for as cheap as possible, unfortunately, live theater is a pretty costly medium, and we've got a lot of things we need to buy! Your contributions will help pay for: 

  • Our venue
  • Props! As any Carrot Top enthusiast will tell you, props are the key to comedy! 
  • Set/lighting design elements
  • Equipment rental fees (projectors are unfortunately, very non-gratis)
  • Printing materials (posters, flyers, postcards, all the things we need to spread the word and pack our tiny little house to the rafters!) 
  • FringeArts costs: Registration, liability insurance, all that boring stuff. 

The Impact

While spreading awareness for these diseases and advocating for disabilities is a  very important part of the mission of this show, we are firm believers in the "put your money where your mouth is" school of thought. Any money we have left over from our contributions after production costs, as well as all of our ticket sales, will be split between two amazing charitable organizations:

THE AMERICAN LIVER FOUNDATION-

Founded in 1976, the American Liver Foundation (ALF) is the nation’s leading nonprofit health organization for people living with liver disease. They are a nationwide network of staff and volunteers that provides awareness, outreach, education and patient support services to educate the public about liver health and to improve the lives of individuals and their families affected by liver disease. Their mission is to facilitate, advocate and promote education, support and research for the prevention, treatment and cure of liver disease.

Follow them on Facebook at 
https://www.facebook.com/liverinfo
or check out their website: www.liverfoundation.org 
PSC PARTNERS SEEKING A CURE- 

PSC Partners Seeking a Cure is a volunteer organization that was formed in 2005 to provide primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) patients and their caregivers education and support and to raise funds to research the origins and a cure for the disease. PSC Partners Seeking a Cure is a 501(c)3 nonprofit foundation. The mission of the PSC Partners Seeking a Cure foundation is to provide education and support to PSC patients, families and caregivers and to raise funds to research causes, treatments and cures for primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Follow them on Facebook at: 
https://www.facebook.com/PscPartnersSeekingACure
or check out their website: www.pscpartners.org 
IMPORTANT NOTE: While these charities will be the beneficiaries of the proceeds of this campaign, your donations are to fund the production of this play and will not be tax deductible. We STRONGLY encourage those who feel so moved to match their donation to this campaign with a donation to one of the above organizations. 
 OUR TEAM
Jason Rosenberg(Playwright) is a Philadelphia based playwright/actor. He recently graduated from UArts with a BFA in playwriting. He is a founding member and resident playwright of Cursed Church Theater, and the Development Associate at Brat Productions. Jason strives to use theater as a means of demonstrable, concrete change, and could not be more excited to start his foray into social justice theater with Me First. For more information, check out his website atwww.jasonrosenberg.weebly.com

Emma Arrick (Co-Director) is a director, performer and multidisciplinary artist living and working in Philadelphia. She holds a BFA in Theatre with focuses in Movement Pedagogy and Interdisciplinary Collaboration from the University of the Arts. Emma is a founding co artistic director of Cursed Church Theater, an artist collective she developed with Jason Rosenberg as a platform to develop his first play and their first collaboration, [sleep] holds them. She is also a company member with Zimbo Films, theSheisaproblem Collective and Brat Productions. Recently Emma closed an artist's residency with BRAT, developing her ongoing project: Plant Me Here, a collaborative experiment rooted in a collection of Jason's poetry. Upcoming: She is a Problem for the Philadelphia Fringe (deviser/collaborator), Plant Me Here pop up performances, an evening of performances dealing with gender identity with VOX Populi (Solo Performance), and Emma Watches the TV (collaboration with Caitlin Dagle)

Anthony Adair (Co-Director) is a performer and director based in the City of Brotherly Love. He holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Acting and Theatre Arts from the University of the Arts in Philadelphia. He is ecstatic to be working with his best friends at Cursed Church Theater and at the prospect of helping facilitate a conversation about what it means to be "sick" with the public. Up next for Anthony is his Philadelphia Theatre Company debut as Abe in DISGRACED

David Reece Hutchison(Producer) is a Philly based Actor and pseudo-producer. He has worked locally with: Mauckingbird Theatre Co., Bristol Riverside, The Arden. David also produced and acted in MAD BLOOD & other beauties that he co-created with Jason and fellow collaborators in last years Fringe. 
Check out his website at www.davidrhutchison.com

Gracie Martin(Composer) is a Philadelphia based performer, deviser and singer/songwriter. Most recently her music has appeared in Plant Me Here (Brat Productions) which was one of several previous collaborations with Jason. Gracie is also co-creator of Sheisaproblem which will be returning from it's tour to Providence, RI as a part of the 2015 Philadelphia Fringe Festival. Up next: The Winter's Tale (Shakespeare in Clark Park)
Other Ways You Can Help 

Wanna help out but tight on funds? That's ok friend, we get it. There are TONS of things we need that aren't money. Share this page with your friends and follow us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/mefirstmefirst! 

Want to get involved in some other way, or just wanna say hey? Email us at mefirstphilly@gmail.com

It's called "Me First: An Autobiographical Comedy about Dying" and it will be a meta-theatrical exploration about what it means to live while you're dying just a little bit faster than everyone else, and how people with disabilities experience the world. 
There's a puppet show, stand up about pooping, a really funny powerpoint, and maybe even a song or two! I want this play to foster conversations between sick and healthy people alike, and to truly explore the barriers of communication that exist between these two groups in a way that engages empathy, not pity. I want to use this play as a way to figure out how I would like to be treated by the people who love me, and to help other disabled people figure it out for themselves. I also want to increase awareness for these diseases and help advocate for the rights of the people struggling every day to be "normal." 
To do all these things, I've assembled a team of truly excellent artists and collaborators (and my best friends) to help me bring this wacky, funnysad play to life! But we need your help!    
What We Need & What You Get
 While we are absolutely committed to doing this play for as cheap as possible, unfortunately, live theater is a pretty costly medium, and we've got a lot of things we need to buy! Your contributions will help pay for: 

Our venue
Props! As any Carrot Top enthusiast will tell you, props are the key to comedy! 
Set/lighting design elements
Equipment rental fees (projectors are unfortunately, very non-gratis)
Printing materials (posters, flyers, postcards, all the things we need to spread the word and pack our tiny little house to the rafters!) 
FringeArts costs: Registration, liability insurance, all that boring stuff. 

    The Impact While spreading awareness for these diseases and advocating for disabilities is a  very important part of the mission of this show, we are firm believers in the "put your money where your mouth is" school of thought. Any money we have left over from our contributions after production costs, as well as all of our ticket sales, will be split between two amazing charitable organizations:
THE AMERICAN LIVER FOUNDATION- 
Founded in 1976, the American Liver Foundation (ALF) is the
nation’s leading nonprofit health organization for people
living with liver disease. They are a nationwide network of staff and volunteers that provides awareness, outreach, education
and patient support services to educate the public about
liver health and to improve the lives of individuals and their
families affected by liver disease. Their mission is to facilitate, advocate and promote education,
support and research for the prevention, treatment and cure
of liver disease.
Follow them on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/liverinfo
or check out their website: www.liverfoundation.org PSC PARTNERS SEEKING A CURE- 
PSC Partners Seeking a Cure is a volunteer organization that was formed in 2005 to provide primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) patients and their caregivers education and support and to raise funds to research the origins and a cure for the disease. PSC Partners Seeking a Cure is a 501(c)3 nonprofit foundation. The mission of the PSC Partners Seeking a Cure foundation is to provide education and support to PSC patients, families and caregivers and to raise funds to research causes, treatments and cures for primary sclerosing cholangitis.
Follow them on Facebook at: https://www.facebook.com/PscPartnersSeekingACureor check out their website: www.pscpartners.org 
IMPORTANT NOTE: While these charities will be the beneficiaries of the proceeds of this campaign, your donations are to fund the production of this play and will not be tax deductible. We STRONGLY encourage those who feel so moved to match their donation to this campaign with a donation to one of the above organizations. 

 OUR TEAM
Jason Rosenberg(Playwright) is a Philadelphia based playwright/actor. He recently graduated from UArts with a BFA in playwriting. He is a founding member and resident playwright of Cursed Church Theater, and the Development Associate at Brat Productions. Jason strives to use theater as a means of demonstrable, concrete change, and could not be more excited to start his foray into social justice theater with Me First. For more information, check out his website atwww.jasonrosenberg.weebly.com
Emma Arrick (Co-Director) is a director, performer and multidisciplinary artist living and working in Philadelphia. She holds a BFA in Theatre with focuses in Movement Pedagogy and Interdisciplinary Collaboration from the University of the Arts. Emma is a founding co artistic director of Cursed Church Theater, an artist collective she developed with Jason Rosenberg as a platform to develop his first play and their first collaboration, [sleep] holds them. She is also a company member with Zimbo Films, theSheisaproblem Collective and Brat Productions. Recently Emma closed an artist's residency with BRAT, developing her ongoing project: Plant Me Here, a collaborative experiment rooted in a collection of Jason's poetry. Upcoming: She is a Problem for the Philadelphia Fringe (deviser/collaborator), Plant Me Here pop up performances, an evening of performances dealing with gender identity with VOX Populi (Solo Performance), and Emma Watches the TV (collaboration with Caitlin Dagle)


Anthony Adair (Co-Director) is a performer and director based in the City of Brotherly Love. He holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Acting and Theatre Arts from the University of the Arts in Philadelphia. He is ecstatic to be working with his best friends at Cursed Church Theater and at the prospect of helping facilitate a conversation about what it means to be "sick" with the public. Up next for Anthony is his Philadelphia Theatre Company debut as Abe in DISGRACED


David Reece Hutchison(Producer) is a Philly based Actor and pseudo-producer. He has worked locally with: Mauckingbird Theatre Co., Bristol Riverside, The Arden. David also produced and acted in MAD BLOOD & other beauties that he co-created with Jason and fellow collaborators in last years Fringe. Check out his website at www.davidrhutchison.com


Gracie Martin(Composer) is a Philadelphia based performer, deviser and singer/songwriter. Most recently her music has appeared in Plant Me Here (Brat Productions) which was one of several previous collaborations with Jason. Gracie is also co-creator of Sheisaproblem which will be returning from it's tour to Providence, RI as a part of the 2015 Philadelphia Fringe Festival. Up next: The Winter's Tale (Shakespeare in Clark Park)


Other Ways You Can Help 


 Wanna help out but tight on funds? That's ok friend, we get it. There are TONS of things we need that aren't money. Share this page with your friends and follow us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/mefirstmefirst! 
Want to get involved in some other way, or just wanna say hey? Email us at mefirstphilly@gmail.com

story:
SUPPORT JASON BLYNN JR 

To the 2014 

ICU World Cheerleading Championship and Summit... 

 

2013-2014 Season

Jason Blynn has.. 

  • Last 3 years he has been a team mate with Vegas Cheer Authority (VCA) and is one of there elite competitors.  Jason will be attending multiple individual competitions representing VCA to include many international world events.

  • Spending 15+ hours in the gym a week working to improve his skills in tumbling, stunting and strength training.
  • Works 8-10 independent hours at VCA doing janitorial work to help pay for his yearly tuition and attends all local community service events.
      • Susan B Koman
      • National Disability Awareness Day
      • Annual Blood drive for leukemia (Remembrance of fellow teammate)
      • Run Walk Roll Against Bullying
      • Cheer for Charity
      • Toy Drive
      • Walk with the Heart of a Child
      • Easter Seals Parade
      • Bottle  for the Homeless
      •  Prom Closet
      • 51s game

 

  • Jason was diagnosed with ADHD at 7 years old and has had many paths that he mentally and physically had to over come. Always looking on the positive side and never letting anyone tell him he could not do something because of his disability. After joining VCA and focusing on self-esteem and physical ability he was able to be taken off his ADHD medication and works everyday on identify his weakness and overcome for success.
  • Jason is working very hard everyday not only for himself but his team to attend these international events.

 

Thank you for taking  the time to consider Jason Blynn Jr. for this opportunity.

story:
Our Story

`AVEI`A, a contemporary Polynesian dance company, created in 2008 by Founder and Artistic Director Anthony Aiu, is a platform for preserving Polynesian cultural heritage and dances through the creation of new dances in traditional form and structure, and to choreograph contemporary works that draw on the rich and abundant inspiration found in these native traditions.  

On May 17, 2014 Aveia will participate alongside thousands of other cultural dancers and receive broader exposure in this years televised Dance Parade in New York City.  Hundreds of dance groups will be viewed by millions of people as they dance down Broadway.  This campaign is important to us because it will help establish a voice for Polynesian cultural heritage in mainstream contemporary dance, and contribute a unique perspective to the dance world from a deep and untouched, influential society.  

We are engaging in community outreach to spread the influence of these island people in hopes to build stronger, unified and informed communities, raise awareness and advocate for tolerance, and encourage progression through cross-cultural communication.  

These indigenous cultural dances are highly under represented in New York City and often misunderstood.  Even the pure and exquisite spoken languages of these islands, are in danger of becoming extinct. Our campaign is to raise funds that will cover production costs including: registration and participation fees, securing a float and reliable sound system, rehearsal studio rental, promotional items, and traditional costumes.  This year we’d like to include members from our community outreach. 

Costuming is expensive and time consuming, your donations will aid in purchasing and shipping of authentic costume materials like hau (grass) skirts, shells, coconut bark, mother of pearl shells, and feathers, for additional handcrafted costumes to be made. You will make it possible for additional members from our community to participate and represent these countries well.   

Your immediate contribution will help make all this a reality!


What We Need Your Help With

The total amount needed is $7655.92.  Below is a carefully calculated list of fees, studio costs, float vehicle rental, and items needed for the additional dancers’ costumes.

  • Registration Fee
  • Vehicle Registration Fee
  • Parade Float Vehicle
  • Sound System
  • Studio Rentals 
  • Costume Materials and shipping (Natural hau fiber skirts, i’i’s, hau tassels, mother of Pearl Shells, cowry shells, Feathers for headdresses and hip bands, visors for headdresses, velcro, thread, plumeria leis, Tahitian Flags, conch shells
  • Promotional Materials


The Impact

Your contribution will directly influence the campaign.  Not only will you help Aveia dance down broadway in style and build the Polynesian audience in NYC, you will allow people to learn and experience a new cultural dance form and help expand a company that houses these unique and rare indigenous forms thus contributing to American contemporary dance.  With your help, we will be able to create riveting and moving dance works that teach and engage, with greater production value.  Aveia is still a young dance group and needs your help to grow.  The company has performed at numerous venues throughout the New York tri-state area since 2008 and has been delightedly received by all audiences.  We hope to continue to grow and with your help and donations, we will be able to change our communities for the better through new and innovative work that is tied to ancient cultural tradition.

MAHALO, MAURUURU ROA, and THANK YOU!!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in a position to contribute monetarily, we are grateful for your desire to help build us.  Some other ways you can help include:

  • Sharing our campaign with friends, family, and other enthusiasts.  Help us make some noise!
  • Use Indiegogo share tools to post our campaign on your social networks.
  • Volunteer to help in our productions.

story:
Short Summary

The Point is a daring and challenging project driven by female artists. Every city has a dark little secret, a shift place in the shadows where sex, drugs, prev’s, pimps and prossy’s can’t be missed. The Point follows three of the local sex workers Cindy, Chargo and Amber through their past, present, future, hopes and fears that comes with being a part of the oldest profession on Earth.

The Point was supposed to premier at The Arches theatre, Glasgow back in June 2015 but five days before our opening night the venue went into administration and the show had to be cancelled.    


Directed by: Mhari Watt
Starring: Jennifer McErlane, Rebecca Burton and Dionne Frati

ADVANCE TICKET SALES:

The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the biggest arts festival in the world and there is no better place to launch The Point but it is an expensive experience. The main purpose of this crowdfunding campaign is to raise most of the money through advanced ticket sales. Instead of asking for donations we are asking people to buy their ticket for the show in advance which will be used to pay the venue costs.


You do not need to know which date you want to attend at this moment, reminders will be sent 6 weeks, 4 weeks, 3 weeks and on the week before the festival to ask you for your booking dates. If you can't make it to the festival you can still make a donation if you want.

Everyone who buys an advance ticket will be given a free copy of the published script and a free show programme. Each person will be thanked in the show programme and in the published script.

Everyone who makes a donation of £5 will be thanked in the show programme and in the published script. Everyone who makes a donation of £15 or more will be thanked and sent a copy of the published script and programme. 


All money raised will go to venue cost.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, you can help by sharing this page and the project with your friends.

story:
Who Are We?

MOLLY PEASE, playwright & executive producer. She is a queer southern comedy writer from Atlanta, Georgia. She holds an MFA in Writing for the Screen and Stage from Northwestern and Bachelor's degrees in Public Relations and Theatre from the University of Georgia. Molly has done pretty much every form of comedy. During her time at Northwestern, she created original sitcom pilots, plays, screenplays, and a sock puppet web series. She helps produce the annual showcase Queergasm at Northwestern. Her full-length play Stix received a stage reading at Northwestern in Spring 2017. Her feature length dramedy Can I Finish? won second place for the Krevoy Screenwriting Award. She currently lives with her cat, Bubby, in Chicago. 

SUSAN E. BOWEN, director & co-producer. Since moving to Chicago eight years ago, Susan has directed and/or assistant directed at companies such as Jackalope Theatre, Lookingglass Theatre, A Red Orchid Theatre, and American Theater Company, among others. Some favorite projects in Chicago include: History 2:2 by Michael Allen Harris for Jackalope Theatre Company’s Living Newspaper Festival and Queer Is Not Yet Here by Jorge Ignacio Cortiñas for Pivot Arts. Most recently, Susan directed a remake of Lope de Vega's Fuente Ovejuna, which she coadapted with playwright Kori Alston at Northwestern University, where she is an MFA candidate in directing.

RACHEL GREENHOE, co-producer. Born and raised in Brooklyn, New York. She holds an MFA in Writing from Northwestern. She attended Sarah Lawrence College, where she studied playwriting with Sterling Spencer, Cassandra Medley and Lucy Thurber. Her play, ‘Not Retarded’, won the David Lindsay-Abaire award for playwriting and had a showcase performance the main stage. Two of her plays, ‘Not Retarded’ and ‘Tiger Trap’, have been produced in Off-Off Broadway showcases. Her latest play, ‘Monkey’, had its first reading at La Mama ETC. In addition to La Mama Rachel has worked with Mabou Mines, DTA, Fresh Fruit and Bass Films and interned with Motion picture Corporation of America and Nickelodeon. 

We also have an INCREDIBLE female-centric team of actors, designers, and more working on this project. We will give you more information about them & their work as the campaign continues!

Why Stix?

It's entertaining. It's fresh. It's relevant. Don't believe us?

Let's ask our team!

From the playwright, Molly Pease: "I know a play about a talking Stick doesn't seem personal, but it feels relevant because it stems from many frustrations I have as a queer female artist today. There are so many ridiculously impossible expectations that we're suppose to meet! Sometimes it feels like a person could only meet those expectations if they were just an inanimate object that people could project their desires onto." 

From our co-producer, Rachel Greenhoe: "I personally love the theme of ‘ownership of stories’ in the play. In these days of easily shared media content, sometimes it feels like no one truly owns their stories."

From creative team member, Oona O'Leary: "It's creative, it's different, it's of the moment without being on the nose."

Stix has also already had a staged reading at Northwestern University. What did they say about it?

Audience member: "This is a dystopian play about American culture seen through the eyes of a stick. He is a total narcissist who is able to rise to power through pop culture. The arc of a celebrity rising to an influential position of power is particularly relevant right now. Overall, it’s a biting, witty play about wellness vs. American Capitalism.”

Speaking of Capitalism...

Currently we have a combined $6,000 in grants from Northwestern University and the Araca Project. However, that only covers 60% of our overall budget. Our ultimate goal is to raise the other 40% to complete a working  production of the show. 

Realistic Budget

(based on past Araca Projects)

Wait, but why me?

Simple, with your donation, you can:

  • Compensate at least 13 hardworking, early career theatre artists. 
  • Get perky! Your donations give you the chance to receive awesome perks: handwritten post cards, original songs, tshirts, tote bags, dinner, and more! 
  • Help fund a professional showcase of multiple female artists who have been working their butts off for YEARS for the chance to work in a NYC production. 
  • Be a vital part of bringing new work to the NYC stages. 
  • Go on a weird, wonderful journey with characters who are hilarious yet oddly relatable and reflect on how society encourages us to commodify our personal tragedies. 
  • Make theater fun again.

"You can't underestimate the value of entertainment" - Stix. 

Other Ways You Can Help

STIX has a robust social media campaign, feeding into the show itself. Follow and get involved! We’d love to hear from you. Facebook and Twitter below:

https://www.facebook.com/StixThePlay/

https://twitter.com/?lang=en

Also you can buy your tickets to the show here:

http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/3051843

Help fund a professional showcase of multiple female artists who have been working their butts off for YEARS for the chance to work in a NYC production. 
Be a vital part of bringing new work to the NYC stages. 
Go on a weird, wonderful journey with characters who are hilarious yet oddly relatable and reflect on how society encourages us to commodify our personal tragedies. 
Make theater fun again.

"You can't underestimate the value of entertainment" - Stix. 

Other Ways You Can Help
STIX has a robust social media campaign, feeding into the show itself. Follow and get involved! We’d love to hear from you. Facebook and Twitter below:
https://www.facebook.com/StixThePlay/
https://twitter.com/?lang=en
Also you can buy your tickets to the show here:
http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/3051843

story:
PWR Presents: FloridaSlam

Party World Rasslin' is a seasonal party and bizarre wrestling spectacle. In March, we went on a Fantasy-RPG-style-quest to slam the heck out of a proud bird man! But a dark power triumphed over our beloved former-champion, Theodosia. Now it's time for SUMMER VENGEANCE! And this time, it's PERSONAL!

PWR prepares for our 16th Party! Can you believe that??? Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—this thing has become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. In ~4 years we've gone from a handful of people watching a home-made ring in a backyard to attendance of two thousand people and a full spectrum of professional audio, video and lighting. And we've built almost all of it ourselves, thanks to you! We continue to do a DIY show that is all-ages and free to the public, even as costs increase. Your continued support allows our core ethos to flourish. It means so much to us. The show remains FREE TO ATTEND, even as we mount mammoth costs. Here's what we want to do for our next show!

WELCOME: To Florida

Summer is here, and it's a special time for PWR! In Junes past we've wrestled amidst Nickelodeon-esque-slime zones and Dinosaur-haunted tropics. Now, we brace to enter the most fearsome environ we ever have: FLORIDA! We're taking our EXTREMELY LIMITED KNOWLEDGE of this great state, and spinning it into a full-fledged art theme! We'll have skeleton flamingos, all kinds of alligators, neon signs, fan boats, golf-course vibes and JUICED OUT tropical aesthetics!.Think BEACH HORROR meets SUMMER GOTH! FLORIDA is coming to TEXAS, and wrestling will NEVER be the same!

THE STORY SO FAR:

The Draconian Birdman - Randy "the Eagle" Eagleman - has captured the Partyweight belt! He's  combined it with his own NECROWEIGHT TITLE, creating a unified championship of horrible power! A dark bargain with unknown Necroforces has been made, the Multiverse shudders! Baby Worm, our reborn deity that we nourish with slams, has transformed into TEEN WORM, and fled! Now Randy is on her trail. We've got to find her before he does, or else the entire world could be at risk.
With Theodosia vanquished, her future uncertain, and Dock Master injured from the last Darkwar, can any hero stand against Randy? Can any...villain stand against Randy?! Someone has to stop him, before it's too late! 

The next chapter will be revealed, as well as Randy's next rival! Expect to see the usual PARTY ATHLETES in action: Dan "the Man" Ziglar, Bench Horse, Luigi Primo, The NARRC, IGX, Big Daddy Bolero, Pink Eye, Babyface, Pastaman, Alexandra Cage, Sweetie Tuff, Dino Rida, Arbitro Obscuro, Puggin'Head and Chubby Uncle Juan, Hot Dog, Skip Rathbone, and MANY, MANY MORE!

 

What is this money used for?

$5400 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important recitation: PWR is free and we want to keep it free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.

PWR is also now a 80-person organization putting on a show for nearly 2000 people. TWO OF THUNDO! Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spent north of $9000, each, to produce our last 2 shows.

Through diligent saving and prudent investment, we've managed to cap our fundraising goal at ~$5400 (up ~$400 due to porta-cool rentals). We are continuously able to improve the show and make it grander; your support and our rigorous planning have allowed us to do this without ballooning our costs! And it's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than two years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHT

Some of the cool things your donations will help us do include:

  • Cooling. 4th Tap Brewing Co-Op is an awesome space, with plenty of room for our ring and a whole bunch of people, plus an air conditioned tap room. However, there's no central AC in the ring-room. It's gonna get hot, and we want everyone to be comfortable: That's why we spent hundreds of dollars installing a new airflow system last year, as well as portable coolers for our VIP area. But that's not enough  - we're building 2, 5-foot tall risers to mount high-powered evaporative coolers on. With your help, we hope to knock the temp down another 10-20 degrees!

  • Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into a DRAGON-CURSED DUNGEON for our last show! Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

  • Paying artists. We work hard to make sure everyone who contributes to our production gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, or our A/V crew.

  • Safer space/security: PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

  • Projection and lighting. PWR has some of the most advanced lighting for an independent wrestling show in the country! And we built it ourselves, with your help. We still have tweaks to make. If you saw our lights at the last show, you know how shockingly powerful our latest generation is! Also, our projection system allows people to watch the show from 3 different places in the venue, each with different sitting and standing options!

  • Training: Party Violence is its own unique sport. We have crafted a training program that makes use of experienced pro-wrestling coaching to help keep our PARTY ATHLETES smooth n' safe.  

  • Profit split: after we cover all our costs, we take 20% of our profits and reinvest it in PWR. We split up whatever is left among performers and staff who worked on the show.

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a majority of them. Below is our complete budget.

Show Expenses: $2825

Props: $250

Coolers: $450

Art: $550

Staff Food: $80

Live Video Projection: $235

Promo Material $100

Security: $140

Insurance: $385

Printing: $260

Construction: $350

PA: $225
Gaffe Tape: $50

Operational Expenses: $2850

Artist and staff pay: $2450
New Projects Capital : $400

Indiegogo Reward production and fulfillment: $2864
Indiegogo and credit card fees: $522.00

Extremely Hype Swag

We've got SO MUCH CRAZY STUFF this time for you to check out! Including a brand new T-shirt and Tank top by Nat Bradford. Check out the  DRAFT VERSION of the shirt, available in black or summer mint!



But that's not all, how about some laser-cut, acrylic pins by Nat Bradford?

The Florida doesn't stop here...we've got a silkscreened poster by Rory Blank!


Get ready for UNNECESSARILY MORE MERCH...It's PWR Frisbee from Zeke Guadiana!

And while your throwin' that ol' disk, how 'bout coolin your drink with a koozie by Nat Bradford, that looks like this?!

Check out this paaaatch! Also by Nat!

Risks & Challenges

 

Challenges:

PWR has become robust and its universe swole with powerful party drama. As it continues to grow wantonly like an uncontrollable teen (and our expectations for our performance climb) we approach a new realm of costs we could not have imagined before.  We are depending on the support of our Multiverse to keep our show free and open—thank you for your continued support.  Rest assured we are working night and day to make sure this event is the most fun thing you do all quarter.

 

Risks:

The only risk is the risk of not partying hard enough. We laugh at the concept of "risk." It is as outmoded as "shame," or "weakness." We have sworn to party 'til death, and we will do so.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and SPACESLAM!


Here is the Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/202690457126868/

HMW
story_txt:
PWR Presents: FloridaSlamParty World Rasslin' is a seasonal party and bizarre wrestling spectacle. In March, we went on a Fantasy-RPG-style-quest to slam the heck out of a proud bird man! But a dark power triumphed over our beloved former-champion, Theodosia. Now it's time for SUMMER VENGEANCE! And this time, it's PERSONAL!PWR prepares for our 16th Party! Can you believe that??? Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—this thing has become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. In ~4 years we've gone from a handful of people watching a home-made ring in a backyard to attendance of two thousand people and a full spectrum of professional audio, video and lighting. And we've built almost all of it ourselves, thanks to you! We continue to do a DIY show that is all-ages and free to the public, even as costs increase. Your continued support allows our core ethos to flourish. It means so much to us. The show remains FREE TO ATTEND, even as we mount mammoth costs. Here's what we want to do for our next show!WELCOME: To FloridaSummer is here, and it's a special time for PWR! In Junes past we've wrestled amidst Nickelodeon-esque-slime zones and Dinosaur-haunted tropics. Now, we brace to enter the most fearsome environ we ever have: FLORIDA! We're taking our EXTREMELY LIMITED KNOWLEDGE of this great state, and spinning it into a full-fledged art theme! We'll have skeleton flamingos, all kinds of alligators, neon signs, fan boats, golf-course vibes and JUICED OUT tropical aesthetics!.Think BEACH HORROR meets SUMMER GOTH! FLORIDA is coming to TEXAS, and wrestling will NEVER be the same!THE STORY SO FAR:The Draconian Birdman - Randy "the Eagle" Eagleman - has captured the Partyweight belt! He's  combined it with his own NECROWEIGHT TITLE, creating a unified championship of horrible power! A dark bargain with unknown Necroforces has been made, the Multiverse shudders!
