story:
We believe #TheOperaIsAlive! For us, making opera is a job for the present moment. That´s why La Nueva Escena (The New Stage), a team of young artists, has decided to bring an original production of this genre to the Latin American stages. Join us!

Thanks for watching our video! Here you can learn more about this project and its creators!

¡Gracias por ver nuestro video! Acá puedes leer un poco más sobre nuestro proyecto y sus creadores!

¿Quiénes somos?

La Nueva Escena es un colectivo conformado por jóvenes creadores que se han interesado por traer a la escena cultural nuevas obras escenográficas, haciendo un énfasis inicial en la producción de ópera inédita en castellano, proyectos que aún buscan tener cabida en las agendas culturales de Colombia. La Nueva Escena es, también, una plataforma de creación para todas las exploraciones que se propongan cercanas al mundo de los escenarios.

Who are we? 

La Nueva Escena is a group made up of young artists who have decided to bring new stage works into the cultural scene. All of this, making an initial emphasis in the production of new operas in spanish, a field still unexplored in the cultural agenda of Colombia. La Nueva Escena is also a creative platform for all art forms that are related to the stage.

¿Qué es Melpómene?

El primer proyecto del colectivo, Melpómene, drama lírico en un acto, busca presentar una propuesta de ópera de cámara en español, escrita para una sola intérprete con trío de piano, clarinete y violoncello. Compuesta por F. Hoyos González con base en el libreto del autor G. Galo, el drama propuesto por los autores explora el mito trágico de Melpómene, Musa regente de la tragedia, en reinterpretación contemporánea para crear un puente entre la tradición clásica y el malestar actual en la cultura, de donde se vale para crear la estructura narrativa que no hace mano del tradicional monólogo para la ópera de cámara, sino que, manteniendo una sola intérprete en escena, logra forjar dos personajes en un solo cuerpo. Se manifiesta, pues, como corresponde al género, un profundo trabajo de colaboración entre la literatura y la música, todo a su vez  enmarcado en el montaje teatral de la obra.

What is Melpómene?

The first project of the group, Melpómene, lyric drama in one act, is a chamber opera in spanish, composed for a single performer accompanied by a trio of piano, clarinet and violoncello. Composed by F. Hoyos Gonzalez and based on the a script by G. Galo, the drama explores the tragical myth of Melpómene, reining Muse of tragedy. The opera is a contemporary interpretation of the myth, all in the effort of creating a bridge between tradition and the current problems in society. This metaphorical bridge is represented by the lack of the typical monologue, but instead by maintaining a single person on the stage and creating two characters in one body. In this way, and as is expected of the genre, there is a profound collaboration between literature, music and theatre.

¿Cuál es la importancia de este proyecto?

El teatro y la música, ámbitos muy fuerte en la industria cultural, no siempre da lugar a nuevas producciones de ópera joven. Este proyecto parece oportuno para abrir nuevos espacios para nuevos públicos donde continúe la exploración del canto, el texto y las artes escénicas, dándole esa mayor presencia que acaso amerite en los escenarios y espacios académicos de Colombia. No solo nos acercaremos a los espectadores, sino que nos importa crear un acceso a una nueva plataforma de creación que se propone estar abierta para aquellos artistas (estudiantes y profesionales) que quieran incursionar en la interdisciplinariedad de las áreas tan variadas que la ópera esencialmente reúne como la puesta en escena, la actuación, la dramaturgia y la poesía, la música y el canto.

What is the importance of this project?

Music and theatre, strong fields in cultural industry, are not often associated with productions of new opera. This project is the perfect opportunity to open new spaces to new audiences, where we can continue to explore on singing, text and theatre. Not only are we reaching out to spectators, but we are also making way towards a new creative platform which will be open to all artists interested in the areas that opera comprises, such as acting, poetry, music, singing and dramaturgy.

¿Cuáles son nuestras metas y desafíos?

  • Llevar a buena terminación la producción Melpómene, estrenando la primera semana de agosto de 2017.
  • Presentar la obra en al menos tres escenarios del país, incluyendo espacios académicos.
  • Abrir foros de debate y socialización sobre los procesos que ameritan este tipo de producciones en la región.
  • Posicionar a La Nueva Escena en el panorama cultural del país como una plataforma de creación e interacción entre jóvenes creadores.
  • ¡Que esta sea la fuente para otras y más ambiciosas producciones!

Which are our goals and challenges?

  • To complete the production of Melpómene, premiering the first week of August 2017.
  • To perform the opera in at least 3 stages in Colombia, including academic ones.
  • To encourage local debate about the process required to bring about this kind of productions.
  • To position La Nueva Escena in the cultural map of the country, as a platform of creation and interaction among young artists.
  • To make this the source for other, more ambitious projects!

¿Cómo puedes ayudarnos?

Necesitamos tu apoyo para poder financiar este proyecto. ¡Tenemos el equipo, tenemos las ideas, las mentes creadoras y el ímpetu! Ahora necesitamos tu apoyo. ¡Ayúdanos y haz parte de Melpómene!

Al invertir en el proyecto estarías contribuyendo en lo siguiente:

How can you help?

We need your support to be able to finance this project. We have the team, the ideas, the creative minds and the drive! Now we need your support.

Join us and be part of Melpómene! By investing in this project you are contributing to:

¡Hay otras maneras de ayudarnos!

  • Comparte nuestra campaña en tus redes sociales con amigos y familiares.
  • Envía el link de la campaña especialmente a quien creas que pueda estar interesado en ayudar este tipo de proyectos.
  • Si no tienes tarjeta de crédito ¡no hay problema! Puedes donarnos dinero por otros medios. Contáctanos a lanuevaescena@gmail.com
  • ¿Tienes otra forma de ayudarnos? ¡Escríbenos a lanuevaescena@gmail.com, queremos escucharte!
  • Síguenos en las redes y mantente al tanto de nuestro proceso, ¡porque #LaÓperaEstáViva!

Even more ways to help!

  • Share our campaign on social media, with friends and family.
  • Show this link specially to anyone you think would want to help this kind of projects.
  • Have you come up with another way of contributing? Contact us at lanuevaescena@gmail.com, we want to hear your ideas!
  • Follow us on social media and keep up with our progress, because #TheOperaIsAlive!

Sobre nuestro equipo: 

More on our team:

F. Hoyos González – Compositor:

Inicia sus estudios musicales en el programa musical para niños de la Escuela Sinfónica de Cartagena y en la Escuela de Piano de Patricia Ojeda. En el año 2007 se condecora con el primer puesto del Premio Alberto Assa de la Fundación Pro-Cultura del Caribe. Se vincula al programa en Estudios Musicales de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana en el año 2009, con énfasis en Piano Clásico, para luego iniciar el programa de Composición. Finaliza sus estudios de composición bajo la tutela del maestro Guillermo Gaviria. También ha estudiado con maestros como Óscar Murcia, Carolina Noguera, Juan Pablo Carreño y Marco Suárez.

Sus obras se destacan por su interpretación en distintos escenarios del país, tales como Opúsculo a la Noche (2015), para mezzosoprano y piano; Opúsculo Caribeño (2015), para orquesta de cuerdas. Y su más reciente obra para orquesta, TempoCumbé (2016), estrenada por la Orquesta Filarmónica de Bogotá en el Teatro Mayor Julio Mario Santo Domingo bajo la dirección del maestro Conrad van Alphen. Actualmente se encuentra en la creación de su primera producción de ópera en español, Melpómene, del libretista y escritor venezolano George Galo y compuesta para la soprano Ana Mora.

Como compositor de música para cine se destacan Por Siempre Alicia, película de formato cortometraje nominada en el Los Angeles Cine Fest y en el Festival de Cine al Mar, y Videl, producción cinematográfica colombo estadounidense.

F. Hoyos González – Composer:

Starts his musical studies at Symphonic School of Cartagena and Patricia Ojeda’s Piano School. In 2007 wins the first price in the Alberto Assa contest from the Pro-Cultura Foundation of the Caribbean. In 2009 initiates Musical Studies program at Pontifical Javeriana University in Bogotá, Colombia. Studying classical piano and composition, finishes his undergraduate diploma under the direction of professor and composer Guillermo Gaviria. Has also studied with Colombian international composers like: Carolina Noguera Palau (Birmingham Conservatoire), Juan Pablo Carreño (CNSMDP) and Marco Suarez (CNSMDP).

His works stand out for their interpretation in different stages of the country, like Opúsculo a la Noche (2015), for mezzosoprano and piano; Opúsculo Caribeño (2015), for string orchestra; and his most recent work for orchestra, TempoCumbé (2016), interpreted by Bogota’s Philharmonic Orchestra under the direction of Conrad van Alphen. He is currently in the creation of his first opera production in Spanish, Melpómene, original libretto by Venezuelan writer George Galo and composed for the mezzosoprano Ana Mora.

Felipe has worked as a film composer in short films Por Siempre Alicia (For ever Alice), nominated at Los Angeles Cine Fest and Festival de Cine al Mar, and Videl, Colombo-American production.

G. Galo – Libretista:

Escritor caraqueño. Realizador audiovisual por la Escuela Nacional de Cine de Colombia (2016) con énfasis en documental de creación, ha realizado proyectos vinculados con el documental, el cine experimental y la video-instalación, ejerciendo asimismo como guionista para proyectos de ficción. Pianissimo Amabile, El sonar de los nombres, Les Apostrophes or The Fallen Goddesses (ganador de seis premios en el Festival de Imaginarios de las Artes, Caracas), y Nonna o el optimismo (su primer largometraje documental y proyecto de grado laureado), se cuentan entre sus piezas audiovisuales. Comienza a escribir a la edad de 14 años en revistas de opinión para más adelante iniciar su formación narrativa en diplomados de guión cinematográfico y de literatura grecolatina y japonesa. Obtiene su título de Bachiller mención Humanidades gracias a su tesis La apología del utopismo con la que realiza su primer gran acercamiento a la historia de las ideas de Occidente, en lo que luego enmarcará su obra narrativa. En 2015 publica su primer libro de relatos Ucronías. Ficciones filosóficas (Ed. Eclepsidra) ya presentado en Caracas, Bogotá y Madrid, y continúa escribiendo artículos para revistas y folletos literarios como Cinéfono o ForoLibertad, donde también se han publicado sus poemas. La ópera de cámara Melpómene está libremente basada en sus diarios inéditos Los cuadernos de Melpómene. Actualmente cursa un pregrado en Filosofía.

G. Galo – Librettist:

Venezuelan writer. Filmmaker from Colombia's National Film School (2016) with major in creative documentary, he has made projects in experimental film, video-installation and documentary, as well as a fiction scriptwriter. Pianissimo Amabile, El sonar de los nombres, Les Apostrophes or The Fallen Goddesses (awarded six prizes at the Festival de Imaginarios de las Artes, Caracas), and Nonna o el optimismo (his first feature documentary and awarded undergraduate degree project), stand out as audiovisual works. He started writing in opinion magazines when he was 14 years old, to then start his narrative formation with graduates in film script and greco-latin and japanese literature. Got his High School Diploma with the thesis project "The Utopianism´s Apology", with which he made his first important approach to the History of Western Thought, topic that became an important influence in his narrative work. In 2015 published "Uchronies. Philosophical fictions" (ed. Eclepsidra), his first tales book, presented in Caracas, Bogotá and Madrid. Galo continues writing articles for magazines and literary brochures like Cinéfono and ForoLibertad, where his poems have also been published. Melpómene, a chamber opera, is based on his unpublished diaries Los Cuadernos de Melpómene. Nowadays, Galo studies an undergraduate degree in Philosophy.

Ana Mora – Mezzosoprano, Melpómene.

A los 17 años inicia la carrera de Estudios Musicales en la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana en donde actualmente es estudiante de X semestre en el énfasis de canto lírico, trabajando con las maestras Carolina Plata y María Olga Piñeros.

En abril del año 2012 consigue su primera labor como solista al interpretar el Stabat Mater de G.B Pergolesi bajo la dirección del Maestro Alejandro Zuleta. Ese mismo año fue solista en el estreno de la obra “Lux Aeterna” de Felipe Hoyos, interpretada por el coro Nova Vox bajo la dirección de Leonardo Palacios, y de la Misa de Requiem en Re menor de W. A. Mozart bajo la batuta de James Allen Anderson.

A finales del año 2012 trabajó en la producción del musical “Sweeney Todd” de la compañía REC en el teatro Colsubsidio.

Fue solista en el oratorio “Judas Maccabeus” de G.F Händel, dirigido por Luis Guillermo Vicaria, y en Diciembre del 2013 es seleccionada por audición para interpretar “Gloria” de A. Vivaldi y “Weihnachtsoratorium” de J.S Bach bajo la dirección de Carolina Gamboa.

En marzo del año 2014 viaja a Filadelfia, donde es seleccionada entre cientos de cantantes de todo el mundo como uno de los finalistas de las audiciones de primavera 2014 en el Curtis Institute of Music.

Regresa a Bogotá donde interpreta la voz de Juana de arco en el oratorio “Voices of light” de Richard Einhorn dirigido por Guerassim Voronkov, y luego, las “Vesperae solennes de confessore” de W.A Mozart bajo la batuta de Jorge Alejandro Salazar.

Interpretó el papel de “Rosine” de la Opera “Signor Deluso” de Thomas Pasatieri en el marco del Festival Ópera al Parque 2014 organizado por la Orquesta Filarmónica de Bogotá, y el año 2015  inicia con la interpretación de la  “Missa in tempore belli” de Joseph Haydn al lado de la Orquesta Sinfónica Nacional dirigida por Tomasz Golka.

Recientemente interpretó el papel de Giovanna en la producción de “Rigoletto” del Teatro Mayor, dirigida por Patrick Fournillier y regido por Tatjana Gürbaca, y a mediados del 2015 regresa a Filadelfia, donde participa en el Summerfest, en el Curtis Institute of Music, trabajando con los maestros Mikael Eliasen, Lisa Keller, William Stone y Matthew Brower.

En febrero del año 2016 trabajó en la producción del Teatro Mayor de la ópera Salomé de Richard Strauss, y en marzo cantó el Alto solista de la Misa de Requiem en Re menor de W. A. Mozart con la Orquesta Filarmónica de Bogotá dirigida por el Maestro Patrick Fournillier. Asimismo, participó en el concierto “Narraciones coincidentes” dentro del ciclo de conciertos de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, en donde se estrenaron las obras “Aproximación a la patria” y “Opúsculo a la Noche” de los compositores colombianos Sergio Cote y Felipe Hoyos respectivamente, y se realizó el estreno en América de la ópera de cámara “Nadja’s song” de la compositora británica Lucy Armstrong. En abril hizo parte del ciclo de conciertos estudiantiles del Auditorio Fabio Lozano, y en junio participó en la serie de conciertos de Jóvenes Intérpretes de la biblioteca Luis Ángel Arango.

Ana Mora – Mezzo-soprano, Melpómene.

Venezuelan Mezzo-soprano currently finishing her bachelor degree at the Voice Department in the “Pontificia Universidad Javeriana” in Bogotá, Colombia under the supervision of Ph.D. Carolina Plata.

After migrating to Colombia due to political reasons, she has made a name for herself in oratorio repertoire, singing “Judas Maccabeus” by G.F Händel, conducted by Luis Guillermo Vicaria. In December 2013 she performs Antonio Vivaldi`s “Gloria” and “Weihnachtsoratorium” by J.S Bach under Carolina Gamboa’s baton, and in 2015 she sings the alto role of the “Missa in tempore belli” by Joseph Haydn conducted by Tomasz Golka.

In 2015 she played the role of Giovanna in Teatro Mayor’s production of Verdi’s Rigoletto, conducted by Patrick Fourniller and taken to the stage by Tatiana Gürbaca, and in July she traveled to Philadelphia, USA, where she participates in the Curtis Institute of Music Summerfest, working with Mikael Eliasen, Lisa Keller and William Stone.

In february 2016 Ana worked in Teatro Mayor’s production of the opera Salomé by Richard Strauss, and in March she sang the Requiem in D minor by W. A. Mozart with Bogotá’s Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Patrick Fournillier. Likewise, she participated in “Narraciones coincidentes” a concert at the Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, where the works Aproximación a la patria and Opúsculo a la Noche by colombian composers Sergio Cote y Felipe Hoyos were premiered, and the opera “Nadja's song” by british composer Lucy Armstrong was premiered in Latin America. In October 2016 she played the role of Hermia in Britten’s A Midsummer’s night dream.

Óscar Aquite – Productor General.

Músico productor de audio de la Universidad de los Andes. Ha sido fagotista, flautista y corista de diferentes agrupaciones como el Coro Uniandes (con el que ha realizado giras nacionales e internacionales), Coro de Cámara de la Universidad de los Andes, Ensamble de Experimentación Vocal de los Andes –EEVA- (con el que ha estrenado y reestrenado obras de compositores destacados nacionales e internacionales), Coro Lux Aeterna, el Coro Novavox y el Coro binacional Juvenil (América Cantat 2013). Formó parte del comité de la revista REC de Artes y Humanidades de Uniandes en representación de los estudiantes del departamento de Música. Se ha desempeñado como asistente de investigación en proyectos académicos interdisciplinarios como  “Las propiedades acústicas de las trompetas americanas de conchas de caracol fututo y waylla kepa” (Uniandes, 2010-2012). Ha trabajado para diferentes organizaciones que apoyan las artes y la cultura como Hay Festival (Cartagena de Indias) y Festival Mundial de Coros América Cantat (Bogotá, 2013). Actualmente hace parte del equipo que organiza la Temporada de Conciertos del Banco de la República de Colombia, y estudia una maestría en Estudios Interdisciplinarios de Desarrollo.

Óscar Aquite – Producer. 

Musician and audio producer of the University of the Andes in Bogotá, Colombia. He has been a bassoonist, flute player and chorus singer of different groups such as the Uniandes Choir, Chamber Choir of the University of the Andes, Experimentation Vocal Ensemble of the Andes (EEVA), Coro Lux Aeterna, the Novavox Choir, the Juvenile Youth Choir (América Cantat 2013) and the Juvenile Philharmonic Choir. He was part of the committee of the magazine REC of Arts and Humanities of University of the Andes representing the students of the Department of Music. He has worked as research assistant in interdisciplinary academic projects such as "The acoustic properties of the American trumpets of conch shells fututo and waylla kepa" (University of the Andes, 2010-2012). He has been part of different organizations that support the arts and culture, such as Hay Festival (Cartagena de Indias) and Cantabria World Choral Festival (Bogotá, 2013). He is currently part of the team that organizes the National Concert Season of the Bank of the Republic of Colombia, and studies for a Master's degree in Interdisciplinary  Studies in Development.

*AVISO IMPORTANTE: las boletas a entregar como recompensa están sometidas a disponibilidad del aforo. Esto será informado con antelación a la parte interesada. 

*IMPORTANT INFORMATION: the tickets to be handed as a reward are subject to availability. This will be informed in advance.​
story_txt:
We believe #TheOperaIsAlive! For us, making opera is a job for the present moment. That´s why La Nueva Escena (The New Stage), a team of young artists, has decided to bring an original production of this genre to the Latin American stages. Join us!Thanks for watching our video! Here you can learn more about this project and its creators!¡Gracias por ver nuestro video! Acá puedes leer un poco más sobre nuestro proyecto y sus creadores!¿Quiénes somos?La Nueva Escena es un colectivo conformado por jóvenes creadores que se han interesado por traer a la escena cultural nuevas obras escenográficas, haciendo un énfasis inicial en la producción de ópera inédita en castellano, proyectos que aún buscan tener cabida en las agendas culturales de Colombia. La Nueva Escena es, también, una plataforma de creación para todas las exploraciones que se propongan cercanas al mundo de los escenarios.Who are we? La Nueva Escena is a group made up of young artists who have decided to bring new stage works into the cultural scene. All of this, making an initial emphasis in the production of new operas in spanish, a field still unexplored in the cultural agenda of Colombia. La Nueva Escena is also a creative platform for all art forms that are related to the stage.¿Qué es Melpómene?El primer proyecto del colectivo, Melpómene, drama lírico en un acto, busca presentar una propuesta de ópera de cámara en español, escrita para una sola intérprete con trío de piano, clarinete y violoncello. Compuesta por F. Hoyos González con base en el libreto del autor G. Galo, el drama propuesto por los autores explora el mito trágico de Melpómene, Musa regente de la tragedia, en reinterpretación contemporánea para crear un puente entre la tradición clásica y el malestar actual en la cultura, de donde se vale para crear la estructura narrativa que no hace mano del tradicional monólogo para la ópera de cámara, sino que, manteniendo una sola intérprete en escena, logra forjar dos personajes en un solo cuerpo. Se manifiesta, pues, como corresponde al género, un profundo trabajo de colaboración entre la literatura y la música, todo a su vez  enmarcado en el montaje teatral de la obra.What is Melpómene?The first project of the group, Melpómene, lyric drama in one act, is a chamber opera in spanish, composed for a single performer accompanied by a trio of piano, clarinet and violoncello. Composed by F. Hoyos Gonzalez and based on the a script by G. Galo, the drama explores the tragical myth of Melpómene, reining Muse of tragedy. The opera is a contemporary interpretation of the myth, all in the effort of creating a bridge between tradition and the current problems in society. This metaphorical bridge is represented by the lack of the typical monologue, but instead by maintaining a single person on the stage and creating two characters in one body. In this way, and as is expected of the genre, there is a profound collaboration between literature, music and theatre.¿Cuál es la importancia de este proyecto?El teatro y la música, ámbitos muy fuerte en la industria cultural, no siempre da lugar a nuevas producciones de ópera joven. Este proyecto parece oportuno para abrir nuevos espacios para nuevos públicos donde continúe la exploración del canto, el texto y las artes escénicas, dándole esa mayor presencia que acaso amerite en los escenarios y espacios académicos de Colombia. No solo nos acercaremos a los espectadores, sino que nos importa crear un acceso a una nueva plataforma de creación que se propone estar abierta para aquellos artistas (estudiantes y profesionales) que quieran incursionar en la interdisciplinariedad de las áreas tan variadas que la ópera esencialmente reúne como la puesta en escena, la actuación, la dramaturgia y la poesía, la música y el canto.What is the importance of this project?Music and theatre, strong fields in cultural industry, are not often associated with productions of new opera. This project is the perfect opportunity to open new spaces to new audiences, where we can continue to explore on singing, text and theatre. Not only are we reaching out to spectators, but we are also making way towards a new creative platform which will be open to all artists interested in the areas that opera comprises, such as acting, poetry, music, singing and dramaturgy.¿Cuáles son nuestras metas y desafíos?
Llevar a buena terminación la producción Melpómene, estrenando la primera semana de agosto de 2017.
Presentar la obra en al menos tres escenarios del país, incluyendo espacios académicos.
Abrir foros de debate y socialización sobre los procesos que ameritan este tipo de producciones en la región.
Posicionar a La Nueva Escena en el panorama cultural del país como una plataforma de creación e interacción entre jóvenes creadores.
¡Que esta sea la fuente para otras y más ambiciosas producciones!
Which are our goals and challenges?
To complete the production of Melpómene, premiering the first week of August 2017.
To perform the opera in at least 3 stages in Colombia, including academic ones.
To encourage local debate about the process required to bring about this kind of productions.
To position La Nueva Escena in the cultural map of the country, as a platform of creation and interaction among young artists.
To make this the source for other, more ambitious projects!
¿Cómo puedes ayudarnos?Necesitamos tu apoyo para poder financiar este proyecto. ¡Tenemos el equipo, tenemos las ideas, las mentes creadoras y el ímpetu! Ahora necesitamos tu apoyo. ¡Ayúdanos y haz parte de Melpómene!Al invertir en el proyecto estarías contribuyendo en lo siguiente:How can you help?We need your support to be able to finance this project. We have the team, the ideas, the creative minds and the drive! Now we need your support.Join us and be part of Melpómene! By investing in this project you are contributing to:¡Hay otras maneras de ayudarnos!
Comparte nuestra campaña en tus redes sociales con amigos y familiares.
Envía el link de la campaña especialmente a quien creas que pueda estar interesado en ayudar este tipo de proyectos.
Si no tienes tarjeta de crédito ¡no hay problema! Puedes donarnos dinero por otros medios. Contáctanos a lanuevaescena@gmail.com
¿Tienes otra forma de ayudarnos? ¡Escríbenos a lanuevaescena@gmail.com, queremos escucharte!
Síguenos en las redes y mantente al tanto de nuestro proceso, ¡porque #LaÓperaEstáViva!
Even more ways to help!
Share our campaign on social media, with friends and family.
Show this link specially to anyone you think would want to help this kind of projects.
Have you come up with another way of contributing? Contact us at lanuevaescena@gmail.com, we want to hear your ideas!
Follow us on social media and keep up with our progress, because #TheOperaIsAlive!
Sobre nuestro equipo: More on our team:F. Hoyos González – Compositor:Inicia sus estudios musicales en el programa musical para niños de la Escuela Sinfónica de Cartagena y en la Escuela de Piano de Patricia Ojeda. En el año 2007 se condecora con el primer puesto del Premio Alberto Assa de la Fundación Pro-Cultura del Caribe. Se vincula al programa en Estudios Musicales de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana en el año 2009, con énfasis en Piano Clásico, para luego iniciar el programa de Composición. Finaliza sus estudios de composición bajo la tutela del maestro Guillermo Gaviria. También ha estudiado con maestros como Óscar Murcia, Carolina Noguera, Juan Pablo Carreño y Marco Suárez.Sus obras se destacan por su interpretación en distintos escenarios del país, tales como Opúsculo a la Noche (2015), para mezzosoprano y piano; Opúsculo Caribeño (2015), para orquesta de cuerdas. Y su más reciente obra para orquesta, TempoCumbé (2016), estrenada por la Orquesta Filarmónica de Bogotá en el Teatro Mayor Julio Mario Santo Domingo bajo la dirección del maestro Conrad van Alphen. Actualmente se encuentra en la creación de su primera producción de ópera en español, Melpómene, del libretista y escritor venezolano George Galo y compuesta para la soprano Ana Mora.Como compositor de música para cine se destacan Por Siempre Alicia, película de formato cortometraje nominada en el Los Angeles Cine Fest y en el Festival de Cine al Mar, y Videl, producción cinematográfica colombo estadounidense.F. Hoyos González – Composer:Starts his musical studies at Symphonic School of Cartagena and Patricia Ojeda’s Piano School. In 2007 wins the first price in the Alberto Assa contest from the Pro-Cultura Foundation of the Caribbean. In 2009 initiates Musical Studies program at Pontifical Javeriana University in Bogotá, Colombia. Studying classical piano and composition, finishes his undergraduate diploma under the direction of professor and composer Guillermo Gaviria. Has also studied with Colombian international composers like: Carolina Noguera Palau (Birmingham Conservatoire), Juan Pablo Carreño (CNSMDP) and Marco Suarez (CNSMDP).His works stand out for their interpretation in different stages of the country, like Opúsculo a la Noche (2015), for mezzosoprano and piano; Opúsculo Caribeño (2015), for string orchestra; and his most recent work for orchestra, TempoCumbé (2016), interpreted by Bogota’s Philharmonic Orchestra under the direction of Conrad van Alphen. He is currently in the creation of his first opera production in Spanish, Melpómene, original libretto by Venezuelan writer George Galo and composed for the mezzosoprano Ana Mora.Felipe has worked as a film composer in short films Por Siempre Alicia (For ever Alice), nominated at Los Angeles Cine Fest and Festival de Cine al Mar, and Videl, Colombo-American production.G. Galo – Libretista:Escritor caraqueño. Realizador audiovisual por la Escuela Nacional de Cine de Colombia (2016) con énfasis en documental de creación, ha realizado proyectos vinculados con el documental, el cine experimental y la video-instalación, ejerciendo asimismo como guionista para proyectos de ficción. Pianissimo Amabile, El sonar de los nombres, Les Apostrophes or The Fallen Goddesses (ganador de seis premios en el Festival de Imaginarios de las Artes, Caracas), y Nonna o el optimismo (su primer largometraje documental y proyecto de grado laureado), se cuentan entre sus piezas audiovisuales. Comienza a escribir a la edad de 14 años en revistas de opinión para más adelante iniciar su formación narrativa en diplomados de guión cinematográfico y de literatura grecolatina y japonesa. Obtiene su título de Bachiller mención Humanidades gracias a su tesis La apología del utopismo con la que realiza su primer gran acercamiento a la historia de las ideas de Occidente, en lo que luego enmarcará su obra narrativa. En 2015 publica su primer libro de relatos Ucronías. Ficciones filosóficas (Ed. Eclepsidra) ya presentado en Caracas, Bogotá y Madrid, y continúa escribiendo artículos para revistas y folletos literarios como Cinéfono o ForoLibertad, donde también se han publicado sus poemas. La ópera de cámara Melpómene está libremente basada en sus diarios inéditos Los cuadernos de Melpómene. Actualmente cursa un pregrado en Filosofía.G. Galo – Librettist:Venezuelan writer. Filmmaker from Colombia's National Film School (2016) with major in creative documentary, he has made projects in experimental film, video-installation and documentary, as well as a fiction scriptwriter. Pianissimo Amabile, El sonar de los nombres, Les Apostrophes or The Fallen Goddesses (awarded six prizes at the Festival de Imaginarios de las Artes, Caracas), and Nonna o el optimismo (his first feature documentary and awarded undergraduate degree project), stand out as audiovisual works. He started writing in opinion magazines when he was 14 years old, to then start his narrative formation with graduates in film script and greco-latin and japanese literature. Got his High School Diploma with the thesis project "The Utopianism´s Apology", with which he made his first important approach to the History of Western Thought, topic that became an important influence in his narrative work. In 2015 published "Uchronies. Philosophical fictions" (ed. Eclepsidra), his first tales book, presented in Caracas, Bogotá and Madrid. Galo continues writing articles for magazines and literary brochures like Cinéfono and ForoLibertad, where his poems have also been published. Melpómene, a chamber opera, is based on his unpublished diaries Los Cuadernos de Melpómene. Nowadays, Galo studies an undergraduate degree in Philosophy.Ana Mora – Mezzosoprano, Melpómene.A los 17 años inicia la carrera de Estudios Musicales en la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana en donde actualmente es estudiante de X semestre en el énfasis de canto lírico, trabajando con las maestras Carolina Plata y María Olga Piñeros.En abril del año 2012 consigue su primera labor como solista al interpretar el Stabat Mater de G.B Pergolesi bajo la dirección del Maestro Alejandro Zuleta. Ese mismo año fue solista en el estreno de la obra “Lux Aeterna” de Felipe Hoyos, interpretada por el coro Nova Vox bajo la dirección de Leonardo Palacios, y de la Misa de Requiem en Re menor de W. A. Mozart bajo la batuta de James Allen Anderson.A finales del año 2012 trabajó en la producción del musical “Sweeney Todd” de la compañía REC en el teatro Colsubsidio.Fue solista en el oratorio “Judas Maccabeus” de G.F Händel, dirigido por Luis Guillermo Vicaria, y en Diciembre del 2013 es seleccionada por audición para interpretar “Gloria” de A. Vivaldi y “Weihnachtsoratorium” de J.S Bach bajo la dirección de Carolina Gamboa.En marzo del año 2014 viaja a Filadelfia, donde es seleccionada entre cientos de cantantes de todo el mundo como uno de los finalistas de las audiciones de primavera 2014 en el Curtis Institute of Music.Regresa a Bogotá donde interpreta la voz de Juana de arco en el oratorio “Voices of light” de Richard Einhorn dirigido por Guerassim Voronkov, y luego, las “Vesperae solennes de confessore” de W.A Mozart bajo la batuta de Jorge Alejandro Salazar.Interpretó el papel de “Rosine” de la Opera “Signor Deluso” de Thomas Pasatieri en el marco del Festival Ópera al Parque 2014 organizado por la Orquesta Filarmónica de Bogotá, y el año 2015  inicia con la interpretación de la  “Missa in tempore belli” de Joseph Haydn al lado de la Orquesta Sinfónica Nacional dirigida por Tomasz Golka.Recientemente interpretó el papel de Giovanna en la producción de “Rigoletto” del Teatro Mayor, dirigida por Patrick Fournillier y regido por Tatjana Gürbaca, y a mediados del 2015 regresa a Filadelfia, donde participa en el Summerfest, en el Curtis Institute of Music, trabajando con los maestros Mikael Eliasen, Lisa Keller, William Stone y Matthew Brower.En febrero del año 2016 trabajó en la producción del Teatro Mayor de la ópera Salomé de Richard Strauss, y en marzo cantó el Alto solista de la Misa de Requiem en Re menor de W. story:
Trolley Dances Riverside is a production that offers choreographers a platform to create original, site-specific work along the local bus route. The dances take place in public spaces and bring attention to the special attributes of the city. An opportunity like this one is rare in Riverside in that it bridges community dancers from local colleges and dance studios and provides a professional performance opportunity. Trolley Dances Riverside is a production of Riverside City College Dance, P.L.A.C.E. Performance, and the Riverside Arts Council, in partnership with the Riverside Transit Agency. Trolley Dances is a trademarked event of Jean Isaacs San Diego Dance Theater and is celebrating 20 years in that city. This unique dance performance also happens in San Francisco. Although the topography, diversity, and culture of each city may differ, each location retains the original idea of creating site-specific work along the public transportation line and has attracted over 3000 patrons throughout the state each year. We are extremely excited to offer honorariums for dance artists involved in Trolley Dances Riverside. This year's talented line-up of choreographers includes Jay Carlon, Megan Fowler-Hurst, Primera Generación Dance Collective, Wade Madsen, and Julie Simon. Support the project and help us reach our goal! If you are unable to contribute at this time, you can help us out by spreading the word about the fundraiser. Hope to see you at the event on October 13th!

http://trolleydancesriverside.com/

 

Photo credits:

Intersect Dance Theatre on the steps of Riverside Metropolitan Museum. Photo by Michael J. Elderman.

Choreographer Tracy Tom-Hoon at dancer auditions 2016.

Trolley Dances Riverside is a production that offers choreographers a platform to create original, site-specific work along the local bus route. The dances take place in public spaces and bring attention to the special attributes of the city. An opportunity like this one is rare in Riverside in that it bridges community dancers from local colleges and dance studios and provides a professional performance opportunity. Trolley Dances Riverside is a production of Riverside City College Dance, P.L.A.C.E. Performance, and the Riverside Arts Council, in partnership with the Riverside Transit Agency. Trolley Dances is a trademarked event of Jean Isaacs San Diego Dance Theater and is celebrating 20 years in that city. This unique dance performance also happens in San Francisco. Although the topography, diversity, and culture of each city may differ, each location retains the original idea of creating site-specific work along the public transportation line and has attracted over 3000 patrons throughout the state each year. We are extremely excited to offer honorariums for dance artists involved in Trolley Dances Riverside. This year's talented line-up of choreographers includes Jay Carlon, Megan Fowler-Hurst, Primera Generación Dance Collective, Wade Madsen, and Julie Simon. Support the project and help us reach our goal! If you are unable to contribute at this time, you can help us out by spreading the word about the fundraiser. Hope to see you at the event on October 13th!
http://trolleydancesriverside.com/
 
Photo credits:
Intersect Dance Theatre on the steps of Riverside Metropolitan Museum. Photo by Michael J. Elderman.
Choreographer Tracy Tom-Hoon at dancer auditions 2016.

story:
This winter, Cold Basement gets hot. Very hot. 

Forget about the Polar Vortex. Join us for the Heat Wave.

Produced through the Steppenwolf Garage Rep this February, Heat Wave will mark the 20th anniversary of the Chicago heat wave of 1995, when temperatures soared to catastrophic levels and over 700 citizens died from lack of city response. Written by Steven Simoncic and directed by Rinska Carrasco-Prestinary, Heat Wave tells the story of those who were made invisible and the resilient Chicago community that suffered, yet carried on.

Help CBD fuel the fire of this powerful story!


True Story

In 1995, 739 people died in Chicago when they didn’t have to. They were the invisible ones – poor, elderly, minorities -- living by themselves in tenements and transient hotels. Their killer was just as invisible. For five days temperatures hovered above 100 degrees with heat indices as high as 120. As the city morgues overflowed, the effectiveness of the city’s emergency response system came into question and Mayor Daley’s team snapped into action. But instead of attacking the problem, they attacked the victims with a PR campaign that successfully absolved the city of any wrongdoing and blamed the dead and their families for the fatalities. 


How You Can Help

All funds from this campaign directly contribute to Heat Wave. 
Production costs include, but are not limited to:

  • Set construction, props, costumes
  • Rehearsal space and scripts
  • Designers, actors, director and playwright 

Your Impact

Your generous donations will keep Cold Basement hot!  Heat Wave is our largest, most diverse show to date, and a true Chicago-centric piece that rekindles events that should never be forgotten. We want to reveal these human stories to remind Chicagoans of their strengths and to remind city leaders of their essential responsibilities to citizens across all spectrums. Don't let them forget. Fuel the fire. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about CBD and Heat Wave:
"Like" us on Facebook
Follow us on Twitter: @coldbasement
Check out our website: www.coldbasement.org
Tell your friends and family!

But most of all:
Come see Heat Wave, produced through the Steppenwolf Garage Rep. Performances begin February 20th - Get tickets here!

Warm up with Cold Basement Dramatics this winter. Help the Heat Wave!

Cold Basement Dramatics is a federally recognized 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, and all donations are tax-deductible.

story:
Who Is Libra?

Libra Theater Company believes that all artists, in order to truly develop their craft, must maintain a balance between art and everyday responsibilities like jobs, family commitments, and education. Our mission is to create quality New York theater that honors and works with the time commitments of our artists.

What Has Libra Done?

  • The Entropy Songs: a musical by Jonathan Larson grant winner Joshua H. Cohen
  • Fleet Week and Other Reasons to Sail: a three-night concert of the songs of Unlock'd writers Sam Carner and Derek Gregor
  • Midsummer Musicals: a concert reading of short musicals from Sophia Chapadjiev, Joshua H. Cohen, Mat Eisenstein, Mark T. Evans, Allison Leyton-Brown, Sara Nicholson, and Sunny Dahlia Turner
  • About a dozen play readings, including A Midsummer Night's Dream, An Ideal Husband, Prelude to a Kiss, and Antigone

What's Coming Up?

After finishing up a great first year of programming, we've got some exciting plans, including a full production this spring, a new musical concert event, and another edition of Midsummer Musicals with a new group of up-and-coming composers and lyricists. We're also beginning a new play reading series: In the Balance.

What is In the Balance?

Now that we're in our second year, Libra's launching In the Balance, a new quarterly reading series. Each reading is a free event (complete with a pre-show reception with the cast) that gives our artists a chance to perform semi-staged readings of a variety of plays. Our 2011-12 season has a great line-up of shows:


  • To Gillian on Her 37th Birthday by Michael Brady (a heartwarming story of a man's grief and its effect on his family)
  • Parfumerie adapted by Edward P. Dowdall (the Christmastime story that inspired The Shop Around the Corner, She Loves Me, and You've Got Mail)
  • The Lucky One by A. A. Milne (a romping British comedy from the author of Winnie the Pooh)
  • Antony and Cleopatra by William Shakespeare (an intense drama about the doomed Egyptian queen and her Roman commander)

Why Support Libra, In the Balance, and the Rest of Our Work?

As you can see, we've got some ambitious plans for the coming year. But to achieve our goals and continue to program opportunities for our artists, we need your support. For example: In the Balance is a great, new reading series. But after space rental, scripts, refreshments, and licensing fees, each of these readings costs an average of $300 to put up. Below are just a few reasons to support Libra and our work:


  • See great theater (including In the Balance - a free program!)
  • Enjoy fun nights with homemade snacks and free wine
  • Ensure performance opportunities for at least 60 actors
  • Gather with old friends and meet new people
  • Network with other artists looking to create
  • Get involved with a new, ambitious company

This Winter, Help Make Theater Happen

At Libra, we believe in making theater happen for our artists. To do that, we work to create as many flexible performance opportunities as possible - from full production to our In the Balance series. But we need your help and support. With $100, $25, or even $5, you can make all the difference in making Libra's work possible. Thanks for your support!

story:
Bloody Bedlam. . .

Welcome to the Dunsinane Institute for the Criminally Insane where the creative team at Crooked Teeth Theatre have matched and overleaped Macbeth's vaulting ambition with an edgy, futuristic take on Shakespeare's text.

Our play begins as Macbeth is being readied for his execution, convicted of the murders of Duncan, Banquo and Macduff's family. The ghosts of Banquo and Lady Macbeth stand vigil over his deathbed as he hallucinates in his final moments, reliving his descent into madness, murder and mayhem.

Crooked Teeth Theatre would like to invite you to be a partner in our greatness. Even on a bare stage this play would be bloody brilliant: we have a passionate, dedicated and talented cast, an inspired, resourceful production design team and a BIG dream! 

We're pretty good at doing a lot with very little, but this version of Macbeth is something special and we'd love to do it justice.  We have a dream to breath fresh life into Shakespeare's texts, to clean away the cobwebs of time, reach into the hearts and souls of our audience and make them feel alive in a way that is like nothing else on earth. We'd love your help in making our dream reality.

Help us Fill the Gaps. . .

The concept artwork for the costumes and makeup is gorgeous! Right now we're having to scale down our dream to fit our budget but with the right resources we could take this from a really great show to one of the best, most haunting, raw and beautiful interpretations of William Shakespeare's Macbeth that you've ever seen. 

The producers have been putting  a lot of their personal savings into the everyday production costs of the show. We've already paid the venue fees, marketing expenses (production photography, posters, programs) and we've also received  some really generous in-kind donations (set, sound design, lighting design, props, videography and graphic design) but sometimes you just need cold hard cash. 

We're specifically raising money for:

  • Lighting equipment and rental of a smoke machine
  • Costume build 
  • Makeup (including prosthetics and contact lenses for the witches)

We don't need much, so anything small you can spare will make a big difference to us.  

We've included some of the ways we'd love to express our gratitude in the area on the right. If there's something specific that we could do to say thank you that would be more meaningful to you, or if you want to hear more about us, or if you'd like to work with us on future projects please contact us. We'd love to hear from you!

If you'd like to donate a different amount or after the campaign closes, we do have a donation button on www.crookedteeththeatre.com that isn't going anywhere. 

Please share our info on your social media and in person! Bring your friends to the show and come talk to us after, we'd love to meet you.

Any monies raised in excess of our goal will go towards offsetting the costs of the next show. We're working towards a sustainable business model that includes a performance arts school that feeds into the professional company so we'll be entirely self-sufficient, but we need a bit of help getting that going.

More about Crooked Teeth's Macbeth. . .

This is Crooked Teeth Theatre's third theatrical production, but the momentum that Macbeth is building has brought us up to the cusp of something really special.

Director's notes: 

This project began as a single image: Lady Macbeth obsessively scrubbing her hands with a wire scrubbing brush, making more blood with every desperate attempt to get clean. The futility and vulnerability of this cracking mind fuelled by this insatiable inner fire really spoke to me. She was so beautiful that I became a little obsessed and I thought: Macbeth is mad by the end of the play, so why can't Lady M and Banquo both be ghosts? Obsessions? The unrecognized beginning of his madness?

The idea kept tugging at me and as I grappled with my own inner demons, anxiety, depression and the occasionally brush with insanity, directing Macbeth became an inevitable step.

When I finally went back to the script I was worried I'd have to significantly change the text to fit this concept, but the more I read, the more it all made sense! 

Between mining the script for clues and my own  tortured experiences, it all just came together: Lady Macbeth and Banquo emerged as constructs that Macbeth's mind had created to help him deal with his fear, isolation and guilt. They keep on path in Act One and Two. It's only when he stops listening to their guidance that his world starts to fall apart. 

The witches have been really fun too, as orchestrators of the action, they appear as minor characters throughout the play, keeping an eye on things, providing a nudge here and there as necessary, and a few similar characters have merged together, gathering this whole new internal life. 

Aside from the Macbeth Triumvirate the biggest conceptual discovery was casting Malcolm and Donalbain as women. King Lear is another favourite of mine, so when I was casting and we had more talented women than female characters it seemed like such a neat idea to mirror Lear's daughters in Duncan's offspring, even if there are only two. But then I reread Act 4 Scene 3 and suddenly the relationship between Macduff and Malcolm is the perfect counterpoint to Macbeth and Lady Macbeth! There are so many parallels between these two strong couples, it has balanced the play in a really exciting new way.

I can't wait to share this world we've built together with an audience. It's dark and tortured and messy but in a way it feels really compassionate. We're all hurting. We do things we regret. Sometimes we can pull ourselves back form those choices and sometimes we can't. I hope this play really opens up compassion in people for others and for themselves as we all struggle against the madness lurking in our own souls."

story:
Success consists of getting up just one more time than you fall.
- Oliver Goldsmith

Greetings! We are Ahkai Franklin and Garrett “Spaghetti” Minniti, Co-Founders and Artistic Directors of The Breakthrough Outreach & Performance Not-For-Profit Corporation aka The Breakthrough Movement. We are back in our SECOND Indiegogo campaign, dedicated to completing the funding for The Breakthrough Movement in New York City.

Company members and apprentices, from 2 countries, 3 Canadian provinces, and 9 states, are currently in the Big Apple coming together for the first time as a full-fledged dance company to develop their repertoire. These dancers, carefully selected based on their talent and abilities as well as their own personal stories, all bring something that is unique to The Breakthrough. It is a group of dancers that we believe in and want to see break through their own barriers in order to succeed and grow in this industry, just as we have in our own careers.

We would like to take the moment to say that we are beyond grateful for having received the support that we did in our first campaign! Our funders' belief in our vision and dedication to this group of young and talented dancers has not gone unnoticed. We are filled with gratitude that our passion is being recognized as we navigate our way to breakthrough any and all obstacles we come across. That is where our campaign 2.0 comes in.

This new campaign was created in order to cover the bare minimum of our remaining expenses for the month of July, specifically:

  • rehearsal and performance spaces
  • teacher salaries
  • traveling and living expenses

We have gotten this far thanks to YOU, but now we need your help to reach our end goal, which is the opportunity for this group to debut our first production of original work on a New York City stage. Every tax-deductible donation of any amount will help us to achieve this goal.

The Breakthrough Movement

Breakthrough (noun): a sudden, dramatic and important discovery or development; an instance of achieving success in a particular sphere or activity. (synonyms) ADVANCE, development, step forward, success, improvement, discovery, innovation, revolution, progress, headway.

Movement (noun): a group of people working together to advance their shared political, social, or artistic ideas. (synonyms) MOTION, gesture, sign, signal, action, activity, transportation, shift, conveyance, transfer, campaign, drive, push, crusade, develop, change, trend, drift, swing, progress, ADVANCE.

The Breakthrough Outreach & Performance Not-for-Profit Corporation, aka The Breakthrough Movement, is an international dance and theatre company that addresses culturally relevant issues through original theatrical works, brings arts education to areas in need through outreach programs, and raises money and awareness for various causes and charities both locally and internationally. The Breakthrough Movement also promotes positive and healthy living that focuses on defining dreams and dedication to follow through towards fruition and achievement.

A brief history, current events, and moving forward...

In 2013, In It For Life co-founders Ahkai Franklin and Garrett “Spaghetti” Minniti created The Breakthrough Outreach & Performance Company, a company comprised of 7 dancers from across the United States and Canada. Dancers coming from very different backgrounds and experiences drawn together by their passion for dance, their commitment to their art form, and also their need to breakthrough the social, economic, and geographic barriers that place limits on outlets of opportunity.

In June of 2014, less than one year after it's inception, The Breakthrough Movement has become officially registered as a 501(c)3 Not-for-Profit organization in New York City! Our ranks have grown from 7 dancers to 20 company members and 10 apprentices, currently from 2 countries, 3 Canadian provinces, and 9 states.

Currently, in July of 2014, The Breakthrough Movement Company members and Apprentices have congregated in New York City with 3 goals in mind: to workshop our first original production, to film a documentary of the incredible and inspiring stories of our Company members and Apprentices, and to plan our first outreach & performance TOUR, working with and raising money for Habitat for Humanity in the New Orleans area to build homes for families STILL affected by Hurricane Katrina.

Background

In the summer of 2006, Ahkai and Garrett met dancing for Sybarite Artist Development Collective (SADC), and although we came from very different backgrounds, our common passion, energy, and commitment to our artform drew us together. Soon after, we fused our styles and experiences to create innovative works of theatre and dance in numerous venues in and around NYC. To date, we have produced over 30 events, workshops, intensives, festivals, choreography showcases, and original Off-Broadway productions, all of which have been focused around the idea of creating a community of like-minded artists by creating new connections and bridging the gap between passion and opportunity.

"Our initial intention when creating our first production was to create opportunity for ourselves, our friends, and our students. Making a career in this industry is just plain hard. After we got through the process, we realized that we produced something more than just a show. We had found our voice. We created a way of saying, ‘THIS is my dream, and I AM going after it,’ and we built the foundation of a community to help support achieving those dreams." - Garrett “Spaghetti” Minniti & Ahkai Franklin (2007)

Over the past seven years, we have come to realize how serious the need is for creating community, not only within our industry, but also in our families, our children and students, our local communities, and even in our international relations and world view. We have also discovered that our vision extends much further than just pushing the boundaries of our craft, and what we want to say with our art is more focused than simply preaching the message of defining what your ‘it’ is of being "in it for life." As Agnes de Mille said, “The truest expression of people is in its dance and in its music.” After seven years of creating and dancing together our "truest expression," like dance, is a movement. Something that we call The Breakthrough.

What We Need & What You Get

It's incredible and inspiring to us that in less than a year The Breakthrough Movement has more than tripled in size, going from seven to thirty company members and apprentices. But more importantly than the size of the army, is the conviction with which they fight. Twelve company members (not local to New York), five of them for the second time, have paid the cost of their flights in order to join The Movement. Working with a group of people who believe in our vision with such faith is exactly the motivation we need as directors and the very reason why The Breakthrough Movement will be known around the world!

We are campaigning for $8,750.00. This is the minimum that we require in order to secure all of the necessary elements for our current project. These funds will be used for:

  • Rehearsal and performance space for the remaining two weeks.
  • Salaries for the six dance instructors involved in our program.
  • Living and transportation expenses for our Company members.

*The Breakthrough Movement has been operating as a Not-for-Profit entity since September of 2013. We are waiting to receive our official 501(c)3 status from the IRS, but we have received our Tax ID Number and therefore will provide you with tax-deductible receipt for your donation.

In return for your donations we are offering social media shout outs, crazy donation dancing, awesome LIFE Gear, private dance instruction, Flash Mob-o-grams (see what we did there?), sponsorship packages, and exclusive meet and greets with the company. We will even create a piece of choreography inspired by YOU and YOUR story! PLEASE check out our FULL list of perks stage right.

The Impact

We can't change the world alone. Each donation to our campaign is an open declaration of joining The Movement!

This project aims to develop what we anticipate being one of the most talented and dedicated dance companies in the business, showcasing original work on a consistent basis, eventually performing our own production on a Broadway stage, and traveling to spread the message that created them - which is in big bold letters under our video. By the end of this month, The Breakthrough will have workshopped our greatest theatrical work, allowing us to move into the next stage of production.

The general public will not only receive an entertaining, feel-good experience, but they will also be inspired by the thought-provoking message that The Breakthrough will offer. The content that The Breakthrough presents will be artistically created in such a way as to question common social barriers that exist in our society. The goal for those who attend our performances and participate in our outreach programs and philanthropy is to achieve a level of social awareness and self-reflection that would motivate them to reach their full potential and, in turn, make them a source of inspiration within their own communities. #JoinTheMovement

Risks & Challenges

We understand the challenge of running a weeklong campaign for our dance company's current project. We, our dancers, and all of those involved have invested into this company's success and have used all available resources and finances. Our dancers have flown to New York City and put everything else on hold to be a part of this experience. We have also extended ourselves financially, physically, and emotionally in order to make this happen and get our dancers to where they are now. We see this as a high-risk, high-reward opportunity. As with anything in life, there are challenges, but this project is the beginning of a track that will eventually get our Breakthrough dancers traveling around the world and performing on a Broadway stage for our own, original show. This is the first step we need to take in order to progress and get closer to making our dream a reality.

Before You Go

We want to say THANK YOU for taking the time to learn about who we are and our campaign! If you are reading this, you either know one of us personally and/or professionally or have been asked to learn about us and our campaign through family, friends, and/or social media. Any and all donations are appreciated! Please also help our cause reach a wider audience by spreading the word!!

#JoinTheMovement
story_txt:
Success consists of getting up just one more time than you fall. - Oliver Goldsmith

Greetings!  We are Ahkai Franklin and Garrett “Spaghetti” Minniti, Co-Founders and Artistic Directors of The Breakthrough Outreach & Performance Not-For-Profit Corporation aka The Breakthrough Movement.  We are back in our SECOND Indiegogo campaign, dedicated to completing the funding for The Breakthrough Movement in New York City.
Company members and apprentices, from 2 countries, 3 Canadian provinces, and 9 states, are currently in the Big Apple coming together for the first time as a full-fledged dance company to develop their repertoire. These dancers, carefully selected based on their talent and abilities as well as their own personal stories, all bring something that is unique to The Breakthrough.  It is a group of dancers that we believe in and want to see break through their own barriers in order to succeed and grow in this industry, just as we have in our own careers.
We would like to take the moment to say that we are beyond grateful for having received the support that we did in our first campaign! Our funders' belief in our vision and dedication to this group of young and talented dancers has not gone unnoticed. We are filled with gratitude that our passion is being recognized as we navigate our way to breakthrough any and all obstacles we come across.  That is where our campaign 2.0 comes in.
This new campaign was created in order to cover the bare minimum of our remaining expenses for the month of July, specifically:

rehearsal and performance spaces
teacher salaries
traveling and living expenses
We have gotten this far thanks to YOU, but now we need your help to reach our end goal, which is the opportunity for this group to debut our first production of original work on a New York City stage. Every tax-deductible donation of any amount will help us to achieve this goal.
The Breakthrough MovementBreakthrough (noun): a sudden, dramatic and important discovery or development; an instance of achieving success in a particular sphere or activity. (synonyms) ADVANCE, development, step forward, success, improvement, discovery, innovation, revolution, progress, headway.Movement (noun): a group of people working together to advance their shared political, social, or artistic ideas. (synonyms) MOTION, gesture, sign, signal, action, activity, transportation, shift, conveyance, transfer, campaign, drive, push, crusade, develop, change, trend, drift, swing, progress, ADVANCE.The Breakthrough Outreach & Performance Not-for-Profit Corporation, aka The Breakthrough Movement, is an international dance and theatre company that addresses culturally relevant issues through original theatrical works, brings arts education to areas in need through outreach programs, and raises money and awareness for various causes and charities both locally and internationally. The Breakthrough Movement also promotes positive and healthy living that focuses on defining dreams and dedication to follow through towards fruition and achievement.A brief history, current events, and moving forward...In 2013, In It For Life co-founders Ahkai Franklin and Garrett “Spaghetti” Minniti created The Breakthrough Outreach & Performance Company, a company comprised of 7 dancers from across the United States and Canada. Dancers coming from very different backgrounds and experiences drawn together by their passion for dance, their commitment to their art form, and also their need to breakthrough the social, economic, and geographic barriers that place limits on outlets of opportunity.In June of 2014, less than one year after it's inception, The Breakthrough Movement has become officially registered as a 501(c)3 Not-for-Profit organization in New York City! Our ranks have grown from 7 dancers to 20 company members and 10 apprentices, currently from 2 countries, 3 Canadian provinces, and 9 states.
Currently, in July of 2014, The Breakthrough Movement Company members and Apprentices have congregated in New York City with 3 goals in mind: to workshop our first original production, to film a documentary of the incredible and inspiring stories of our Company members and Apprentices, and to plan our first outreach & performance TOUR, working with and raising money for Habitat for Humanity in the New Orleans area to build homes for families STILL affected by Hurricane Katrina.
Background
In the summer of 2006, Ahkai and Garrett met dancing for Sybarite Artist Development Collective (SADC), and although we came from very different backgrounds, our common passion, energy, and commitment to our artform drew us together.  Soon after, we fused our styles and experiences to create innovative works of theatre and dance in numerous venues in and around NYC.  To date, we have produced over 30 events, workshops, intensives, festivals, choreography showcases, and original Off-Broadway productions, all of which have been focused around the idea of creating a community of like-minded artists by creating new connections and bridging the gap between passion and opportunity."Our initial intention when creating our first production was to create opportunity for ourselves, our friends, and our students.  Making a career in this industry is just plain hard.  After we got through the process, we realized that we produced something more than just a show.  We had found our voice.  We created a way of saying, ‘THIS is my dream, and I AM going after it,’ and we built the foundation of a community to help support achieving those dreams." - Garrett “Spaghetti” Minniti & Ahkai Franklin (2007)
Over the past seven years, we have come to realize how serious the need is for creating community, not only within our industry, but also in our families, our children and students, our local communities, and even in our international relations and world view.  We have also discovered that our vision extends much further than just pushing the boundaries of our craft, and what we want to say with our art is more focused than simply preaching the message of defining what your ‘it’ is of being "in it for life."  As Agnes de Mille said, “The truest expression of people is in its dance and in its music.”  After seven years of creating and dancing together our "truest expression," like dance, is a movement.  Something that we call The Breakthrough.
What We Need & What You Get
It's incredible and inspiring to us that in less than a year The Breakthrough Movement has more than tripled in size, going from seven to thirty company members and apprentices.  But more importantly than the size of the army, is the conviction with which they fight.  Twelve company members (not local to New York), five of them for the second time, have paid the cost of their flights in order to join The Movement.  Working with a group of people who believe in our vision with such faith is exactly the motivation we need as directors and the very reason why The Breakthrough Movement will be known around the world!We are campaigning for $8,750.00. This is the minimum that we require in order to secure all of the necessary elements for our current project.  These funds will be used for:
Rehearsal and performance space for the remaining two weeks.
Salaries for the six dance instructors involved in our program.
Living and transportation expenses for our Company members.
*The Breakthrough Movement has been operating as a Not-for-Profit entity since September of 2013.  We are waiting to receive our official 501(c)3 status from the IRS, but we have received our Tax ID Number and therefore will provide you with  tax-deductible receipt for your donation.
In return for your donations we are offering social media shout outs, crazy donation dancing, awesome LIFE Gear, private dance instruction, Flash Mob-o-grams (see what we did there?), sponsorship packages, and exclusive meet and greets with the company.  We will even create a piece of choreography inspired by YOU and YOUR story!  PLEASE check out our FULL list of perks stage right.
The Impact
We can't change the world alone. Each donation to our campaign is an open declaration of joining The Movement!
This project aims to develop what we anticipate being one of the most talented and dedicated dance companies in the business, showcasing original work on a consistent basis, eventually performing our own production on a Broadway stage, and traveling to spread the message that created them - which is in big bold letters under our video. By the end of this month, The Breakthrough will have workshopped our greatest theatrical work, allowing us to move into the next stage of production.The general public will not only receive an entertaining, feel-good experience, but they will also be inspired by the thought-provoking message that The Breakthrough will offer.  The content that The Breakthrough presents will be artistically created in such a way as to question common social barriers that exist in our society.  The goal for those who attend our performances and participate in our outreach programs and philanthropy is to achieve a level of social awareness and self-reflection that would motivate them to reach their full potential and, in turn, make them a source of inspiration within their own communities. #JoinTheMovement
Risks & Challenges
We understand the challenge of running a weeklong campaign for our dance company's current project.  We, our dancers, and all of those involved have invested into this company's success and have used all available resources and finances. Our dancers have flown to New York City and put everything else on hold to be a part of this experience. We have also extended ourselves financially, physically, and emotionally in order to make this happen and get our dancers to where they are now. We see this as a high-risk, high-reward opportunity. As with anything in life, there are challenges, but this project is the beginning of a track that will eventually get our Breakthrough dancers traveling around the world and performing on a Broadway stage for our own, original show. This is the first step we need to take in order to progress and get closer to making our dream a reality.
Before You Go
We want to say THANK YOU for taking the time to learn about who we are and our campaign!  If you are reading this, you either know one of us personally and/or professionally or have been asked to learn about us and our campaign through family, friends, and/or social media. Any and all donations are appreciated!  Please also help our cause reach a wider audience by spreading the word!!#JoinTheMovement

story:
Now Harlem... OR GENTRIFY THIS "The Play"

When Rita, a young white poet, moves to a gentrifying uptown block, her black neighbor Joanne, who often goes by the name "Harlem" exclaims, "Your being here is like another Applebee's we don't need." In a slam poetry type of showdown, Harlem is forced to choose between the cause she believes in and an answered prayer. Written for a society masked by centuries of pain, Now Harlem... OR GENTRIFY THIS! 

The Story 

Performer and playwright Latonia Phipps, derived inspiration for this project after moving to Harlem. In relocating, Phipps noticed that the Harlem of today was not the same beloved Harlem she grew up with. This left her to wonder, "What happened to the Harlem I read about in my history books?" Her experiences and questions became Now Harlem... OR GENTRIFY THIS! This production first premiered on July 10th, 2104 at University Settlement after Phipps was offered the opportunity to be apart of an Artist in Residence program. This piece had such a great impact on the L.E.S community Phipps decided to bring this show back to where it originated... HARLEM. 

WHAT WE NEED

To cover production fees as well as stationary costs for press packages presented to interested theaters companies.

  • Musicians (2)               $680
  • Light/media                $700
  • Actors                           $825

50 for 50 (Harlem Based Organizations)

Set up to bridge the gap between local organizations and the Harlem community. We need 50 Harlem based companies to make a $50 tax-deductible donation to help sponsor this project. In exchange we will feature your logo and company name on all of our social media outlets as well as a mention in the program for our next show.  


The Impact

This production experienced three nights of successful talk backs and a packed audience which included Harlem and L.E.S residence, local artist, housing representatives and community board members. What we learned....

  • Gentrification has happened and is happening.
  • People can empower themselves by being apart of their community boards.
  • Artist have a huge impact on this change and can help by using their gifts to keep this conversation going.

No Money... We still need YOU.

  • Share this link on your social media outlets. Help bring this play to Harlem.
  • Every little bit helps.

story:
My name is Tania, and I've been a professional performance artist since elementary school.  Singing was my first love, until I performed for Debbie Allen in high school, and she gave me my first job as dance teacher during rehearsal for her production. I've been a featured dancer for numerous dance companies and have choreographed for shows,artists and dance studios. I also began producing music in 2006 while in an electronica/industrial duo called Pavmire. With this experience and plenty of ideas I've  planned throughout the years, I'm finally starting my cabaret troupe named VaudeVixens- and with my own money I've already made it happened. 

  So far, i have three dancers and singers, we've already started rehearsal at a studio I've reserved for the month and i have costumes already being  made. I got the venues alerted and for my promo campaign, i have hired a photographer/ videographer. With the funding I'll be receiving here, we'll be paying for stage equipment (mics,headsets, speakers/ monitors, lights,etc), more studio time (music and dance), live band, more costumes, makeup artists, and definitely for featured artists flying in to perform in our shows . This will be started in Atlanta, where more diversity is needed, but I plan to take this troupe on tour when the ball gets rolling . I have resources for where and who we work with, and my creativity and hardwork has taken my former clients to higher places. Now I'm using my knowledge and drive for my own company.

story:
You're invited!

You're invited! It's Helge's 60th birthday and we would love for you to join our festive table for lobster soup, wine from the cellar and dangerously candid guests.

Director Anouk Kemp is very intrigued by the extremes of human behavior. Families, like any community or society, are often built on lies, secrets and half-truths. These falsehoods, nestled in the blueprint of the group, are reflected in the face of the family or culture --it is a mask of pretense that is passed on from generation to generation. And the behavior of the group living under such a pact of silence reveals the paradox between a tradition of censorship and a great need to know what is being hidden.
 FESTEN shines a light on the tremendous strength and fearlessness demonstrated by individuals in overcoming this code of silence, foregrounding the beauty and the courage necessary to unearth truth in our lives, both personally and in our cultures. 


What We Need

Due to the modesty of our budget, even the smallest donation will go a long way in launching our production.  Your generosity will enable us to build our set, costume our cast, procure our props, as well as offer our actors and designers a stipend for their work.  What could be better than making sure artists get paid?!

- Set

- Costumes

- Props

- Actor & Designer stipends

 

Who's Who

FESTEN will be brought to life  by the collaborative efforts of our creative team, including:

  • Lighting Designer Mike McGee
  • Set Designer Derek Miller

And our incredible cast:

Alan Altschuler*, Lauren Cipoletti*, Steve Fogelman*, Josh Frank*, Nico Kiefer, Sophie Labelle, Gareth Lawson, Deborah Offner*, Seth Reich*, Tyler Reilly, Peter Romano, Vanessa Vaché & Matthew Whitfield
*Denotes member of AEA

story:
The play.

 

The River Lady by David Widdicombe will be produced this May 2011, by the co-operative The Lonesome Crowded West, at Theatre Passe Muraille in Toronto. We are a group of artists who have come together to put on this amazing piece of Canadian theatre. 

 

The River Lady is a play that unites two people who exist on the fringes of society. A dishwasher, who feels his life is over, and a drifter with a dangerous proposition, come together in this darkly funny and brutally honest play. We are so excited to showcase these artists, and to bring this remarkable play to the stage.

 

But we need your help.

 

Every time a show is produced, it is a small miracle. The costs involved including the venue, rehearsal space, set, props, costumes, advertising materials, and programs can be overwhelming to say the least. As a co-op we’ve put up our own money to get this show off the ground, but now our pockets are bare and we look to you for help. 

 

We believe in this show. We believe in the power of theatre to challenge an audience, to make them laugh, cry, or simply experience something that is unique and powerful. Every penny we raise will go toward funding this production and making it as good as we believe it can be.

 

Every dollar helps. Believe me. Anything you can spare, be it $5, $15, $50 and beyond, will be so appreciated. Every person who donates will receive a special mention in our program (as well as our undying gratitude!). Help support Canadian theatre. You’ll be glad you did!

 

Let the word out!

 

Friends, acquaintances, people on the subway…let them know about us. Help spread the word to other theatre lovers in the city. Any donation is welcome, and needed. Feel free to share this on facebook, twitter, and any other social media site you can think of! 

 

Thank you so much for your support!

 

Details:

The River Lady

by David Widdicombe

 

Directed by Matthew Gorman

Featuring Arlin Dixon and Daniel Chapman-Smith

Designed by Travis Hatt

Sound/Asst. Direction by Aynsley Moorhouse

 

May 4 - 14, 2011

Wed to Sat 7:30pm, Sat 2pm

Theatre Passe Muraille Backspace, 16 Ryerson Ave, Toronto

All tickets $15

Box Office - 416-504-7529

or

www.artsboxoffice.ca

 

More info at www.lonesometheatre.wordpress.com
