story:
Watch the #buGIVEBACK Concert HERE!

Live from NYC, in real time!
7:30pm EST • Monday November 3, 2014


Once a year, Broadway Unlocked throws the party to end all parties - the #buGIVEBACK concert. It's Broadway's first global Google Hangout and All Star Benefit Concert - which means no matter who you are or where you live, you can be a part of Broadway during the show.

But, what does all that really mean, exactly?

First: It means we're putting on a Broadway concert, live from New York with these amazing performers and writers:


Second: We livestream it through YouTube, as a giant Google Hangout - which means, if you're watching, you'll see something like this: 


Third: We do fun things like have real time Q&A's, play games and feature fans from around the world through the Hangout. Also, there's belting. Lots of belting.

And, this one's a benefit concert which means the proceeds are donated to an incredible organization that we love - called the Crime Victims Treatment Center.

This year's concert is going to be out of this world - with performances from Kirstin Maldonado from Pentatonix, Tituss Burgess, Kate Wetherhead, Keala Settle, Barrett Wilbert Weed, Corey Mach, Christopher Rice, Kait Kerrigan & Brian Lowdermilk, Nathan Tysen & Chris Miller, Joey Contreras, Adam Gwon, Georgia Stitt, Bobby Cronin and 5J Barrow (featuring Jason Hite, Eryn Murman & Eric Namaky)

You're probably so excited, you've already contributed by now, but in case you need further convincing:

IndieGoGo is the only place where you can get a seat on the GOOGLE HANGOUT and win opportunities to talk to your favorite performers and writers. Check out our perks!


E x p l o r e


If you read nothing else, please read this!!

* plus *
Who we are • We Need You

You Make a Difference • Ways You Can Help
In the News



Who are we?

We are theatre geeks. Technology nerds. We are actors, musicians, designers, writers, photographers, lovers of the arts. And people who are passionate about forming a global theatre community.

We put our heads together, met with our friends at Google, got hopped up on sugar (thanks to their delicious interoffice snack bar) and came up with the idea for an All Star Benefit Concert & Hangout that would bring together theatre lovers from around the world for a livestreamed, interactive Hangout with Broadway.

And, because this concert is all about community, we decided to use the opportunity to give back to our community. The proceeds of the Give Back Concert benefit the Crime Victims Treatment Center.



Why it Matters

Approximately 1 out of every 6 people are victims of violent crime.

That's a crazy number. Think about your Facebook page - if you're like most people, you have about 300 friends. That means at least 50 people you love are likely to have experienced violent crime and needed help last year.

The CVTC has been turning terrible events into incredible stories of hope and survival for almost 40 years. In New York, they offer FREE trauma-focused therapy, support and services to survivors. And for those of you in other cities, it's pretty likely that the center in your town was modeled, in some way, after this groundbreaking organization. They continue to go out into other communities to help improve the way we support survivors of violent crime.

Through this concert, we have raised almost $90,000 for the CVTC over the past three years. We have the chance to blow this amount out of the water with the #buGIVEBACK concert this year.

And that's good, because at the end of July, CVTC was notified that its public funding would be cut by 46% beginning October 1, 2014.  This news was sudden and completely unexpected.  If CVTC is unable to find these funds elsewhere it will mean the collapse of New York State’s leading victim services program.

This has always been an important event for the CVTC - but this year, things got really real. And it's up to us to step up to the plate.


We Need You

We took a look at the budget from last year and determined that we need $10,000 to cover the cost of the Greene Space and incidental costs- so that everything else we raise goes straight to the CVTC. Totally doable, right? In fact, that's only 400 people donating the minimum amount to get a seat on the Hangout.

Pshaw.

We can do better than that. Plus, anything we raise beyond the cost of the concert will go straight to the Crime Victims Treatment Center. So, even though we set our goal at $10,000, we want to raise $25,000. Or $50,000. Or a BAJILLION dollars. And before you go telling us there's no such thing as a Bajillion, we will kindly remind you that most of us have a BFA in Musical Theatre and haven't had a math class for a loooong time. So, we're feeling confident that a BAJILLION is possible.

It's a pretty cool idea -  we can create a really exciting event for ourselves to enjoy AND make the world a better place. Nice.


You Make a Difference

The #buGIVEBACK Concert is the only source of non-restricted funding for the CVTC. So in addition to saving them from the funding crisis and helping keep one of the most important survivor services programs from going under (oh, just that), we'll also be providing money that can be used to do things like:

  • Continue to fund the CVTC Volunteer Rape Crisis and Domestic Violence Emergency Room Advocate Program, making sure survivors of sexual assault and domestic violence receive compassionate and knowledgeable care and support in the ER

  • Provide integral non-restricted emergency funds to survivors. Last year’s funds helped purchase furniture for a woman and her two toddlers who had escaped a life-threatening partner and found a safe apartment of their own, clothing for rape survivors whose clothing must be kept for evidence, emergency transportation for people fleeing abusive partners, and many other necessary things to which survivors normally have limited or no access

As we mentioned before, we have three successful years of concerts under our belt, with almost $90,000 raised for the CVTC. That's not bragging, that's just making sure that you know the money goes where we say it's going, and that you can be sure your contribution will make a difference.



    Other Ways You Can Help

    Broadway Unlocked is all about community, and the #buGIVEBACK concert is no different. It's about getting the word out, joining together and making this thing happen. There are lots of ways to contribute aside from donating -so, here's a few ideas:

    follow us @bwyUNLOCKED on twitter, and retweet the things you like .

    subscribe to us on YouTube and share your favorite video

    like us on Facebook and join in the conversation.

    Jump in and contribute ideas to our Instagram, Tumblr and Spotify accounts

    or

    really anything clever you can think of. Let us know what you come up with at broadwayunlocked(at)gmail.com.

    Most importantly: Use IndieGoGo's share tools to spread the word about the campaign. We can save the CVTC -

    and we'll do it together.



    Check out what people are saying about the #buGIVEBACK Concert

    2014

    Theatremania: Keala Settle and Titus Burgess join next Monday's Broadway Unlocked Concert
    BroadwayWorld: Kate Wetherhead, Barrett Wilbert Weed & More set for Broadway Unlocked Concert

    2013

    Lifestyle & Charity Magazine: The Party List: Top Charity Events for April
    NYC ABC 7: Crime Victims Treatment Center of New York City
    Playbill: Broadway Benefit Concert to Feature Andrew Keenan-Bolger
    Theatremania: Broadway Stars Will UNLOCK Their Performances on the WWW
    BroadwayWorld: STAGE TUBE: Jeremy Jordan Sings 'The Wheel' from Tuck Everlasting
story_txt:
Watch the #buGIVEBACK Concert HERE!
Live from NYC, in real time!7:30pm EST • Monday November 3, 2014

Once a year, Broadway Unlocked throws the party to end all parties - the #buGIVEBACK concert. It's Broadway's first global Google Hangout and All Star Benefit Concert - which means no matter who you are or where you live, you can be a part of Broadway during the show. 

But, what does all that really mean, exactly? 
First: It means we're putting on a Broadway concert, 
live from New York with these amazing performers and writers:





Second: We livestream it through YouTube, as a giant 
Google Hangout - which means, if you're watching, you'll see something like this: 


Third: We do fun things like have real time Q&A's, play games and feature 
fans from around the world through the Hangout. Also, there's belting. Lots of belting. And, this one's a benefit concert which means the proceeds are donated 
to an incredible organization that we love - called the Crime Victims 
Treatment Center.This year's concert is going to be out of this world - with performances from Kirstin Maldonado from Pentatonix, Tituss Burgess, Kate Wetherhead, Keala Settle, Barrett Wilbert Weed, Corey Mach, Christopher Rice, Kait Kerrigan & Brian Lowdermilk, Nathan Tysen & Chris Miller, Joey Contreras, Adam Gwon, Georgia Stitt, Bobby Cronin and 5J Barrow (featuring Jason Hite, Eryn Murman & Eric Namaky)You're probably so excited, you've already contributed by now, but in case you need further convincing:








IndieGoGo is the only place where you can get a seat on the GOOGLE HANGOUT and win opportunities to talk to your favorite performers and writers. Check out our perks!



 

E x p l o r e
If you read nothing else, please read this!!* plus *Who we are • We Need YouYou Make a Difference • Ways You Can HelpIn the News

 



Who are we?

We are theatre geeks. Technology nerds. We are actors, musicians, designers, writers, photographers, lovers of the arts. And people who are passionate about forming a global theatre community. 
We put our heads together, met with our friends at Google, got hopped up on sugar (thanks to their delicious interoffice snack bar) and came up with the idea for an All Star Benefit Concert & Hangout that would bring together theatre lovers from around the world for a livestreamed, interactive Hangout with Broadway.
And, because this concert is all about community, we decided to use the opportunity to give back to our community. The proceeds of the Give Back Concert benefit the Crime Victims Treatment Center.



Why it Matters


Approximately 1 out of every 6 people are victims of violent crime. 
That's a crazy number. Think about your Facebook page - if you're like most people, you have about 300 friends. That means at least 50 
people you love are likely to have experienced violent crime and needed help last year.

The CVTC has been turning terrible events into incredible stories of 
hope and survival for almost 40 years. In New York, they offer FREE 
trauma-focused therapy, support and services to survivors. And for those of you in 
other cities, it's pretty likely that the center in your town was 
modeled, in some way, after this groundbreaking organization. They 
continue to go out into other communities to help improve the way we 
support survivors of violent crime.

Through this concert, we have raised almost $90,000 for the CVTC over the past three years. We have the chance to blow this amount out of the water with the #buGIVEBACK concert this year. 
And that's good, because at
the end of July, CVTC was notified that its public funding would be cut by 46%
beginning October 1, 2014.  This news was sudden and completely unexpected.  If CVTC is unable
to find these funds elsewhere it will mean the collapse of New York State’s
leading victim services program. 
This has always been an important event for the CVTC - but this year, things got really real. And it's up to us to step up to the plate.

We Need YouWe took a look at the budget from last year and determined that we need $10,000 to cover the cost of the Greene Space and incidental 
costs- so that everything else we raise goes straight to the CVTC. Totally doable, right? In fact, that's only 400 people donating the minimum amount to get a seat on the Hangout. Pshaw.We can do better than that. Plus, anything we raise beyond the cost of the concert will go 
straight to the Crime Victims Treatment Center. So, even though we set our goal at $10,000, we want to raise $25,000. Or $50,000. Or a BAJILLION dollars. And before you go telling us there's no such thing as a Bajillion, we will kindly remind you that most of us have a BFA in Musical Theatre and haven't had a math class for a loooong time. So, we're feeling confident that a BAJILLION is possible. It's a pretty cool idea 
-  we can create a really exciting event for ourselves to enjoy AND make
 the world a better place. Nice. 


You Make a Difference
The #buGIVEBACK Concert is the only source of non-restricted funding for the CVTC. So in addition to saving them from the funding crisis and helping keep one of the most important survivor services programs from going under (oh, just that), we'll also be providing money that can be used to do things like:



Continue to fund the CVTC
Volunteer Rape Crisis and Domestic Violence Emergency Room Advocate Program,
making sure survivors of sexual assault and domestic violence receive
compassionate and knowledgeable care and support in the ER



Provide integral
non-restricted emergency funds to survivors. Last year’s funds helped purchase
furniture for a woman and her two toddlers who had escaped a life-threatening
partner and found a safe apartment of their own, clothing for rape survivors
whose clothing must be kept for evidence, emergency transportation for people
fleeing abusive partners, and many other necessary things to which survivors
normally have limited or no access
As we mentioned before, we have three successful years of concerts under our belt, with almost $90,000 raised for the CVTC. That's not bragging, that's just making sure that you know the money goes where we say it's going, and that you can be sure your contribution will make a difference. 



Other Ways You Can Help

Broadway Unlocked is all about community, and the #buGIVEBACK concert is no different. It's about getting the 
word out, joining together and making this thing happen. There are lots of
 ways to contribute aside from donating -so, here's a few ideas:
follow us @bwyUNLOCKED on twitter, and retweet the things you like . 
subscribe to us on YouTube and share your favorite video
like us on Facebook and join in the conversation.
Jump in and contribute ideas to our Instagram, Tumblr and Spotify accounts
or
really anything clever you can think of. Let us know what you come up with at broadwayunlocked(at)gmail.com.
Most importantly: Use IndieGoGo's share tools to spread the word 
about the campaign. We can save the CVTC - 
and we'll do it together.



Check out what people are saying about the #buGIVEBACK Concert
2014
Theatremania: Keala Settle and Titus Burgess join next Monday's Broadway Unlocked ConcertBroadwayWorld: Kate Wetherhead, Barrett Wilbert Weed & More set for Broadway Unlocked Concert 

2013

story:
Short Summary

The League of Extraordinary Thespians proudly presents The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, The Musical. 100% of our show's proceeds will benefit Alex's Lemonade Stand Foundation (ALSF)to combat pediatric cancer. The Legend of Zelda and all characters therein are the solo property of Nintendo. Our show is simply a nonprofit homage to a beloved franchise that's free to all who donate to our ALSF fundraiser.
 
Alex's Lemonade Stand Foundation is a great foundation that was created by a young girl who was diagnosed with cancer. She spent her last days dedicated to combating this disease for children like herself by running local lemonade stands to fund research. Alex is no longer with us, but her dream lives on through inspiring folk like you.

What We Need & What You Get

As in any theatre show we need to raise money for sets, costumes, props and advertising (posters, flyers, playbills).

With your donation, you get to help us put on an event that can change not only the lives of those involved in a positive way.

The Impact

  • Bringing back the need to do something good in the world without any compensation to both young and old.  Working as a team for a common goal.
  • We successfully had a previous show, Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog: Live on Stage raised $2,500.00 for the American Red Cross, for local tornado relief victims in 2011.
  • http://www.alexslemonade.org/mypage/93462

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our story, get involved in your community.  One person CAN make a difference!

story:
Our Story

In our PAYO Culture Night, it revolves around a dysfunctional family. we will address problems such as: the lack of conversation in a family household, family relationships,and dealing with biracial identities.

                       

                               What We Need 

This production alone costs approxtimately $5,000+.

The theater (Ruth Chapman Theatre) at which we are performing costs: ~ $3,000.

Being a major theatrical play that highlights the Filipino American experience with traditional cultural dances, we need your help to make sure this play happens.

Costumes:  for cultural dancers/performers =$300

Prop Design: an actual set for actors/actresses to maneuver around and utilize = $100

Program: for itinerary and list of student participants = $400

Aministrative support: for food,snacks, and drinks to keep us going during our practices = $75

                                         What YOU Get

With the funds you raised you will be recognized through our program for your generosity.

           

                          Other Ways You Can Help PAYO

Even if some of you are unable to contribute fiscally, please help PAYO promote our PAYO Cultural Night on the web! And if you live in San Diego, spread the word around town! Help us light up the world with our flier (coming soon*).

story:
QUAKE: A Love Story

We were accepted to the New York International Fringe Festival!!!!!

It's Aug. 9-25, 2013, and we need your help getting there from Orlando, FL. We're gonna kick some Big Apple butt, but we can't do it alone!

About QUAKE

Here’s the SparkNotes version of our play!

Joe and Hannah have been married for a while - married just out of high school - and they can't seem to make it work.

With no clear answer, they decide to try and go their separate ways.

While splitting up their belongings in a utility closet full of junk, Joe and Hannah find themselves face to face with fate when an earthquake hits, trapping them inside.  Over the following days, without food, water, or a bathroom ... Joe and Hannah panic, fight, play games, sing songs and do whatever they have to in order to survive the present, their past, and each other.

Taking place entirely within the confines of a utility closet, this two-person tour-de-force is a must-see at this year's Fringe. Full of music, physical comedy, and high drama, QUAKE is a production you won't want to miss.

Premiering at the Humboldt County Acata Theater in 2010, QUAKE went on to sweep the stages of the Minnesota, San Francisco, and Berkshire Fringe Festivals. These initial productions were performed by the playwright, Tyler Olsen, and Zuzka Sabata. After that, Justin Baldwin and Lara Miller obtained the rights and had a successful run at the Cincinnati Fringe Festival in 2012, receiving three Cincinnati/Dayton, OH Broadway World Award nominations (including Best Play and Acting nominations for both Justin and Lara).

Here's what some writerly people have said about QUAKE so far:

"QUAKE is well-done: a bittersweet story about realizing very important things at the worst possible moment, but also, before it’s too late. And in a very small space."
- Harper Lee, CityBeat

"… a funny, poetic, poignant, and visceral experience."
- Michael Fields, Dell'Arte International

"astonishing and heartening ..."
- William Kowinski, Eureka Times-Standard

"A gem!"
- David Ferney, Arcata Playhouse

Now we need you to help Justin, Kelly, and Trevin take this play to the next level!!!

WHO's WHO??

A.R.T. Artistic Director: Justin Baldwin

Producers: Justin Baldwin & Emma Marks

Director: Trevin Cooper

Stage Manager: Angel Emerson

Cast: Justin Baldwin & Kelly Kilgore

Lighting: James Lees

Graphic Design: Lawton Lovely

Why We Need Your Help!

We love this play. After having it passed to us from its creators, we knew this was a story that needed to be told. We think it’s a perfect fringe festival show: honest, intimate, and funny.

We submitted our proposal to the New York International Fringe Festival and we've been accepted! We are now in the process of putting together the next step of the QUAKE Tour, and we need your help in making it to NYC.

Your contribution to our campaign will allow us to take our production to New York. After having played successfully in Arcata, San Francisco, Minnesota, and most recently in Cincinnati, the next step is the Big Apple.

We need your generosity so that our production can afford the following items:

  • NYC Fringe Registration Fee - (Expensive!!!)
  • Set - The play is set in a closet, so the required set is pretty minimal, but we need pieces capable of being broken down into small enough bits to travel to NYC and being stored in a very small section of the theatre.
  • Props - Some of our props can be found in our own closets; but we need a dozen or so props that require purchase as they will be destroyed or consumed during the show! So we don't want to borrow your stuff ... cause you won't get it back!
  • Marketing - We're putting this bad boy up in NYC, so we need as much marketing material as we can get our hands on! A producer in NYC once told me that if you're doing a show up there you need to spend half your budget on marketing ... We're not going to use half, but we need to be able to get the word out! And that's going to cost us some pretty serious dough.
  • Travel - Your contribution will also literally help us get to NYC. We're going to be hauling a set, actors, lights, props, and a whole lot of awesomeness to New York, and your donation will help us afford gas, trailer, parking, and travel expenses.
  • Anything Left Over - Ha! As you know, there are always expenses that come up unexpectedly. if we are able to fully fund our production and have any kind of money left over from our fundraising, the remaining funds will be spent on last ditch marketing efforts such as extra flyers and posters, venue tip for the amazing theatre techs who help us in our venue in NYC, etc.

What Do You Get in Return for Your Awesomeness?!

We're going to send you something to remember our production and how valuable your contribution was to us achieving our goal!

Rehearsal photos, flyers autographed by the actors, posters autographed by the entire artistic team, photos of the production in NYC, and tickets to the show -- we've got plenty of snail-mail-worthy perks!

Thank You!!!

We are soooooo super excited to take this beautiful play to its next incarnation in New York City. Please consider helping us out, whether it's through a donation, by sharing our IndieGoGo on your Facebook page, or by spreading the word to your friends. We appreciate every dollar, and we can't do it without your help! :)

- Justin, Kelly, and Trevin

story:
Hello!

My name is James Holbrook and I am a professional actor living and working in the great city of Chicago.  On my 30th birthday, I landed my next fantastic acting role.  I am going back to beautiful Sonora, California to be in HARVEY at Sierra Repertory Theatre﻿. After an absolutely fantastic experience in their 2008 production of SOUTH PACIFIC, I am thrilled to be returning to this fantastic theatre and creative team.  They are some of the greatest human beings and artists in this industry, and are graciously taking the best care of me that they can.

This project takes me one step closer to full union membership (I will be well over half way).  Becoming an Equity actor is my ultimate goal, and in order to keep that momentum going I am going to need your help.  My contract is for $200 a week. While in California, I will not only be working for the theatre, but working to keep in touch with my contacts in Chicago, keep my bills paid, and keep looking for the next audition.

In order to achieve my goals, I am looking to raise $1500, which breaks down to an extra $150 weekly and matches the Theatre's weekly Equity minimum pay scale ($350/wk) for the duration of the 8 week contract.  

All contributions will help make this project a success, even if you can just help by spreading the word through your own social networks!

I have posted my audition video and will continue to update with other videos and ways to connect with my work.

Please check out my Facebook page, follow me on Twitter, and follow my blog through my website.  

Thank you all so much!

James Holbrook

story:
Who We Are

Iluminar Aerial is a professional aerial dance and circus arts company specializing in performance and education under the direction of Emmy and Travis Moon. Iluminar strives to move aerial dance into a respected and recognized dance genre by combining technical dance into the vertical space. Our goal as a company is to increase the recognition of the aerial and circus arts across the globe but especially in the United States. We want anyone and everyone to experience the joy of the circus world, either by taking a class with us or enjoying our performances as audience members. 

Iluminar Aerial provides aerial and circus classes for kids and adults at their Broomfield studio and at various schools around the Denver and Boulder area. Iluminar produces five annual shows per season with their professional core company and their youth performance company. Iluminar also provides a wide range of circus entertainment for a variety of events around the United States including aerial acrobatics, stilt walking, juggling, fire dancing, acrobatics and gymnastics. 

Our Campaign

Our campaign’s goal is to raise enough money to provide the financial assistance to our company members to be able to travel to Ireland for a week in the summer of 2014.  Fidget Feet Aerial hosts the Irish Aerial Dance Festival every year in Letterkenny, Co. Donegal.  This festival provides a medium for some of the most talented people in the aerial circus community to teach classes in cutting edge techniques and forms.  The festival also provides companies attending the opportunity to bring pieces to Ireland to perform for the festival, which Iluminar is planning to do.

In a world that is too quick to disregard the arts as frivolous, we dedicate our lives to maintain a sense of grace and beauty in this often dark world.  Helping to send us to as beautiful a place as Ireland to learn what we love from people we respect will mean more to us than we can ever possibly communicate to you.

Helping us achieve our funding goal will provide a once in a lifetime opportunity for our company members to experience our art form in a new and inspirational country.  Traveling overseas is quite expensive, and many of our company members work 2, 3 or even 4 jobs to be able to pursue their art form that they love so much.

At current prices, a round trip flight from Denver, CO to Dublin, Ireland costs about $900-$1000.  From there, we will be traveling by bus to the northern part of County Donegal.  Lodging in Letterkenny for aerialists attending the festival ranges anywhere from $45 to $110 a night.  We will also have to fend for ourselves in a foreign land for food, which we are all rather looking forward to.

As far as the fundraising campaign is concerned, the minimum amount we are hoping to raise will help provide transportation from the States to Ireland and back.  Anything more than that and we will hopefully be able to provide lodging and some meals to our members.

If you can't contribute financially, we understand completely.  Good news is that you can still help!  Please share this on Facebook, Twitter, and every other social media you can find!  Help us get the word out so we can continue to be a thriving member of the wonderful contemporary aerial and circus world!

Meet the Company 


Emmy Moon, Artistic Director & Co-Owner

Emmy graduated from Collin College with her Associate of Arts Degree in Dance and then went on to complete her Bachelors in Dance from the University of Texas(UT) in Austin.  Immediately after college, Emmy was invited to dance with Aerial Dance Chicago where she was a core company dancer. She continued her training in Los Angeles  in order to train and work closely with Aerial Experience Productions(AEP) and Arise Aerial Dance. She currently still works with AEP for special events and corporate shows around the world.

Emmy was introduced to aerial dance at UT when she was selected to perform in an installation piece with rope and harnesses and quickly after, started silk training at Blue Lapis Light in Austin, TX. She continued her training with Aerial Dance Chicago, Aloft Circus Arts, Helium Aerial Dance, Hollywood Aerial Arts, Arise Aerial Dance, Frequent Flyers and at the Aerial Dance Festival in Colorado. Emmy has had the opportunity to perform for many companies, places, clients and events including the Toshiba International Conference, Midnight Circus, Millennium Park and the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago, Hewlett Packard, “Imagine Christmas” Touring Show, “Stories from the Shack” Touring Show, and as a featured aerialist in an international LG Washing Machine commercial. Emmy was recently invited to be one of the silks judges for the first ever Miss Texas Polestar Aerial Arts Competition in Dallas Texas in October of 2012.

Emmy’s choreography has been shown around the United States in Austin, Dallas, Chicago, Los Angeles, Seattle, Atlanta, New York and Denver for numerous events. Her choreography was selected for the Gala show at the American College Dance Festival in 2006. In 2011, Emmy, featuring Iluminar Aerial, was selectively invited to be a part of the Alumni Dance Fusion Show in Plano Texas, highlighting former students that have broken ground in the professional dance world.

Travis Moon, Executive Director & Co-Owner

Growing up, Travis participated in numerous competitive sports and martial arts training. In high school, he joined the JROTC, Junior Reserve Officer Training Course, which provided him an education in discipline, respect and leadership techniques.  JROTC propelled his interest in learning other military techniques like rock climbing, rappelling and knot tying. He discovered aerial arts as the perfect way to pursue all of his hobbies and ambitions.

Travis started his aerial training under the direction of Emmy Moon and together they created Iluminar Aerial. Travis has continued his training with Blue Lapis Light in Austin, Texas, at the Aerial Dance Festival in Boulder, CO, Shayna Swanson of Aloft Loft, and studied partner acrobatics with Colleen Mckeown and Amy Christian of WiseFool.  He has had the privilege to teach and perform at many different events including the Dance Fusion show at Collin College, multiple private schools in Denver and Boulder, Mile High Station, Parker Wildlife Experience, Robert G. Weiland Center, Denver Hilton Hotel, City Hall Events Venue, Lockport Exchange Circus and the Miss Texas Polestar Competition in Dallas.

Fallon Voorheis, Assistant Director & Core Company Dancer

Fallon Voorheis is a Colorado native who started taking gymnastics lessons when she was 3 years old after her mom caught her hanging off of their 3rd floor balcony. She was a competitive gymnast for most of her childhood and adolescent life. 

While attending Mesa State College she taught at Grand Junction Gymnastics Academy while working on a minor in dance.  She was introduced to the art of aerial dance in 2010 and immediately was hooked as it combines her passion for gymnastics and dance.  She has spent most of her training at Frequent Flyers as a member of the apprentice company. She has also studied with Tanya Burka of Cirque du Soleil, Annabelle D’Artois of Cocoon Aerial Dance, and with the Imperial Flyers High Flying Trapeze Club.

George Grijalva, Media Director & Core Company Dancer

George has been an athlete all his life, he started playing Soccer as a child and Water Polo, swimming and wrestling in High School.  He continued developing his athletic ability and has received various recognitions in: Jiu jitsu, wrestling, indoor soccer, fencing, dancing, biking, waterpolo, swimming, running, and scuba diving.

Then he caught the Ballroom bug when he met his wife, a professional Ballroom Dance instructor, and competed in the American Rhythm style of dancing for a few years.  He’s currently a Bronze level Ballroom Rhythm instructor (Salsa, Merenge, Rumba, Cha-Cha, Bolero, Waltz, Samba, Tango, Swing), he continues developing his athletic skills here at Iluminar Aerial. His competitive edge keeps him motivated and gives him the advantage to pursue an active lifestyle.

Katie Brunner, Entertainment Coordinator & Core Company Dancer

Katie began her immersion in circus arts in Gainesville, Florida where she trained in aerial fabric and trapeze with S-Connection Aerial Arts. Her passion for hooping and fire performance blossomed while she completed her Master’s degree in Public Health and co-founded the performance troupe Obsidian Fire Entertainment. She has performed and taught with the University of Florida’s aerial dance club and at events throughout North Florida including the Rasa-Lila Yoga Festival, Tioga Spring Arts Festival, Two Hawk Hammock Festivals, NightGlo Downtown events, and more.

In August 2012, Katie relocated to Denver, Colorado to pursue her dream of fusing aerial artistry, circus entertainment and fitness education. She teaches classes and private lessons in aerial dance, hula hoop, and acrobalance and is excited about the opportunity to bring cirque arts to youth as an educator with the Iluminar Mobile Outreach Program.

Marci Wojciechowski, Core Company Dancer

Marci Wojciechowski has been dancing since age five and has trained in ballet, jazz, contemporary, modern, hip-hop and has recently started aerial dance with Iluminar Aerial.  While dancing at the University of Colorado she graduated with a degree in Kinesiology, she later attended The George Washington University where she obtained Masters degrees in Public Health as well as Heath Sciences.  She has performed with various companies in Florida, Colorado, New York and Washington D.C. and is currently performing and choreographing with Art As Action as well as Iluminar.  Marci spends her time outside of dance working as a physician assistant in trauma surgery, spending time with family, friends, her pup Layla and traveling as much as possible.

Bringing together the science of the human body with the grace and strength it has the potential to possess is truly an amazing gift.  Marci is lucky to have a career that focuses on healing and the mechanics and chemistry of the body as well as dancing in the ground and in the air to further physical health, creativity and artistry.

Ashley Smith, Core Company Dancer

Ashley Smith graduated from the University of Colorado in Boulder with her Bachelors of Arts Degree in dance. Throughout her career, she had the opportunity to train in many dance forms among them ballet, modern, jazz, contemporary, salsa, African, to finally aerial dance.  Ashley fell in love with aerial dance when she was selected to perform in an aerial piece at the University choreographed by Nancy Smith. Later on she was invited by Smith to perform with her professional company, Frequent Flyers, in their spring show Cirque du Minuit. Ashley went on to receive formal training through Frequent Flyers by completing their Professional Aerial Dance Training Track. Later, alongside four other colleagues, she founded Rabble Dance Collective, an aerial dance troupe focused on combining physical theater, aerial dance, and circus arts.

With a passion for aerial dance and being a bit of an “adrenaline junky”,  Ashley finds joy in being able to perform in many settings; from black box theater, to guerilla rigging off of cliffs, bridges, trees, etc. She has performed locally in Boulder with her aerial company Rabble Dance Collective, and with Lemon Sponge Cake Ballet, Moth Poetic Circus, Devotchka, Frequent Flyers, and internationally at the International Dance Festival in Italy. Ashley is excited to continue performing and teaching with Iluminar Aerial to bring the joy of aerial dance to people of all ages and backgrounds.

Daniel Nolasco, Core Company Dancer

Daniel Nolasco is from El Paso, TX but considers himself a Coloradan for having lived there for most of his life. Always passionate about the arts and ways of expression, he has trained in a variety of art forms. He came to the world of circus through Frequent Flyers Productions Inc. in Boulder, CO where he trained and performed with them for 3 years. The exhilarating combination of dance, theater, physicality, and music has made circus his addiction. He has completed his 2nd year of training in the New England Center for Circus Arts Professional Program focusing on Static/Dance Trapeze, and Sling in Brattleboro, VT. He is currently starting his first season with Iluminar Aerial, with whom he dreams of performing his work and passion into spectacular productions that can be performed for a variety of audiences.

Sophia Herscu, Core Company Dancer

At age six, Sophia started putting on circus shows on the swing-set in the backyard of her house in Amherst, MA. Although circus and aerial arts have only recently returned to the forefront of her life, the days swinging around like a monkey in the backyard certainly made an impression. Sophia was delighted to discover aerial arts during college as the perfect infusion of athletics and creativity- two of her passions. 


Sophia graduated in 2011 from Colorado College with a BA in Sociology and Drama/Dance. After graduation she was awarded a Watson Fellowship to travel the world teaching and learning about the positive effects of circus education on underprivileged youth and women. Upon her return, Sophia attended the year long Professional Aerial Dance Program at Frequent Flyers Productions in Boulder, CO. In early 2013 Sophia and four classmates at FFP founded Rabble Dance Collective, an aerial group that mixed together original music, dance, aerials, physical theater, and social justice. Sophia is excited to join Iluminar for the 2013-2014 season!

Ariel Mosier, Core Company Intern

Ariel Mosier was born and raised in Colorado, dancing and flipping for Airborne Gymnastics and Dance. She was a student athlete in gymnastics, diving and track until graduating Niwot High School in May 2012. After graduation she discovered the aerial arts and in September moved to Orlando, FL to begin training with the company AntiGravity; studying aerial silks, lyra, cube, trampoline, bungee and walltrack. After winning Best Innovation Apparatus in the Aerial Arts Festival 2013 with her AntiGravity team, Ariel moved back home to begin working towards a Bachelor’s degree in Biology.  In addition to being an Illuminar Intern, she teaches gymnastics at Airborne Gymnastics in Longmont.
story_txt:
Who We AreIluminar Aerial is a professional aerial dance and circus
arts company specializing in performance and education under the direction of
Emmy and Travis Moon. Iluminar strives to move aerial dance into a respected
and recognized dance genre by combining technical dance into the vertical
space. Our goal as a company is to increase the recognition of the aerial and circus arts across the globe but especially in the United States. We want anyone and everyone to experience the joy of the circus world, either by taking a class with us or enjoying our performances as audience members. 
Iluminar Aerial provides aerial and circus
classes for kids and adults at their Broomfield studio and at various schools around the Denver and Boulder area. Iluminar produces five annual shows per season with their professional core company and their youth performance company. Iluminar also provides a wide range of circus entertainment for a variety of events around the United States including aerial acrobatics, stilt walking, juggling, fire dancing, acrobatics and gymnastics. Our Campaign
Our campaign’s goal
is to raise enough money to provide the financial assistance to our company
members to be able to travel to Ireland for a week in the summer of 2014.  Fidget Feet Aerial hosts the Irish Aerial Dance
Festival every year in Letterkenny, Co. Donegal.  This festival provides a medium for some of
the most talented people in the aerial circus community to teach classes in
cutting edge techniques and forms.  The
festival also provides companies attending the opportunity to bring pieces to
Ireland to perform for the festival, which Iluminar is planning to do.
In a world that is
too quick to disregard the arts as frivolous, we dedicate our lives to maintain
a sense of grace and beauty in this often dark world.  Helping to send us to as beautiful a place as
Ireland to learn what we love from people we respect will mean more to us than
we can ever possibly communicate to you.
Helping us achieve
our funding goal will provide a once in a lifetime opportunity for our company
members to experience our art form in a new and inspirational country.  Traveling overseas is quite expensive, and many
of our company members work 2, 3 or even 4 jobs to be able to pursue their art
form that they love so much.
At current prices, a
round trip flight from Denver, CO to Dublin, Ireland costs about
$900-$1000.  From there, we will be
traveling by bus to the northern part of County Donegal.  Lodging in Letterkenny for aerialists
attending the festival ranges anywhere from $45 to $110 a
night.  We will also have to fend for
ourselves in a foreign land for food, which we are all rather looking forward
to.
As far as the
fundraising campaign is concerned, the minimum amount we are hoping to raise
will help provide transportation from the States to Ireland and back.  Anything more than that and we will hopefully
be able to provide lodging and some meals to our members.If you can't contribute financially, we understand completely.  Good news is that you can still help!  Please share this on Facebook, Twitter, and every other social media you can find!  Help us get the word out so we can continue to be a thriving member of the wonderful contemporary aerial and circus world!
Meet
the Company 
Emmy Moon, Artistic
Director & Co-Owner
Emmy graduated from Collin College with her Associate
of Arts Degree in Dance and then went on to complete her Bachelors in Dance
from the University of Texas(UT) in Austin.  Immediately after college, Emmy
was invited to dance with Aerial Dance Chicago where she was a core company
dancer. She continued her training in Los Angeles  in order to train and
work closely with Aerial Experience Productions(AEP) and Arise Aerial Dance.
She currently still works with AEP for special events and corporate shows
around the world.

Emmy was introduced to aerial dance at UT when
she was selected to perform in an installation piece with rope and harnesses
and quickly after, started silk training at Blue Lapis Light in Austin, TX. She
continued her training with Aerial Dance Chicago, Aloft Circus Arts, Helium
Aerial Dance, Hollywood Aerial Arts, Arise Aerial Dance, Frequent Flyers and at
the Aerial Dance Festival in Colorado. Emmy has had the opportunity to perform
for many companies, places, clients and events including the Toshiba
International Conference, Midnight Circus, Millennium Park and the Museum of
Science and Industry in Chicago, Hewlett Packard, “Imagine Christmas”
Touring Show, “Stories from the Shack” Touring Show, and as a featured
aerialist in an international LG Washing Machine commercial. Emmy was recently
invited to be one of the silks judges for the first ever Miss Texas Polestar
Aerial Arts Competition in Dallas Texas in October of 2012.
Emmy’s choreography has been shown around the United

Colorado native who started taking gymnastics lessons when she was 3 years old

Mosier was born and raised in Colorado, dancing and flipping for Airborne

story:
About The Show :

Steph is a recovering depressive. Jamie overachieved himself off the deep end. When they meet in their psychiatrist's office, they can't deny their chemistry, but can they survive it? A pitch black and piercingly insightful comedy about being crazy in love.

Chemistry was written by Jacob Marx Rice on a trip to Ireland, cobbled together on park benches and church naves. It has been workshopped at Actors Theatre of Louisville with the Apprentice Company and  performed at the Alchemical Theatre Laboratory. Chemistry is a powerful and hilariously truthful portrayal of life with mental illness. 

We can't wait to share it with you.

What We Need :

We've set this campaign up as an all or nothing fundraising effort, which mean's it is impossible for us to put on this production with out your help! 

While we're trying to do this on as small of a budget as possible, there are some things that are simply going to cost us money. Here is a rough estimate of the what we need money for in order to cover for the show:

  • Festival Administrative Fee, Indiegogo Fee, Fundraising Perks/Mailing, Program Printing ~ $1,780
  • Set Design, Makeup, Costumes ~ $450
  • Insurance to cover us, and insurance to cover you when you come to see the show ~ $125
  • Personnel stipends for our crew: Producer, Director, Writer, Marketing and Press Director, Assistant Director, Two Actors, Stage Manager, Costume Designer, Makeup Artist, Lighting Designer, Photographer, Graphic Designer, Composer, Venue Manager ~ $2,100
  • Marketing and Promotional Materials, Website, Postcard Printing ~ $920
  • Fireproofing our set ~ $300

We're hoping to raise $5,750.00 in order to safely cover all of the costs of our production, and that will give us a tiny bit of a contingency for any emergencies. 

We know this is a very big number to reach. If you break it down, we need at least 220 of you to donate $25.00 each in order to reach our goal.

Remember, no donation is too small, even a dollar will help us get there! 

What You'll Get :

Other than the wonderful warm fuzzies of doing something good for your fellow man, and a fully realized version of Chemistry - we have some great perks for all of our donors, both big and small! Please check out the prizes at the side of the page for more details!

The Creative Team :

Audra Arnaudon (Producer) is on her third show for The New York International Fringe Festival. In 2012, Audra produced ...And Then She DIES at the End!, which received a Performance Award from the festival. In 2013, she produced I Was Loved by a Rat, which was directed by Anna Strasser. She graduated with honors from the New York University's Tisch School of the Arts with a major in Film and Television and a minor in Producing. When not producing her own work, Audra is a Production Manager for National Geographic Television’s Live Free or Die, which will be premiering on NatGeo this fall.

Anna Strasser (Director) directed I Was Loved by a Rat and produced Recipe For Success With Chef Michael Denardi, both of which premiered at The New York International Fringe Festival last summer. In the spring of 2013 Anna directed a one-act play by Anthony Dvarskas, which premiered at the Strawberry One Act Festival. She directed Lucy Wang in Chinese Girls Don't Swear at the Workshop Theater in Manhattan. Following this, Anna helped her develop it into a one-woman show, which was produced by the Emerging Artists Theater in 2013. Currently Anna works as the Executive Assistant at Signature Theatre Company. Prior to that she worked in the administrative offices of Lincoln Center Theater. She graduated from Oberlin College with honors in Theater, where she also double majored in psychology.

Jacob Marx Rice (Writer) has had plays produced and developed by Actors Theatre of Louisville, The New York International Fringe Festival, Sanctuary: Playwrights Theatre, The Alchemical Theatre Laboratory, The Cake Shop, Theater in Asylum, Carlton College, and Barnard College Theatre Department. He is the winner of the 2012 Seymour Brick Memorial Prize for Playwriting and a semi-finalist for 36th Annual Bay Area Playwrights Festival. Jacob attended Columbia University where he studied playwriting with Ellen McLaughlin, Julia Jordan, and Sylvan Oswald.

Diana Levy (Marketing Director) has produced, general and company managed, and marketed shows at Fringe, NYMF, Columbia University, and at various Off-Off-Broadway venues. Previous work includes Portrait and a Dream (FringeNYC 2011, Producer), The Cake Shop Theatre Company's Pains of Youth (General Manager), Foreverman (NYMF 2012, Company Manager).  A graduate of Columbia University with a double-major in theatre and political science, she currently works in the facilities department of the Shubert Organization.

FringeNYC & The Future :

FringeNYC has served as a springboard to Broadway and Off-Broadway for many years, introducing the world to shows like Urinetown and Dog Sees God. The festival has launched the careers of many well-known writers, such as The Office's Mindy Kaling. Basically: if you kill it at FringeNYC it can open doors. Doors that you will have helped us walk through! We hope you'll support our show and the tradition of FringeNYC!

Other Ways You Can Help :

If you're in Manhattan, or Brooklyn, or the Bronx, or even just close by - come see our show in August at FringeNYC! The proceeds we make for the show will help us to cover some of the costs we will ultimately incur while putting on the production. We're still waiting on our venue assignment and our performance schedule, but will be posting updates here as soon as we have them!

If you can't come see the show, and you can't contribute monetarily, but you would still like to help out - please make some noise for us! A Like or a Share on Facebook or Twitter is so incredibly valuable to our fundraising efforts. Spreading our community out even to one more person that we don't know personally, will help us exponentially in our goals. Use the links above (you'll see them just below the video) to let your family and friends know about our fundraising efforts!

that she worked in the administrative offices of Lincoln Center Theater. She
graduated from Oberlin College with honors in Theater, where she also double
majored in psychology.Jacob Marx Rice (Writer) has had plays produced and developed by Actors Theatre of Louisville, The New York International Fringe Festival, Sanctuary: Playwrights Theatre, The Alchemical Theatre Laboratory, The Cake Shop, Theater in Asylum, Carlton College, and Barnard College Theatre Department. He is the winner of the 2012 Seymour Brick Memorial Prize for Playwriting and a semi-finalist for 36th Annual Bay Area Playwrights Festival. Jacob attended Columbia University where he studied playwriting with Ellen McLaughlin, Julia Jordan, and Sylvan Oswald.Diana Levy (Marketing Director) has produced, general and company managed, and marketed shows at Fringe, NYMF, Columbia University, and at various Off-Off-Broadway venues. Previous work includes Portrait and a Dream (FringeNYC 2011, Producer), The Cake Shop Theatre Company's Pains of Youth (General Manager), Foreverman (NYMF 2012, Company Manager).  A graduate of Columbia University with a double-major in theatre and political science, she currently works in the facilities department of the Shubert Organization.FringeNYC & The Future :FringeNYC has served as a springboard to Broadway and Off-Broadway for many years, introducing the world to shows like Urinetown and Dog Sees God. The festival has launched the careers of many well-known writers, such as The Office's Mindy Kaling. Basically: if you kill it at FringeNYC it can open doors. Doors that you will have helped us walk through! We hope you'll support our show and the tradition of FringeNYC!Other Ways You Can Help :If you're in Manhattan, or Brooklyn, or the Bronx, or even just close by - come see our show in August at FringeNYC! The proceeds we make for the show will help us to cover some of the costs we will ultimately incur while putting on the production. We're still waiting on our venue assignment and our performance schedule, but will be posting updates here as soon as we have them!If you can't come see the show, and you can't contribute monetarily, but you would still like to help out - please make some noise for us! A Like or a Share on Facebook or Twitter is so incredibly valuable to our fundraising efforts. Spreading our community out even to one more person that we don't know personally, will help us exponentially in our goals. Use the links above (you'll see them just below the video) to let your family and friends know about our fundraising efforts!

story:
WHY I NEED YOUR HELP

My name is Robert Smith, and I'm a professional actor living in New York city.  I have been working as a professional actor since getting my Masters of Fine Arts (MFA) from the University of Florida.

I recently have been working on Film/Television sets, and I now have the opportunity to join the Screen Actor's Guild (SAG).  This is great news since it will ensure that I am able to work in a fair and adequate work environment, as well as increase my paycheck as an actor (on certain sets I could make up to 3X as much as I currently make).

To join SAG I must pay an initial $3,000.  This is a one-time payment for benefits of a professional union, giving me the same rights and privileges of its members.

I have come up with some great rewards to send you for your donations, and I hope you can give support in any way possible.  Please only give what you can, and anything you give will be greatly appreciated.  If you can't give money, then please share my page and story on any/every social media platform which you are currently a subscriber.  

I appreciate everything you can do for me and have possibly done in the past!  I hope to one day win an award and thank you along the way.  But you can help by being a part of this campaign today!

WHAT ARE YOU SUPPORTING?

Helping pay Robert Smith's initiation fee for the Screen Actors Guild (SAG)

  • INITIAL FEE= $3,000
  • Fee is accessed for new members of union to obtain Union Rights/Contracts
  • SAG contracts provide a variety of protections for Guild performers. Among these provisions are: minimum rates of pay, adequate working conditions, special protection, arbitration of disputes and grievances, and affirmative action in audition and hiring. 

THE IMPACT

After becoming a SAG actor Robert's contracts will greatly improve and offer:

  • Increased opportunity for auditions
  • More opportunity to obtain speaking roles
  • Increased possibility of seeing him on TV/Film
  • Access to more experienced agents and/or managers

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Get the word out!!!  Please share my story on any social media you can and as often as you can!!!
  • There are easy links on this page for many social media platforms...

story:
Our Purpose

Emurge Theatre Company  is a non-profit organization  developing cultural awareness through theatre to provide understanding, respect, and appreciation of our diversity as a human race; while consistently seeking to provide a means of artistic expression in our community.  We will provide a platform for artists in an all-inclusive and non-divisive way for all cultures and backgrounds in the community.  We intend to share in the accountability of educating our youth through an “edutainment” format, that is designed to empower young people by promoting positive peer influences with a primary focus on our urban youth.  There is a need in Colorado to “urge” our children in the right direction also with the desire to assist in the emergence of racial and gender equality through the arts.  "Emerging into the light from the shadows."


What We Need & What You Get

Our Goals

  • With these programs we intend to build confidence and support our young people.
  • Emurging D.I.V.A.'s  and Emurgency Youth plan to spread light and love
  • These funds will got to taking young women to shows and helping to pay the stipends to the summer youth group


The Impact

Emurging Divas -

Redefining the Diva: Determined, Intelligent, Victorious & Able.

Young girls of all ethnicities and backgrounds tend to be left behind in a world focused on the well being of men and boys.  And, staying true to our vision, the purpose of Emurging Divas is to explore the solidarity of women. The goal is to have young girls from all walks of life share their experiences and to find understanding through sisterhood.  Also to educate them of the other choices in life and to not be defined by what society expects of them. While always striving to be more and setting goals.  We truly intend to provide these girls with cultural experiences they may otherwise not have had access to.  Emurging Divas has a goal to give these young women the building blocks to be successful and build confidence as well.  To know that they are beautiful as they are and learn to better love themselves will be the desired effect of our dream to Redefine the Diva.  

Program details-

-  Mentoring group sessions
-  Group outings to performing arts shows and other cultural activities
-  Volunteer work
-  Access to educational Guest speakers
-  And many more activities as they become available


EmUrgency Youth Group

For the last few years there has been a grave absence in the community for urban youth looking for an outlet. Being in the first few Youth Theatre programs directed by Jeffrey Nickelson, ShaShauna found a need that this program be back in the community.  EmUrgency was born with the mind frame that there is an emergency in the community and it is Urgent that we address it.  The EmUrgency Youth Group is a summer creative outlet where young people can express themselves and the situations they are faced with day to day; while articulating their experiences in a safe and secure environment without being judged or ridiculed.  We want the youth to explain to us, what we can’t possibly understand as adults.

Program details -

-  Learn self-expression

-  Assist each other in creating a theatre performance

-  Guest artists attend assisting in the learning process

-  Guiding young artists through education and entertainment


Other Ways You Can Help

No matter which way you become involved with any nonprofit you support, the sole fact that you have become associated will help.  Being directly involved with Emurge, you’ll share your experiences with other like-minded individuals through casual conversations and various events.  This type of sharing and involvement can go a very long way to gain more local support for our cause.  Using tools like word-of-mouth to grow awareness.

story:
Our Story

Margie Timmons is a state award winning drama teacher, whose high school kids consistently win superiors at local, district, and state drama competitions, without even having an actual theatre at Gulf Breeze High School ! She inspires her kids to not only be wonderful actors/thespians, but to be incredible human beings. The kids that have auditioned for the Spring Musical, "The Drowsy Chaperone", have been told they have to raise the entire cost of the production, because there is no school system funding for "the Arts". They have to rent a local theatre at Pensacola State College, pay for the rights to the production, costumes, the orchestra, technical assistance at the theatre, printing costs, set building costs, and more. There were many kids who were selected to be in the show, who ultimately could not participate because of the enormous financial expectations each student has to raise. Please help these talented teenagers raise the money to put on this production, so that more teens will be able to participate in the show!


The Impact

Without any outside funding, each child is expected to pay @175 each, just to participate in the show, plus an additional $150 in ad sales, and another $225 in ticket sales. There are many families who simply cannot raise this kind of money, and so their kids will get left out. If we can raise it from the online community, these kids will all get a chance to be in the show!


What We Need & What You Get

Checks can also be sent directly to: Gulf Breeze High School Drama, 675 Gulf Breeze Parkway, Gulf Breeze, Fl 32561 (850) 602 3792.

 

The money you donate will cover the following: The costs of the theatre rental--because the high school does not have its own theatre ($10,000), Costumes (3,000), Choreography (2000), Accompanist (2000), Orchestra (7,000), 3 drops (1500), Warehouse rental for one month to build set (1000), Set (3000), Tech support for show (1,500), Show rights (5000), Microphone rental (1000), Dance shoes for all actors (2000), Printing costs (1000)

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with your friends on Facebook and other social network sites. Also needed: Debit cards to Home Depot or Lowe's for bulding supplies, and donations of 1920's style mens and women's clothing.

 

These kids are the talented thespians of the future ! Thanks very much for helping them !!

story:
Our Story

Throughout the years 2009 and 2010, dozens of new playwrights have submitted their original scripts to Mildred’s Umbrella Theater Company. Due to our small budget, and the long list of projects we’ve been wanting to bring to Houston audiences, we haven’t been able to produce as many of these fabulous plays as we would like, but we have narrowed the scripts down to four new plays that fit the edginess of Mildred’s Umbrella’s unique aesthetic. Any of these plays would be a treat for Houston audiences, but we can only produce one of them. We plan to let our audience help us decide.


In the 2011-2012 season, we have scheduled four staged readings, one for each of the plays. These readings will be open to the public, and advertised the same as any show we produce. They will be directed by seasoned directors, and cast with the highest quality actors, and the performances will be ‘pay as you like. We will host a talk-back after the performance in which audience members can interact with the cast and director (and in most cases, the playwright as well), and we will also have a survey for the audience to fill out if they desire to participate. There will be a panel of experts at all the readings as well (Experienced playwrights, writing professors, theatre directors) to give additional feedback.


The readings will take place in August 2011, October 2011, January 2012 and April 2012. From the readings and feedback, a play will be chosen for a world premier production in the 2012-2013 season.

 

The Impact

The playwrights we’ve selected are from all over the US, and we will market the readings and production to all relevant areas to promote tourism into Houston from Texas and beyond.This will allow the audiences of the Houston Theatre scene to show their favorite little indy theatre what kind of show they want to see. It will also allow our fair city to witness four world premiers before any other city, and one full world premier production.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $3000 to bring in the playwrights and put them up, to pay the actors and directors for their amazing work, to pay for the performance spaces... this way we can allow everyone to come and hear the readings for free, especially those who cannot afford to pay, such as students from local colleges and high schools who would like to experience this cutting edge work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Got a space we can use? Airline tickets? A hotel?

story:
I am Mariana Moraes.  I am a 23 year old pre-professional dancer from Belem/PA, Brazil. 

I started dancing ballet when I was six years old in a small ballet school in my city.  My mother was a ballerina and she was my inspiration to start this amazing journey. 

For ten years, I participated in many festivals around Brazil.  That was my life: studying at school, and spending my free time dancing. When I was 16 years old I had to choose between going to university or being a dancer.  Unfortunately in Brazil, and even more so in my city, the support for dance and art is nearly nonexistent.  I had to be rational; I decided to be a lawyer.  For the 3 and a half years that I attended university, I wasn’t myself.  I had stopped doing the thing that made me the happiest in life.  I felt terrible for a long time.  I was stuck doing something that was making me very sad.

A big “BOOM” happened to me then; I was nearly depressed and so I decided to stop going to university and I decided to run after my life's dream.  In 2011, I started to dedicate my life to dance again.  I decided to be happy no matter how much I was going to get from dance, or if I was even going to get anything at all.  

But of course, it wasn’t easy.  At first, my family and friends didn’t understand what was happening.  Eventually I received support from a few people around me, and the most important support that I had was my mother who had always believed in my talent.

In July, 2011, I went to Parauapebas to visit my mother, and, by coincidence, a small dance festival was happening at the same time.  It was here that I met one of the most important people in my life that is making me write this story, Monica Proenca.  I took classes with her for three days.  When I was introduced to contemporary and modern dance, I became extremely interested.  Soon after, I was invited by Monica Proenca {a director alongside Davi Rodrigues and Lara Barclay}, to go to Vancouver, Canada, and be a part of Lamondance, a pre-professional dance training company. 

In January  2011, I finally arrived in Vancouver.  I couldn’t believe that it was really happening!  My small dream was starting to come true, and be bigger that I had ever thought.  Getting there was already one of the hardest challenges in my life.  Being and living there was the challenge; I was far away from my friends and family, trying to deal with language and cultural differences between Canada and Brazil, but I knew that I couldn’t give up; this was my opportunity to be a professional dancer.  The classes, creative process, and rehearsals with Lamondance were incredibly intense, but I loved every single second of it.  For a year and a half I danced with Lamondance, and during that time I grew up as a dancer and, more importantly, as a human being.  I had amazing experiences, I learned English, I made friends, and Vancouver became my home.

But again, this was all possible because of one person in the world --- my mother.  She helped me with money, and she paid for everything by herself, but she can not help me anymore.  I still have the opportunity to go back to Canada and keep going with my dream, and go even further, but unfortunately I can not do this alone in the short amount of time that I have left. This is the reason why I am here asking for your help.

The money that I am seeking will be going towards my airfare, my Canadian visa, and my healthy insurance.  I hope you feel inspired enough with my story to help me, and to dream with me. Any amount you are able to donate would mean a lot to me.

Please do not think that I am just doing this for myself.  My dream is to one day share and teach all that I have learned about dance.  I also want to inspire people the same way my mother inspired me.  I love what I do and I want to show my dance and art all over the world if it is possible.

I hope you can help me raise this amount of money.  Also, I would love it if you could please share this campaign.  It is another way to help me, and I am forever grateful for that. 

I really appreciate your help. Thank you!
Mariana Moraes

story:
The Playtime Players


Summary of Our Fundraising Campaign

The Playtime Players ensemble includes four musicians and four actors.  Each member brings a wealth of diverse personal and professional experiences to our troupe.  We believe that children under five have the same right to experience and enjoy authentic live theatre as older children.  We introduce small children to theatre in a comfortable and developmentally appropriate manner, meeting them where they are at and bringing them theatre on their terms.  During the rehearsal process, we combine knowledge of child development and arts education with collaborative artistic exploration to arrive at a final theatrical production thirty minutes in length.  We are one of only a handful of theatre companies in the United States creating theatre for under-fivers.  We believe Theatre for the Very Young will find a perfect niche in Boston and contribute to the community in incredible ways.  We can’t do this work alone, and need your support to bring our shows to life! 


What We Need & How You Can Help

-We are currently seeking funding through fundraising, donations, and grants!  As a new theatre company, we need resources to pay for:

-Costume Pieces

-Set Pieces

-Props

-Toys and Interactive Items

-Publicity Materials

-Travel Expenditures

While The Playtime Players is not yet a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, your contributions will assist us in extending our reach and eventually gaining non-profit status.  All donations are greatly appreciated!  All contributors will be highlighted in the Special Acknowledgements section of our website.


Your Donation Will Make a Big Impact!

We are all responsible for the wellbeing of the tiniest members of our society.  Theatre for the Very Young brings children and their caregivers a novel, unforgettable experience!  We believe it is vital that children of all ages have access to foundational activities in the arts and are passionate about bringing our unique programming to the Boston area.  Current research confirms that exposure to live theatre is beneficial for small children in many ways.  Theatre fosters young children’s aesthetic appreciation and artistic development, and encourages cognitive skills such as focus and critical thinking.  As a shared community experience, it promotes interpersonal connection and socio-emotional growth, and supports the adult-child bond so crucial to early development.  It also provides a nurturing space to practice appropriate audience behavior, which will serve children as they attend the performing arts in later childhood.  Most importantly, live theatre is an enriching and enjoyable experience, and should be available to even the youngest of audience members!  Your donation will help bring our shows to community centers, libraries, theaters, and other public spaces throughout Boston and the surrounding area. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute financially, use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word about our performance troupe and generate interest through word of mouth advertising!  Tell your friends and family all about our new theatrical venture and help us build the connections we need to succeed!

The Playtime Players ensemble includes four musicians and four
actors.  Each member brings a wealth of
diverse personal and professional experiences to our troupe.  We believe that

companies in the United States creating theatre for under-fivers.  We believe Theatre for the Very Young will

story:
Hello people of the world!

My name is Abigail Vela and I am a first year attending The University of Texas at Austin. I am currently BA in Theatre and Dance with a focus in Acting. I am from La Joya, Texas, which is a small town in the "valley" area down south! 

Anywho, the reason I am making this campaign/page is to ask for any small donations from anybody in order to part of my study abroad trip to Florence, Italy. However, I would like to share a little bit as to why I want to study Theatre in Italy in the first place:

As a theatre major, my academic goal is to gain as much experience in the theater through various places, not just my education in the Department of Theatre and Dance. I want to gain connections and a different perspective about theatre arts, and by taking the opportunity to study abroad at Florence, Italy, I will have a head start in my academic pursuits.

This program allows me to complete six hours of credit that will benefit my BA in Theatre and Dance. The program’s course Dress, Decor, Culture, and Performance in Central Italy, will offer Commedia dell’Arte master classes where I will learn a style of theatre that originated in 16th Century Italy. I am interested in learning how a character and its mask can be inseparable, and how the characteristics of the mask influence the character’s dramatic movements. I have been curious to learn the fine art of puppetry as well, and how a puppeteer can create and bring pieces of wood, string, and wire alive. With the Commedia dell’Arte master classes and puppetry lessons, this program will give me versatility in my acting and theatrical experience.

I have the opportunity to study and live at a different city, rather than my hometown as a first year at The University of Texas at Austin. Besides Texas, the only place I have ever traveled is Mexico, though I have never lived or studied there. Living in Florence, Italy for the summer promises to enrich my global experience and acting repertoire. 

Florence will introduce new environments such as Roman amphitheaters. I will also learn a different culture of theatre, and gain insight toward the various theatre and performance opportunities in Italy. With this study abroad program, the journey towards my dreams will commence. I have faith I will live my goals in the near future if given the chance to take full advantage of the opportunity.

All funds will be released after my deadline for my campaign, which will be May 10, 2013. All funds will go directly towards my program needs, such as:

Tuition, program fee, food, and transportation!

My dream goal is to go past $2000. ALTHOUGH I SPECIFIED THAT MY GOAL IS $2000, I do not expect to reach it in such a small amount of time, which is why I ask for any sort of donations. However, if I reach it before my deadline, I will be forever in gratitude. 

Please help me gain experience, help me travel abroad for the first time in my life (including air travel), and please help me make my experience worthwhile! As a favor from many of my friends and family, I will be recording my experiences while in Italy through a blog, which I am in the process of creating. I will post it up here when I have it up and ready to go. 

Simply donate any amount, big or small, for any amount will be appreciated immensely. If you can't contribute, it's okay! Help me spread the word by sharing my story with your peers, family, etc. Share this page! Any help is welcome! 

Once again, I appreciate you taking your time to read this and helping out. Please spread the word and if there is any other way you'd like to help or if you have any questions, feel free to send me an e-mail to:

atabbeyroad@utexas.com   

or

atabbeyroad@gmail.com

 

Also, for all the details concerning the program, I have provided the Study Abroad Theatre In Italy website, directly from THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS STUDY ABROAD website:

http://utdirect.utexas.edu/io/abroad/pgm_list/detail.WBX?s_master_id=1035

 

Sincerely and with much consideration and appreciation,

 

Abigail Vela

 

 

Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/AbbyInItaly

story:
Overture

Arbor Opera Theater announces a fully staged, fully costumed production of The Marriage of Figaro, to be performed with orchestra June 13-16, 2013 at the Lydia Mendelssohn Theater in Ann Arbor, Michigan.

Recitativo

Based on a Beaumarchais play that was banned in Vienna (and seen as foreshadowing the French Revolution), Mozart and Da Ponte took a huge risk in this first collaboration and created what is a cornerstone of the operatic repertoire.  It's a screwball comedy filled with crazy plot twists and mistaken identities that simultaneously speaks to deep human truths and fears.  Sung in Italian with projected English supertitles, two professional casts, chorus and orchestra breathe new life into Mozart's masterpiece.

Aria: What your funding will make possible

Arbor Opera Theater offers initial professional experiences for artists emerging from academic and other training programs in music trying to bridge the gap from school to their professional careers.
 
With the current "system," singers and other artists (such as scenic and lighting designers, stage managers, etc.) leave the nest of university/conservatory with excellent training, but few full-blown production experiences that would allow them to be hired at professional theaters.  Managers & agents are needed to create initial contacts, but they usually won't sign a singer unless they've proven themselves a hirable commodity. Yet, you can't get hired unless you have these contacts. What to do?! That's where we have stepped in to create a company that "fills in the gap," and gives artists a professional platform to practice their craft and build their résumés. And since we started doing this in 1999, many singers have gone on to major careers, both regional and international.
 
As a grassroots non-profit organization, we rely on grants, ticket sales, fundraisers, and private donations to support our artist training programs and operatic productions. We are asking for your help:
 
Arbor Opera Theater needs $10,000 to pay emerging artists' fees for performing in lead and comprimario roles in its upcoming production of The Marriage of Figaro. We are offering a number of perks for our Indiegogo donors! YOUR donated funds will pay emerging artist fees.  Your donation is 100% tax deductible!!

Coda

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/ArborOpera?fref=ts
  • Attend our production!

 

About the Company

The Marriage of Figaro is the mainstage production of Arbor Opera Theater's 2013 Festival.  Arbor Opera Theater is a 501c3 non-profit arts organization that fosters the talents of operatic artists through professional performing experience and world-class training while cultivating a diverse audience through engaging programming and educational outreach.
