story:
Hello from Wax Wings!

A little on Wax Wings Productions...

My name is Micah Greene, I am the Artistic Director for Wax Wings Productions, a young theatre company working in Boston, MA. We are a group of actors, directors, designers and playwrights who came together seeking to create theatre that explores the deepest truths within Human Nature, and how they effect our choices. Elia Kazan, acclaimed director and actor wisely said in his Actor's Vow that "...The best and most human parts of me are those I have inhabited and hidden from the world. I will work on it. I will raise my voice. I will be heard." It is our mission to create theatre that excites, provokes and stimulates our audiences, while pursuing those "hidden" elements within our deepest selves. 

Our current project...

We are hard at work at the closing production of our first season, A Streetcar Named Desire. I know, big one to attempt, huh? However, we at Wax Wings are thrilled and eager for the challenge. We've found some amazing actors, talented designers and crew and have a wonderful director at the helm. We hope to continue to build our audience, connect with other theatre groups in Boston and, of course, do Mr. William's masterpiece justice. 

What would a contribution go towards in this campaign?

"I've always depended on the kindness of strangers..."

As a relatively new theatre company, we have been very proud to be able to compensate our performers and designers for their work. We aspire to be professionals and to continue to compensate our artists for the hard work they do. The funding from this campaign will be used to pay the director, actors, design and production team, offset productions costs including the rights, space rental, costumes, props, lights, sound and set costs.

Specifically, we need $2,400 for actor and production crew stipends, $800 for the rights. Funding for the arts can be hard to find. It takes a vibrant, cultural community for them to thrive. We feel lucky to be a part of Boston's Theatre scene, and ask any support from you to continue creating more theatre, more art to give back to the city. Besides our gratitude, we have some pretty neato perks to offer! Take a look-see!

Waxy Productions of the Past

We have been so incredibly fortunate to have produced three shows so far; The Last Days of Judas Iscariot, Grandma's House - an original play by a local Boston playwright (and now, company member!) and most recently, The Tragical History of Doctor Faustus with a primarily female cast. We have, other than our "mainstage" productions, our monthly Rumpus Nights which have ranged from staged readings of original works from local playwrights to Shakespeare themed scene studies, to readings of movie scripts (we tackled Resevoir Dogs!). With your help, we can grow and continue to provide more opportunities for directors to take on dream projects, playwrights to get their work done, and actors to stretch their wings.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute to our campaign (thanks for reading this far!), there are other ways that you can help! Word of mouth does wonders for new theatre! Share this link! Talk about us on Facebook, or check out and "Like" our Facebook page. That way you can get more info about us! Or go ahead and grab a ticket for the play itself. (Those will be up on our website). We open June 27 and run through July 7 in the Factory Theatre (791 Tremont Street, Boston MA). We hope to see you there!

As we continue and build ourselves as a company, we hope to learn from each production. We want to make sure this Indiegogo campaign is suceesful for the production but also in the eyes of our donors. Any support, whether it be a donation or simply mentioning us in a tweet or Facebook post, we are truly grateful. We could not have come as far as we have without support from people like you. Thank you.

More information at www.waxwingsproduction.com.

story:
Why was DanceWire created?

As a city who loves their arts Portland is home to a plethora of professional dance companies, studios, and dancers in styles ranging from ballet, aerial, and hip hop to tango, Bollywood and swing. But ... while Portland's dance scene is thriving and has a diversity of offerings, sometimes it's hard to find what you're looking for. DanceWire was created to serve as a centralized network for the Portland dance community where all information about what's going on is in one convenient location - classes, performances, workshops, auditions and more. In addition to being an information hub, DanceWire will offer resources to help strengthen the community as a whole. We believe that each organization whether new or old, big or small, of a formal style or experimental, contributes to Portland’s unique dance scene. We are committed to celebrating all styles of dance, addressing community needs, boosting involvement, and increasing accessibility and visibility to dance happening in the Portland community. 

Our mission is to:

- Support and promote all dance activity regardless of genre or prominence.
- Open up opportunities for companies, studios and individual dancers by increasing their respective visibility in a centralized network.
- Enrich the industry by providing forums for discussion and professional development and connectivity to local, national and international dance networks.

What we need:

We need to raise a minimum of $25,000 to cover start-up costs. Every dollar will go towards building the directory of companies and studios involved, marketing, promotion and developing a high functionality website. Since a quality website is essential to achieving our mission we want to build a site that is user-friendly, secure, interactive and meets the range of community needs.

Our business model is designed for lasting success:

Your contribution is primarily to get us going. Once up and running, our business model was designed so that earned revenue drawn from membership dues will sustain the core operations of the organization.

What does membership look like?

Individual: (what you'll get with every contribution over $50!)

- Access to a comprehensive calendar of performances, auditions, classes and workshops. (with the added bonus of filters to narrow it down to just what you want!)
- Monthly e-newsletter featuring information, resources and opportunities. 
- Opportunity to be a featured artist.
- Member discounts at all participating venues and with our business partners (companies, studios, salons, physical therapists.)
- Connection to an international network of artists and arts professionals.

Organizational:

- Opportunity to add listings to comprehensive calendar of performances, auditions, classes and workshops.
- Opportunity to promote through monthly e-newsletter emailed to the entire DanceWire mailing list. (Direct access to supporters of dance beyond the scope of your current followers!)
- Opportunity to be a featured organization. 
- Invitation to quarterly, topic-driven meetings to discuss dance community progressions, best practices and industry standards.
- Connection to an international network of artists and arts professionals.

Donation Levels:
All contributions at "Shaker" level or higher will get you a year of individual membership to DanceWire. Each member is a valuable asset to the overall network and directly increases our chance for continued success. The Founding Gem-Silver Spotlight ($1,000) and Founding Member-Golden Spotlight ($5,000) levels are for those who truly want to invest in the advancement of the Portland dance community.

Other ways you can help:

A “like” and a “tweet” and SHARE SHARE SHARE!! DanceWire is for everyone so please let your friends, families and professional networks know about this campaign.

story:
“This story must be told—be told, and laid to rest.”

One of the scariest plays of all time is coming your way. You might have seen it on stage. You have NEVER been part of it.

The Woman In Black. Join us for a theatrical experience in a 200-year-old Gothic-styled building. It will keep you torn between wandering deeper and taking flight. More than just a strange tale, theatre meets interactive media in your journey through this epic. You make it happen.

We dare you.
__________________________________

How Ticketing Works:
SGD 18 (USD 15)

When you purchase purchase a ticket, you will be contacted personally to place a reservation on any of the dates below. Your name will be immediately placed on a guest list, and will be used to sign in audience members on show day!

  • 7 February (Fri) 8pm (sold out)
  • 8 February (Sat) 6.30pm (1 space left!!!)
  • 8 February (Sat) 9pm (sold out)
  • 9 February (Sun) 6.30pm (sold out)
  • 9 February (Sun) 9pm (2 spaces left!!!)

Venue: Sculpture Square Chapel Gallery

Duration: 90 minutes, no intermission

story_txt:
“This
story must be told—be told, and laid to rest.”
One
of the scariest plays of all time is coming your way. You might have seen it on
stage. You have NEVER been part of it.
The Woman In Black. Join
us for a theatrical experience in a 200-year-old Gothic-styled building. It
will keep you torn between wandering deeper and taking flight. More than just a
strange tale, theatre meets interactive media in your journey through this
epic. You make it happen.
We
dare you.__________________________________

story:
WHY WE NEED WHAT WE NEED

The Encounter is complete. An Off-Broadyway space (Times Square Arts Center) in Midtown Manhattan has expressed interest. Our spot has already been guaranteed. The $8,500 we are seeking will pay the start-up capital necessary to secure that spot, and initial run. After that, the Encounter becomes self-sustaining, with profits from the show funding future runs as well as providing pay for the cast.

WHAT IS PHANTASM

Phantasm is the evolution of immersive theatre. With Phantasm, the line between theater and reality blurs even further, inserting you into the characters' lives, and ultimately, into their stories.
Our show lets you wander through the evening freely (an after-party at a 1924 speak-easy), interacting with characters as you see fit.
Guests have the unique opportunity to form personal relationships with the characters. Each person's relationship with a character will influence what they are told... and what they will see.
The Encounter is an uncertain mix of comedy and suspense... and often you do not know if what you will experience is funny or scary until the moment is upon you. 
Given a run at the theatre, the cast will continually rotate. Repeat visits are encouraged, because you never know who you will run into, or what they will have to share with you...
For a quick look at  what the  show is offering, visit our website:
www.phantasmnyc.wix.com/phantasmnyc
(A sleeker web domain is one of the things your contributions will get us)

PHANTASM'S AFFORDABILITY

What makes Phantasm truly an experience is the affordability. We plan on setting the price for tickets somewhere between $40-$50. This puts it at exactly half of the next-cheapest immersive theatre experience, and well below the price of ANY other Broadway show.


What We Need & What You Get

With the show largely complete, your contributions will go directly to securing our spot at "The Times Square Arts Center", in the heart of Midtown Manhattan. 100% of your contributions will fund the start-up capital needed to get us a run at this prestigious theater in New York City. Should we hit our goal, we will be joining the ranks of other such beloved shows as "Silence!" and the currently running "50 Shades Musical".
Our spot has already been guaranteed. The $8,500 we are seeking will pay the start-up capital necessary to pay for that spot. After the initial start-up capital, the Encounter becomes self-sustaining, with profits from the show funding future runs as well as paying the cat

---------------------------

In closing, my group has been creating and performing for almost a decade. Having hosted, run, and performed in improv and comedy shows throughout NYC, and having worked closely at New York City's "Sleep No More", I can say with authority that there is a rabid audience for this type of theatre.

I leave you with the following quote from Walt Disney, a personal hero of mine. A quote that encapsulates what we here at "Phantasm" are trying to achieve:

"Get a good idea, and stay with it. Dog it, and work at it until it's done, and done right."

Thank you in advance for any support that you can offer to this Encounter.

story:
Writer/Actor/Producer Ann Starbuck and Producer Julie Lawrence are raising funds to produce Ann's amazing play, Tiananmen Annie, directed by Richard Embardo. Ann has written and stars in this true, one-woman show depicting the hilarious and heartbreaking tale of her year in China as she searches for her Chinese soul and gets swept up in the Tiananmen Square Uprising.

She's at first a student, struggling to learn the customs as a young woman in a foreign land, but her reality is turned upside down when she is hired by CNN to be an interpreter during the Tiananmen Square Uprising.  Ann tells the story of China on the brink of change from the voice of an old woman with bound feet to a heroic hunger striker.

Today in China there is an entire generation in the dark about the events of June 4, 1989 - it is forbidden to discuss. With the current uprisings in Venezula & Kiev and harkening to the Arab Spring,  TIANANMEN ANNIE is as poignant a story today as it was 25 years ago. 

Most people have seen this picture of the unknown "Tank Man" standing in front of some tanks in protest:

But what most people don't realize is that he wasn't just stopping a few tanks. Below is an amazing picture by Stuart Franklin showing a much wider shot and the full impact of what Tank Man (tiny image on bottom left) was really blocking. 


Your contribution will help build a simple set, rent the Hudson Guild theater for 12 performances and bring this amazing story to life!

Showtimes are: 

Mondays, June 2nd, 9th, 16th, 23rd, 30th at 8pm

Friday, June 6 at 8pm

Saturday, June 7 at 3pm

Sundays, June 8th, 15th, 29th at 7pm

Thursday, June 12 at 8pm

Wednesday, June 18 at 8pm

Tickets are available now at www.plays411.com/tiananmenannie or call the box office at 323-960-7780

As you can see to the right, there are several perk options! We would love for you to be able to experience the show but if you can not and would still like to support it, you will be able to do so by clicking on the "Give What you Can," "Special Thanks," or "Program Advertisement" options.

Also, keep an eye out for Q&As after the show!  Dates TBD...

A note about our Director! - Director Richard Embardo graduated from USC Cinema School with a BFA in Drama. He has worked as an actor, writer and director in film, television and theater in Los Angeles for the last twenty-five years. His directing credits include "The World of Mirth" (multiple Dramalogue winner), "Tracers" (LA Weekly Pick of the Week) and Shakespeare's "Henry V" amongst many others. In the Solo genre, he has directed critically acclaimed productions of "Miles from Myself" (LA Weekly Pick of the Week) "Carnival Knowledge" (Edinburgh Fringe Festival) "Growing Up with Uncle Milty," "Bully for Me" and "If Christ is the Answer, What's the Question?" Currently he teaches playwriting for the solo performer and is a freelance writer in Los Angeles.

The TIANANMEN SQUARE UPRISING:

The Tiananmen Square protests of 1989, commonly known as the June Fourth Incident (六四事件) or more accurate language as '89 Democracy Movement (八九民运) in Chinese, were student-led popular demonstrations in Beijing which took place in the spring of 1989 and received broad support from city residents, exposing deep splits within China’s political leadership. Hardline leaders who ordered the military to enforce martial law in the country’s capital forcibly suppressed the protests. The crackdown that initiated on June 3–4 became known as the Tiananmen Square Massacre or the June 4 Massacre as troops with assault rifles and tanks inflicted casualties on unarmed civilians trying to block the military's advance towards Tiananmen Square in the heart of Beijing, which student demonstrators had occupied for seven weeks. The scale of military mobilization and the resulting bloodshed were unprecedented in the history of Beijing, a city with a rich tradition of popular protests in the 20th century.

The Chinese government condemned the protests as a “counter-revolutionary riot”, and has prohibited all forms of discussion or remembrance of the events since. Due to the lack of information from China, many aspects of the events remain unknown in China even today.

The protests were triggered in April 1989 by the death of former Communist Party General Secretary, Hu Yaobang, a liberal reformer, who was deposed after losing a power struggle with hardliners over the direction of political and economic reform. University students who marched and gathered in Tiananmen Square to mourn Hu also voiced grievances against inflation, limited career prospects, and corruption of the party elite. They called for government accountability, freedom of the press, freedom of speech, and the restoration of workers' control over industry. At the height of the protests, about a million people assembled in the Tiananmen Square.

The government initially took a conciliatory stance toward the protesters. The student-led hunger strike galvanized support for the demonstrators around the country and the protests spread to 400 cities by mid-May. Ultimately, China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping and other party elders resolved to use force. Party authorities declared martial law on May 20, and mobilized as many as 300,000 troops to Beijing.

In the aftermath of the crackdown, the government conducted widespread arrests of protesters and their supporters, cracked down on other protests around China, expelled foreign journalists and strictly controlled coverage of the events in the domestic press. The police and internal security forces were strengthened. Officials deemed sympathetic to the protests were demoted or purged. Zhao Ziyang was ousted in a party leadership reshuffle and replaced with Jiang Zemin.  The Chinese government was widely condemned internationally for the use of force against the protesters. Western governments imposed economic sanctions and arms embargoes.

story:
Dear Family and Friends,

As many of you know I am currently in the process of obtaining my PhD in Dance Studies from Temple University. My intended dissertation topic will center on the intersections between cognitive disability and dance in both theatrical performance (the politics surrounding the employment of cognitively disabled dancers and actors in stage productions) and the performance of everyday life (living and moving as a cognitively disabled individual in US society). The inspiration behind this research comes from my dance education and the education I received from my younger brother Anthonie, a 16 year old on the Autism Spectrum. In the spring of 2014 I began a project with Anthonie that attempted to answer the questions associated with the latter half of my dissertation. For the insights and results obtained, please see the video attached to this campaign!

In order to continue investigating this work and possibly extend the research to other individuals on the Spectrum, I want to become certified in Autism Movement Therapy. Though my current academic plate is very full, this certification is no offered as a part of my PhD or Fellowship. Therefore, I need to find outside funding to enroll in the certification workshop. This is where you come in! 

Do you want to help fund my research so that it can reach many individuals, or would you rather hear me gripe about the pitfalls of academic funding at every family gathering for the next three years? The choice is yours! Though my goal is $700 (the full cost of the program), I am launching this campaign to offset the cost of tuition, so any amount you can contribute will be appreciated. If you give a little, we all can do quite a lot!! Please consider contributing. No amount is too small. I look forward to sharing more of my work with you!

Thank you!!!

story:
Our Stretch Goal

Thank you all for helping us reach our fundraising goal for the SoLow Fest show "Ask a Sex Abuse Survivor". We are now trying for a stretch goal of $400 more, so we can afford some rehearsal time in the space before the date of the performances. Please read our story below and donate and share at http://goo.gl/0BdQhY.

No More Silence

Too many survivors of childhood sexual abuse live their lives in terrified silence, afraid what the world might think of them if they spoke up. Abusers are protected by the displaced shame of the ones they have abused. This interactive theatrical show is intended to be a platform, a safe place for survivors to stand up and speak up.

A Unique Approach

"Ask a Sex Abuse Survivor" takes a unique approach to fostering an open and productive discussion on the issues surrounding childhood sexual abuse. Storyteller Michael Broussard will share his experiences as a sexual abuse survivor and encourage audience members to chime in with their questions, comments, reflections--and their own stories.

For Survivors and their Friends and Families

Whether you are a survivor yourself, a friend or family member of a survivor, or simply someone who wants to better understand what it means to live every day with memories of abuse, you will be welcomed with open arms.

"Ask a Sex Abuse Survivor" is part of SoLow Fest

"Ask a Sex Abuse Survivor" is being staged this June as part of the Philadelphia SoLow Fest, a unique festival dedicated to new, experimental work focusing on solo performance.

Your donations go to:

  • Theater Rental
  • Tech Staff
  • Tech Equipment
  • Production Staff
  • Promo Material Printing and Promotion
  • And all the little things that go into putting on a show.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • USE THE SHARE TOOLS above to spread the word about our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Google+ and everywhere possible.
  • Ask your friends and family to make a donation.
  • Post about the show on Facebook, Twitter, Google+ etc. Help get the word out.
  • If you live in the Philadelphia area, come see the show.

Visit the Website

  • Visit the website link below and spread the word about the show to everyone you know.

story:
Felicitas is a sponsored project of Artistic New Directions, a non-profit arts organization. Contributions for the purposes of Felicitas must be made payable to Artistic New Directions and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The Project

Felicitas is a one-woman + one-musician multimedia show portraying the life of my great aunt Lizi, a tough-love Austrian baby nurse. It all began when Gary Austin suggested I write a one-woman show about my grandmother, actress Lilia Skala. In his workshop Lilia! was born. Years later at a performance, a patron suggested I write a show about Lilia's sister, the baby nurse who'd nursed her son 50 years earlier.

I dismissed the idea, thinking Lilia! was my one-hit wonder. I had no stories of Lizi. She'd been the nurse in attendance at my home birth, but she was a private person devoted to her practice. How was that stage-worthy?

Instead, I wrote a show about Lilia and Lizi's middle sister Lisl, an award-winning dance therapy pioneer (A Time to Dance). One day, a colleague said, "You've got two shows about two sisters. But there were three. You need a third show about the third sister."

I finally agreed to embark on the unknown. When my dad, a former journalist and people-person, heard about the project, he began tracking down mothers who'd used Lizi as their nurse. After a few interviews, I discovered that her life is not only stage-worthy, but has significance in its historical context and in the impact it made on society.

In the meantime, I married musician Steven May and wanted to collaborate with him on a project. In our living room, we improvised together Lizi's story with his mandolin music. Insightful colleagues gave us feedback and direction. Our first incarnation of Felicitas was well-received at The One-Woman Standing Festival.

Next, we applied to the New York Fringe Festival as a multimedia production and got in! We enlisted the talents of video designer Stephen Stevo Arnoczy and director Janice L. Goldberg (Artistic Co-director of Artistic New Directions). Artistic New Directions agreed to produce and provide us with box office staff, a lighting designer, man-power and advisory support, for which we are grateful!

Producing at The Fringe is expensive. Should we sell out every performance, only 50% of our production costs will be covered. Your contribution will make a huge difference in defraying the expenses coming out of our pockets. It will give us an enormous boost both financially and morally.

Our budget is based on our expense commitments thus far, including:

  • Festival application and participation fees
  • Director's union fees
  • Stage manager and video designer fees
  • Postcard printing, mailing and distribution costs
  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Program printing
  • Press release distribution
We expect that a positive response at The Fringe Festival will launch the show and lead to future performances.  Please check out the fun perks and benefits you'll receive for any contribution you make, Then help us out by making a donation  or sharing our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools, social media, email etc. Also, please come to see Felicitas - we are so grateful for your support!
story_txt:
Felicitas is a sponsored project of Artistic New Directions,
 a non-profit arts organization. Contributions for the purposes 
of Felicitas must be made payable to Artistic New Directions and are 
tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.The Project

Felicitas is a one-woman + one-musician multimedia show portraying the life of my great aunt Lizi, a tough-love Austrian baby nurse. It all began when Gary Austin suggested I write a one-woman show about my grandmother, actress Lilia Skala. In his workshop Lilia! was born. Years later at a performance, a patron suggested I write a show about Lilia's sister, the baby nurse who'd nursed her son 50 years earlier.I dismissed the idea, thinking Lilia! was my one-hit wonder. I had no stories of Lizi. She'd been the nurse in attendance at my home birth, but she was a private person devoted to her practice. How was that stage-worthy?
Instead, I wrote a show about Lilia and Lizi's middle sister Lisl, an award-winning dance therapy pioneer (A Time to Dance). One day, a colleague said, "You've got two shows about two sisters. But there were three. You need a third show about the third sister." 
I finally agreed to embark on the unknown. When my dad, a former journalist and people-person, heard about the project, he began tracking down mothers who'd used Lizi as their nurse. After a few interviews, I discovered that her life is not only stage-worthy, but has significance in its historical context and in the impact it made on society.
In the meantime, I married musician Steven May and wanted to collaborate with him on a project. In our living room, we improvised together Lizi's story with his mandolin music. Insightful colleagues gave us feedback and direction. Our first incarnation of Felicitas was well-received at The One-Woman Standing Festival.
Next, we applied to the New York Fringe Festival as a multimedia production and got in! We enlisted the talents of video designer Stephen Stevo Arnoczy and director Janice L. Goldberg (Artistic Co-director of Artistic New Directions). Artistic New Directions agreed to produce and provide us with box office staff, a lighting designer, man-power and 
advisory support, for which we are grateful! 
Producing at The Fringe is expensive. Should we sell out every performance, only 50% of our production costs will be covered. Your contribution will make a huge difference in defraying the expenses coming out of our pockets. It will give us an enormous boost both financially and morally.
Our budget is based on our expense commitments thus far, including:

Festival application and participation fees
Director's union fees
Stage manager and video designer fees
Postcard printing, mailing and distribution costs
Rehearsal space rental
Program printing
Press release distribution 

We expect that a positive response at The Fringe Festival will launch the show and lead to future performances.  Please check out the fun perks and benefits you'll receive for any contribution you make, Then help us out by making a donation  or sharing our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools, social media, email etc. Also, please come to see Felicitas - we are so grateful for your support!

story:
STRETCH GOALS:

1) $8,500: BLING! - ACHIEVED! 

Reaching $8,500 will pay for sparkly bits that will make our costumes more visible from far away, and beautifully shiny in the spotlights. Swarovski crystal details aren't cheap, but their visual impact is tremendous and they are a staple element of traditional circus costumes for this very reason.

2) $11,500 SUPERIOR MASTERING! - ACHIEVED!

Professional mastering for the score so the music sounds as good recorded and played back over theater speakers as it did live in the studio. We're writing it, we're recording it, lets make it sound as fantastic as it deserves. Reaching this goal means all of you backers who have a download of the album just got an upgrade in your reward.

3) $14,000 MORE MUSICIANS!

We would like to hire a chorus and even more string musicians, to really give the score for Hinge a full and dramatic sound. Synthetic instruments are nothing compared to the real thing. Help us employ more professional artists, and make this album everything it can be.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Circus is coming to town!

  • My name is Bunny Holmes [Zlotnik] and for the past five years I've been putting on shows locally in the Bay Area, and touring each summer to visit places like Washington, Oregon, Arizona, Texas, and Louisiana with my small and very magical circus troupe, The Vespertine Circus.

  • So far, our production value has been stifled by the fact that we are funding our shows exclusively with ticket-sales. We've cobbled together costumes from thrift-store garments and scavenged for props and set pieces, but we are ready to build a show as beautiful as our dreams are. We aim to improve the spectacle and visual-impact of our shows, without raising the price of admission. 
  • In this spirit, we've joined forces with our nonprofit sponsor, Fractured Atlas, while we undergo the transformation into a 501c3 non-profit organisation ourselves - so we can bring high quality circus-theater performances to audiences all over the USA who could not typically afford to see these arts in person.

What We Need

This campaign has two goals:

  • Creating elaborate, beautiful costumes for our six actors. This will cost $3,000 and is no small feat. They need to both beautiful and strong because they will be worn for hundreds of acrobatic performances. We are working with Gibbous Fashions and Subverse Industries for costume-construction, and no detail will be left un-noticed. These garments will be as whimsical and dreamy up close as they are from 100ft away, and will be sure to leave a strong impression on many an imagination.
  •  Composing & recording a score for our two-hour long production [Hinge], of unique music designed to create an aural landscape in which the show takes place. Music which follows and supports the emotional arc and story being told by the performers. Jesse Buddington and A. Lowe are working together to write the songs, and once they are composed we will be collaborating with local musicians (Unwoman, Ian M Dawson, and Shaly Borgen, to name a few) to record it. To start this process, we have budgeted a modest $3,000. The album will be available online for digital purchase, and an early-release download of it will be available to backers at a certain level. 
Involving this many artists in our show is a reward unto itself, as it's a chance for our small company to join forces with other creatives and build something magnificent. These elements will be key parts of countless performances, moving forward, and last us for many years.


  • The remaining portion of our goal $ here is for fulfilling backer rewards & processing fees. Of course, $3,000 isn't very much for top quality costumes for an entire cast, nor is it a lot of money to make a soundtrack with - it's the bare minimum in our case, and we hope to continue to raise more money above and beyond our initial goals so we're able to further improve the quality, and involve more artists. Every cent earned on this campaign will go directly into making Hinge more wonderful.

Rewards for Roustabouts (YOU!)

  • A download of the soundtrack as soon as it's recorded! Take a listen to the album you helped create! Approximately an hour of music that blends Renaissance-style melodies with hip-hop rhythmic structures. Cello, violin, guitar, bass, mandolin, banjo & a choir. Instead of traditional drums, we will use foley for the bulk of of our percussion, mixing the sounds of nature with industrial & urban soundscapes.
  • We will be screen-printing and distributing backers-only ROUSTABOUT T-shirts (may we call you wonderful people our roustabouts? Truly, those are the laborers who raise the Big Top tent and make the circus possible, and I daresay it's a fitting title for you, who are enabling our show right now.) Below is a design preview - we may change it to incorporate the word ROUSTABOUT if backers prefer, but felt "tent crew" was more clear, tell us what you think!

  • Private & semi-private classes in circus skills as rewards, for all you who like the idea of The Vespertine Circus so much you want to run away with a circus yourself!
  • NEW: good-for-any show (single use) pairs of tickets. Yep. They'll never expire, catch us in any town we visit, and bring a date! Limited to 30 backers.
  • NEW: Orthrus Festival Belt (pictured bellow), for one very fashionable roustabout. Crafted with love by our costume designers from Subverse Industries. Made from premium leather and hardware in Santa Cruz, CA this belt features two small pockets (able to accommodate most phones and point-and-shoot cameras) *Adjustable from 31" to 39"

     

  • NEW: Bundles of private lessons! When one simply isn't enough. Take up spinning on the cyr wheel, or flying with aerial fabrics. Take a look at the column to the right for details!
  • NEW: Cast party! You know who throws a good party? The Circus does, that's who. Come play twister with acrobats, lounge in our ball-pit, enjoy delicious & expertly-crafted beverages, and join us for a truly unforgettable night.
  • NEW: Bring the circus to you! Either a solo-performer (aerial fabrics? Trapeze? Cyr-wheel? Fire-dancing? We've got you covered!) - Or have the ENTIRE TROUPE at your event. *Please plot & plan the coordinates and date with us well in advance so we can be sure the location allows for our acts, we can get a copy of our insurance to you, and all that jazz.  Not all venues are possible, but we can work our magic both indoors and outdoors, and will bring our professional event photographer along for the ride - so there will be plenty of photos of you with the cast (and the rest of your party, too.) When it comes to entertainment, you can't beat having your very own circus.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We are determined to make this show happen. We are in the process of applying for grants, seeking corporate sponsorship, and plan on holding multiple fundraisers for the development of Hinge. What we need to do, is get the ball rolling. So we're passing the hat, and asking you - our friends, our family, our most devoted fans and fellow mischief makers, if you'll help us get this project underway. We can't wait to share it with you.

The Impact of Community Funding

With your help we will reach people who have never seen anything like this and make an impression on the next generation of artists.

  • Three years ago, we lead a community funding campaign, which succeeded and enabled us to purchase our free-standing-aerial rig; since that time this rig has been used to bring the circus to more cities than we can count. Now we're prepared for a more ambitious goal, with even more spectacular outcomes.
  • We've already written, rehearsed and performed 15 original 90 minute shows, and gone on three tours. Each one of these shows has combined narrative theater style storytelling with both classical and contemporary circus disciplines. With our 16th show, we'd like to really transform the scale of production and see if we can keep it on the road for years to come. Join us in our effort.
  • If this crowd-funding campaign is a success, it will help us prove to those companies & organisations who we are approaching for funding the larger parts of our project (the set, a tour bus, circus equipment) that we're serious and worth their consideration. 

Ways you can help:

Because a world with more circus is a better world.

  • Work an hour for the circus? Consider donating an amount equal to one hour at your workplace; donations here are tax-deductible to the fullest extent permissible by law, so you'll get credit for your hard labor.
  • If you can't afford to help with your money, help with your influence and spread the word about our project. Email, tweet, Facebook, blog-away! The more people see us, the more likely we are to meet our goal, it's that simple. Thank you!

[Top photo: Darren Keith. All other photos: Terri Brindisi.]


Deepest gratitude to all of our supporters - 

Sincerely,

Bunny Holmes, Elijah Leone, Danielle Funkadelica, SAM Luckey, Keely Beyries, Brian Feraru, and Terri Brindisi - in collaboration with Selene Ahnese, Arianna Feldman, Trevor Tarin, Erica Mulkey, Matt Diamant, Shaly Borgen, Jesse Buddington, Ian Dawson, and Andrew Lowe.

story:
Who We Are...

The Furies Circus is a Los Angeles based performance group dedicated to exploring the art of movement, defying gravity, and playing with fire. The Furies aim to excite, seduce, and surprise with the power of raw, urban, female elegance. 

"We are a fun-loving, adventurous group brought together through our love for each other and all forms of movement. We want to continue growing together and expanding our creations, knowledge, and passions to share with a broader audience. We raised some funds from our last event, but it is not enough and we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise at least $3000.00 to grow our group. This money will help us:

Travel to and Perform at Lucidity Festival! - We are accepted to perform at Lucidity Festival(a music, arts, and healing festival in Santa Barbara) in April and need funding to help us pay for studio rental space, costumes, and production/travel costs.

Update our training rig- We must ensure the safety of our members and community as we continue to create and teach classes.

Update our aerial equipment- To continue to create and train safely 

Free Standing Portable Rig- This specific rig will allow us to take our shows and workshops around the world! 

Other Ways You Can Help..

Please spread the word and blast our link on your social media so we continue to reach more fabulous friends and family who are able to help our company's dreams come true! 

Thank You Again and Again!

The FURIES

story:
Short Summary

Gaston LeRoux's novel Le Fantôme de l'Opéra was an early pioneer of the noir and suspense genre. In Red Death, The Runaways tackle this classic text from the perspective of an obsessed inspector who reopens the case of Christine Daae, the Chagney brothers, and the mysterious opera ghost.

The Runaways Lab Theatre has had a remarkable few months. We have new company members, new shows and won BEST NEW THEATRE in the Chicago Reader! The successes of our previous shows could not have happened without your support. We want to thank you now, and with our upcoming event the Masquerrager!

*Sketches by Mikaila Von Merr


Our Goals 

$2,700 for The Chopin Theatre

$500 for Rehearsal Space

$1,500 for Costumes/Makeup/Hair

$200 for Props & Set

$300 for Costume Designer

$300 for Graphic Design Work

$800 for Marketing

$700 for Actors 

Total = $7,000

Your contributions help us make our goal. In gratitude of your support we have levels of sponsorship that can provide you with your name in the program, a mask, or a drink named in your honor. 


    Cast & Crew

    Director/Playwright: Olivia Lilley 
    Costume Designer: Mikaila Von Merr
    Sound Designer: Gannon Reedy 
    Fight Choreographer: Christoph Ziegler
    Stage Manager: Ann Kreitman
    The Inspector: Gannon Reedy
    The Persian: Kelly Jean Graham
    Erik/The Phantom: Nathaniel Shaine
    Christine Daae: Hope Barnes
    Raoul de Chagney: Gary Henderson
    Carlotte: Leah Generous
    Madame Giry: Erin Morrill
    Joseph Buquet: Nyle Kenning
    Richard/Moncharmin: Roy Rainey
    Little Jammes: Maggie Vaughn
    Meg Giry: Shaina Schrooten

    Conclusion

    Its been an exciting year for The Runaways Lab Theatre. We gained seven new company members and secured The Chopin Theatre, all of which we could not have done without your support.  If you have donated before: thank you. If this is your first time: welcome, we hope to see you around.

    If you have any questions about our project please feel free to email us at twentypens.orl@gmail.com or follow us on facebook at https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Runaways-Lab...

story:
GOOD NEWS! We have been granted an extension on the campaign! Thanks to all who have donated and to all who will now have the change. We are almost there!!!!


DNAWORKS, in collaboration with Teatro Paraguas

and Associate Producers Nicholas Ballas, Estevan Rael-Gálvez and Juan Rios, Diane Karp, Lisa Samuel and Les Samuel, and Roxanne Swentzell

presents:


The World Premiere of

CASCARONES 

by Irma Mayorga


Directed by: Daniel Banks

Produced by: Vanessa Pike-Vrtiak

With: Nicholas Ballas, Nicole Gramlich, Jonathan Harrell, Marcos Kelly, Roger Montoya, Bernadette Peña and Cristina Vigil.

PERFORMANCES: September 4, 5, 6, 11, 12, & 13, 2014 at 7pm; 7 & 14 at 5pm.

At Teatro Paraguas, 3205 Calle Marie, Santa Fe, NM 87507


We need your support!


About the play:

Cascarones takes place in San Antonio, Texas, as teenager Mary Margaret Caceres, who works for the transit authority giving people bus route directions, attempts to understand the mapping of her community and city. As she navigates the daily challenges her working class family faces, she encounters in a dreamlike state John Wesley Powell, Francisco Vásquez de Coronado, and the other men whose actions in the past influence her present.


A Note from the Director:

In February, we presented a staged reading of Cascarones at Teatro Paraguas. During the post-show community dialogue, an audience member remarked, “This is just the kind of theatre Santa Fe needs to bridge divides in our community.” 

Cascarones is a beautiful and moving play and we have assembled a phenomenally talented cast of local actors.  DNAWORKS' mission is to present work that bring people closer together through art and dialogue, and Cascarones does just this.  Although set in Texas, the play elegantly and courageously addresses some of the very cultural, historic, and economic challenges faced in New Mexico. The plurality of Santa Fe is represented onstage in a beautiful story about the intersections of family and history. I have carried this play around with me for over ten years, and when I arrived in Santa Fe four years ago, I knew this was a perfect project to bring people closer together and catalyze dialogue about the very things that unite and, unfortunately, divide us.  

Although the play had the great honor of being workshopped at the O'Neill Playwrights Conference in 2003 (with America Ferrera in the lead role), it has never had a full production.  Please join us in bringing this magnificent work to life in Santa Fe.  We are already in discussion about touring to other cities and festivals in the Southwest!


Why We Need You:

Bringing the world premiere of Cascarones to Santa Fe is absolutely essential in our eyes. Santa Fe is the right place with the right community, the right culture, and the right cast for the WORLD PREMIERE!  With this committed and passionate team, we know we can create an incredible experience for audiences and give Irma's play the production which it has patiently awaited for over a decade. 

To thank you for your support we have created a number of incentives that we hope will appeal to you, even if you cannot attend the performance. But, most importantly, we want to say a heartfelt thank you to all our potential backers -- every little bit counts.


Goals and Perks

We need to raise $6500 to bring Cascarones to the stage.  This includes: 

  • Design materials costs
  • Publicity 
  • Overhead for Teatro Paraguas for 5 weeks, and 
  • A fee for each cast and crew member working on the show for the next three months.  We have over 25 people working to make this dream a reality!

In other words, everything that is needed to bring you a professional and fantastic show!  Putting a show like this together takes hundreds of hours and we are committed to paying our talented team! All funds contributed will be used directly for the production.  


Who We Are:

Please click here for information on our incredible team.  Together, we have over 500 years of experience in the theatre!


Read more about Cascarones and Irma's work on the blog for the 30/30 US Latin@/NoPassport international reading scheme, which our February staged reading was part of. Irma Mayorga talks 3030.


HUGE APPRECIATION TO OUR COMMUNITY PARTNERS!

- Santa Fe Art Institute for hosting Irma Mayorga as an Artist-in-Residence during August and part of September through their Community Partnership Initiative.

- 315 Restaurant and Wine Bar for hosting the "Dinner with Irma and Daniel" perk.
story_txt:
GOOD NEWS! We have been granted an extension on the campaign! Thanks to all who have donated and to all who will now have the change. We are almost there!!!!DNAWORKS, in collaboration with Teatro Paraguasand Associate Producers Nicholas Ballas, Estevan Rael-Gálvez and Juan Rios, Diane Karp, Lisa Samuel and Les Samuel, and Roxanne Swentzellpresents:
The World Premiere of
CASCARONES by Irma MayorgaDirected by: Daniel BanksProduced by: Vanessa Pike-VrtiakWith: Nicholas Ballas, Nicole Gramlich, Jonathan Harrell, Marcos Kelly, Roger Montoya, Bernadette Peña and Cristina Vigil.PERFORMANCES: September 4, 5, 6, 11, 12, & 13, 2014 at 7pm; 7 & 14 at 5pm.At Teatro Paraguas, 3205 Calle Marie, Santa Fe, NM 87507We need your support!About the play:Cascarones takes place in San Antonio, Texas, as teenager Mary Margaret Caceres, who works for the transit authority giving people bus route directions, attempts to understand the mapping of her community and city. As she navigates the daily challenges her working class family faces, she encounters in a dreamlike state John Wesley Powell, Francisco Vásquez de Coronado, and the other men whose actions in the past influence her present.A Note from the Director:In February, we presented a staged reading of Cascarones at Teatro Paraguas. During the post-show community dialogue, an audience member remarked, “This is just the kind of theatre Santa Fe needs to bridge divides in our community.” Cascarones is a beautiful and moving play and we have assembled a phenomenally talented cast of local actors.  DNAWORKS' mission is to present work that bring people closer together through art and dialogue, and Cascarones does just this.  Although set in Texas, the play elegantly and courageously addresses some of the very cultural, historic, and economic challenges faced in New Mexico. The plurality of Santa Fe is represented onstage in a beautiful story about the intersections of family and history. I have carried this play around with me for over ten years, and when I arrived in Santa Fe four years ago, I knew this was a perfect project to bring people closer together and catalyze dialogue about the very things that unite and, unfortunately, divide us.  Although the play had the great honor of being workshopped at the O'Neill Playwrights Conference in 2003 (with America Ferrera in the lead role), it has never had a full production.  Please join us in bringing this magnificent work to life in Santa Fe.  We are already in discussion about touring to other cities and festivals in the Southwest!Why We Need You:Bringing the world premiere of Cascarones to Santa Fe is absolutely essential in our eyes. Santa Fe is the right place with the right community, the right culture, and the right cast for the WORLD PREMIERE!  With this committed and passionate team, we know we can create an incredible experience for audiences and give Irma's play the production which it has patiently awaited for over a decade. To thank you for your support we have created a number of incentives that we hope will appeal to you, even if you cannot attend the performance. But, most importantly, we want to say a heartfelt thank you to all our potential backers -- every little bit counts.Goals and PerksWe need to raise $6500 to bring Cascarones to the stage.  This includes: 

Design materials costs


Publicity 


Overhead for Teatro Paraguas for 5 weeks, and 


A fee for each cast and crew member working on the show for the next three months.  We have over 25 people working to make this dream a reality!

In other words, everything that is needed to bring you a professional and fantastic show!  Putting a show like this together takes hundreds of hours and we are committed to paying our talented team! All funds contributed will be used directly for the production.  Who We Are:Please click here for information on our incredible team.  Together, we have over 500 years of experience in the theatre!Read more about Cascarones and Irma's work on the blog for the 30/30 US Latin@/NoPassport international reading scheme, which our February staged reading was part of. Irma Mayorga talks 3030.
HUGE APPRECIATION TO OUR COMMUNITY PARTNERS!- Santa Fe Art Institute for hosting Irma Mayorga as an Artist-in-Residence during August and part of September through their Community Partnership Initiative.- 315 Restaurant and Wine Bar for hosting the "Dinner with Irma and Daniel" perk.

story:
What is Shakespeare Company at UCLA?

Shakespeare Company at UCLA strives to bring quality classical theater to all students at UCLA of all years (including graduate students), all majors, and all levels of acting talent. We model our group on a professional theater company and therefore have a variety of roles students may fill, including director, producer, actor, designer, dramaturge, stage manager, etc. Our main goal is to cultivate a sense of appreciation for aging works that continue to speak to the human experience . 

What We Need & What You Get

Producing student theater is incredibly expensive, especially paying for quality lighting. We will use the money we earn from this campaign to pay for said lighting and for facilities costs in the space. We will use any extra money from the campaign to pay for costumes and sound equipment, our next two most expensive needs. We apply to a good deal of UCLA funding, but not nearly enough to cover all of our costs; we need your help!

Should you choose to donate to our production, you may receive any number of perks, from a poster signed by the entire cast to advertisement space in our program!

The Impact of SCU on Campus

Many of our company members have expressed gratitude to SCU for helping them create a home and family on campus. All our members come from different paths in life, yet we all come together for our love of the Bard and other classical authors. We are a young organization, but we have improved in strides this year. Our past two shows had packed houses at every performance and our production quality has seriously amped up. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to our funding campaign, never fear! There are plenty of other ways to contribute. First of all, come and see our show! One of our goals is to provide free, quality classical theater to UCLA population and the general public. If you are interested in what we do, also consider joining our group as a member.

story:
Who am I?

I was given the name Jia Xi which in chinese means perfect dawn. I am 22 and I fell in love with dancing when I was entering a hard phase of my life 10 years ago where I stopped communicating with people around me and fell prey to depression that eventually led me into a long struggle with eating disorder. I have come through stronger than ever. Dancing was the only thing that kept me connected with the world, bringing me on scholarships to Australia, Japan, New Zealand, New York, Singapore. Now I have completed my professional training and apprenticeship, I am ready to start auditioning for a full-time job as a professional dancer. IN EUROPE! 

My story

I found a voice in movement that kept who I am inside alive. Coupled with music, the magic happens, where nothing exists, but the taste of joy. That is dance to me. I am not born an artist nor am I born a dancer, but I am born to be touched by my surroundings, the people around me. I observe their movements, the emotions behind it all. I observed a little girl hopping on the transparent bridge in a shopping mall at Pavillion KL, the different paces and expression of people exercising in the cities of Wellington, Singapore, New York(central park), Kuala Lumpur and my hometown.  It is fascinating to see the rhythm in their bodies. I have a dream of becoming a dancer. And I have an even bigger dream of sharing my passion that has shaped me into someone who is curious(questions), and adventurous(take actions). A person who can now, not only speak mandarin, cantonese, malay, english, but speaks and hear body, too. I was an awkward person without friends. Dance has given me a link bridge to connect with people passionate in many other fields, football, economics, engineering, architecture, psychology, fitness, yoga. To advance in my dancing, I was forced to find what I had been missing, human connection. Any practice means nothing when it is not shared. I want to share my passion. And what is the next step for me? To get a career in dance profession, to experience the essence of the art first hand in the field of performance. And I need your help to take that one more stride forward. 

Why am I crowd funding?

I am going on an audition tour for 2014/2015 audition season in Europe. I will be needing a lot of $$$ to cover food, accommodation, travel, classes and of course FLIGHT. I have a small savings from my apprentice year in 2013 and ballet teaching of this year. My parents will also be supporting part of my expenses. The whole trip will be about 6 months. Here is a breakdown of how much reality requires:

Food $1200/month 

Accommodation $minimum, as I will be couch surfing.

Travel within Europe $500

Classes 12Euro $13/class 5 classes a week is $260 a month is $1040

Return Flight range $1600-$2018(Kayak.com)

All expenses for 6 months bare minimum will be $15540

Converted into Malaysian Ringgit is a round-up of RM50000. That is a bare minimum. My parents and I could fork up about 2/3 of the money. I need your help and generosity. To make my audition tour possible, to take that one step closer to my dream future. 

I am wishing to raise $5000 to cover my trip, mainly for flight, classes and travel around Europe for auditions. And you can help me make that impossible possible. Yes YOU!!

Progress and Experience

I have worked in two professional ballet companies in New Zealand and Singapore. The experience gave me an idea of what kind of dancer I am and a clearer idea of a company that would be the best match for who I am as a dancer. 6-month of being back in Malaysia, without attachment to a company or school, I learned to be proactive in my approach in looking for dance projects and mentors. I have the fortune to teach at City Ballet, Malaysia, where I can practice my idea of teaching with a difference, not just technique, but what it means psychologically and anatomically. In short, instead of focusing on mistakes and failures, I constantly remind the students to focus on what can be changed(body) and how we can do it better(mind). I am very passionate in sharing my own experience to others.

My Qualification

Registered Yoga Teacher 200-hour(pending) taking my exam in July 19 2014

National Diploma in Dance Performance(New Zealand School of Dance, 2012)

Certificate in Education of Malaysia, 2008(Straight-A)

How you can help me?

Every single dollar count. 

Every quarter of a hundred dollars blessed;

Every hundred dollars appreciated;

Every quarter of a thousand dollars takes me miles on the track of my dream. 

Every share of my story and campaign warms and lights up my heart.

Everyone of you that read my story, I thank you for reading, if you have the time and thought my story worth a share, I thank you again! Never give up on your dream just because of one or two obstacles. All successful leaders of history are never defeated by criticism or persecutions. Nureyev, Gandhi, Steve Jobs, Daisaku Ikeda, Rosa Parks... Why should we? 

Thank you 谢谢 Terima Kasih for your contribution, support and help to share my story. Mountains of love to you and your loved ones! 

Just click on the link below for contribution and follow the web instructions to contribute. Don't worry, it's very safe here. :)

story:
.
The Material World is a pop musical about Madonna, Britney Spears, and a family of socialist Jews in 1921. They all live together in a house in the Bronx where they study Kabbalah, plan the destruction of capitalism and occasionally break into song.
.

The Material World is the sequel to my play, You Will Experience Silence. Here’s what the Village Voice said about that one: "Fishback has a Kushnerian sense for the complexities of historical memory, and while You Will Experience Silence might not be as panoramic as Angels in America, it’s sassier and more fun…"
.

The Material World is also sassy and also fun. We’re doing a staged reading in the Dixon Place HOT! Festival on July 22nd at 7pm, and we need to raise money to pay the actors! They are STARVING! Chip in to help your comrades in the arts!
.
http://www.danfishback.com
http://www.dixonplace.org

story:
HI There

We're looking to raise funds that will help pay salaries for 26 performers in three different shows. As performers and artists often times we work for a lower amount or for free because we just love what we're doing, or because we're impassioned about a project or we do it because we could not survive without making art. I believe the artists I work with should get paid what they deserve which is why I play the lottery : ) Seeing that I haven't won the lottery yet, I am hitting the fundraising trail.

Three different shows, 26 performers, 10 crew and a total of 16 performances means a chunk of change. We’ve gotten a grant from the City Council, have had many in-kind donations like my friend David Gilmore who is designing posters and flyers for free, a $,1500 savings, or Chrissy who is costuming us, or the restaurant Southern Cross who are letting us use their space for free saving us over $1,000 in rental; these, plus other in-kind donations all add up but it doesn't cover the cost of salaries.


My goal is that all performers and crew get $100 a performance, if someone does 9 performances my hope is to pay them $900 and the people who created and directed the work need to get paid as well. All these salaries alone add up to over $22,000 and don't include rent, props, costumes, publicity et al. If we sell out every show at the top tier ticket price we will bring in $15,420 yet all budget makers for shows say you can only count on 1/3 of your tickets sales actually coming in which means we will bring in around $5,140. From that we will pay expenses first, like publicity, printing, registrations fees for the Fringe etc. and what's left over will be divided by the artists involved in windyPAE. It's slim pickings but we're doing it anyway because we believe in the work.


The work. These three shows are the inaugural productions of my new company, windyPAE (windy Performing Arts Ensemble). Our shows are funny, clever, tight, original and moving... all the things you want in a performance! Through our murder-mystery bike play, Wheels of Justice, we highlight the unbelievably great graffiti and wall art in Wellington. In TOUCHED we will be exposing Contact Improvisation with new audiences while combining the rich talents of spoken word artists, musicians, installation artists and digital artists; and THE PENIS MONOLOGUES, a solo show that takes place in a bar, addresses issues that are often left silent.


Your contribution not only says to the creators and performers in these shows that their desire to make a livelihood in the performing arts is supported, but it also sends a strong message to artists and future artists that they are wanted, needed, appreciated and valued in society. Imagine how different this world would be if we all felt wanted and valued.

Please watch our video to see your friends and family in it and learn a bit more about who we are and what we're doing. Below is what you can get if you contribute money to help us meet our goal of $8,000, and never fear, if you can't contribute you can help by spreading the word.

Cheers!

Tommy

story:
Let us tell you a short story...

While pursuing dance degrees at the University of Oregon's School of Music and Dance, eight dance students crossed paths and passions in Eugene, Oregon.  Celebrating friendships and artistic partnerships, we desired continued opportunities to learn, create, and share together.  Working as a collective that honors each contributor, we strive to practice our craft through educational and artful community exchange.   

TRANSForm is a collective of dance artists that extends across cultural and geographic boundaries.  Founders Alexandra Taylor (New York), Marcie Mamura (Chicago), Valerie Ifill (Charlotte), A.T. Moffett (St. Paul), Carrie Goodnight (Seattle), Amanda Herman Records (Seattle), and Gina and Kyle Sorensen (San Diego) delve into cross-country collaboration to open contemporary discourses on and through the art of dance.  

TRANSForm builds on a foundation of shared experiences with collective investment in new intersections, presenting contemporary dance work and creating opportunities to engage with dance communities across the country.  TRANSForm dance collective is wildly curious about the TRANSfer of ideas in the process of exchange, TRANSgressing old models and standards of performance, and the TRANSpiring possibilities of dance-making within a community of artists. 

What's happening?

For our 3rd Annual Dance Concert + Teaching Residency, TRANSForm presents On the Subject of Together at The James Sewell Ballet TEK BOX at The Cowles Center in Minneapolis, MN on March 15th-16th, 2013.  Already an exciting event, this is also the first time in our three years of producing that each and every collective member will be in attendance!

As with each residency, we're incredibly grateful for the opportunity to connect and collaborate with the Minneapolis/St. Paul dance community.  This year some of the choreographers are also extending an invitation to those dancers who participate in our classes the chance to perform in our show with us!

Last year, TRANSForm successfully held their 2nd Annual Concert in Charlotte, NC at Carolina Actors Studio Theater with teaching residencies at both Johnson C. Smith and Winthrop Univerisities.  Students from both schools were included as performers and technical crew.  In 2011, TRANSForm traveled to San Diego, CA at Southwestern College where over 200 patrons attended the two-night performance.  We also held a week-long teaching residency at local studio, Academy of Performing Arts, where we taught over 50 students. 

How can you help?

To make On the Subject of Together happen, we are raising funds for:

  • Two-Night Venue Rental at The James Sewell Ballet TEK BOX at The Cowles Center
  • Event Insurance
  • Technical Assistance - Management + Stage Crew
  • Promotional Materials - Posters + Programs
  • Photographer + Videographer
  • Air Travel, Gas, and Hotel Costs

ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX-DEDUCTIBLE! (see below for details) 

A donation of any size is greatly appreciated and it will directly support the production and success of our 3rd TRANSForm Dance Concert + Teaching Residency. 

 

If you are unable to donate, you can still help us!

  • Share our campaign with people you know!
  • Recommend TRANSForm Dance Collective to your friends on Facebook here: facebook.com/TRANSFormDanceCollective
  • Come join us at The James Sewell Ballet TEK BOX at The Cowles Center on March 15th-16th and take class with us from 10-4pm then come back later that evening for our performance! You can buy tickets at brownpapertickets.com
  • Visit our website at TRANSFormDanceCollective.

 

 

*Alexandra Taylor Dance is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Alexandra Taylor Dance must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. The value of the Thank You cards is $3. The value of the Concert DVD is $5. Any contribution above that amount is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Promotional Materials - Posters + Programs
Photographer + Videographer
Air Travel, Gas, and Hotel Costs

ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX-DEDUCTIBLE! (see below for details) 
A donation of any size is greatly appreciated and it will directly support the production and success of our 3rd TRANSForm Dance Concert + Teaching Residency. 
 
If you are unable to donate, you can still help us!

Share our campaign with people you know!
Recommend TRANSForm Dance Collective to your friends on Facebook here: facebook.com/TRANSFormDanceCollective

Come join us at The James Sewell Ballet TEK BOX at The Cowles Center on March 15th-16th and take class with us from 10-4pm then come back later that evening for our performance! You can buy tickets at brownpapertickets.com

Visit our website at TRANSFormDanceCollective.

 
 


*Alexandra Taylor Dance is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Alexandra Taylor Dance must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. The value of the Thank You cards is $3. The value of the Concert DVD is $5. Any contribution above that amount is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Who we are and what we do:

FrenetiCore is a non-profit organization that offers creative community experiences to the public through the presentation and promotion of original theater, dance, film, and music in Houston, Texas.  In addition to maintaining a dance company that presents daring and innovative works, the organization also produces the Houston Fringe Festival, offers weekly dance classes for both children and adults, promotes local artists through an Artist in Residence program and Artist Board, and offers affordable theater rentals.

The Sacred Harp, a multimedia dance theater production about the journey of a young interracial couple, was originally performed in 2004 is being reprised in honor of FrenetiCore's 10 year anniversary. On April 19 at Miller Outdoor Theatre, FrenetiCore will present this free, family-friendly performance that tackles issues of morality with a message of tolerance and acceptance.  

The Sacred Harp is set in an early 20th century, small Southern town divided by race but united by faith.  At the center of the story is a young couple, deep in love, but with one controversial problem: he is black and she is white.  An uprising begins when the townspeople discover the couple’s relationship and an evil traveling preacher places a spell over the town causing them to commit a terrible injustice against the couple.  The town’s trusted preacher regains hold of his congregation, but not before lives are lost.  In the end, the townspeople find redemption in societal change and finally come together in hope.  

The Sacred Harp is told through contemporary ballet, modern and American folk dance, along with historical shape-note music and narrative film while portraying the journey of Southern society from oppression and prejudice to tolerance and acceptance.

Featuring choreography by Rebecca French, film and costumes by Ashley Horn and lighting design by Kris Phelps.

Performers include Shanon Adams, Kira Boerkircher, Adam Castaneda, Dorianne Castillo, Taylor Coon, Makeda Easter, Rebecca French, Jaime Fruge, Carlos Guzman, Erica Henderson, Ashley Horn, Mallory Horn, Lauren Hurstell, Naana Jefferson, LaShanna Leonard, Aileen Mapes, Mollie Miller, Drew Peerless, James Pitre, Varina Rush, Denzel Taylor and Ruben Trevino.

What We Need & What You Get

To bring this relevant and powerful story to life requires a large cast and crew. With over twenty performers, plus a lighting designer, choreographer, costume designer, administrative staff and more The Sacred Harp is a large undertaking both in effort and in dollars. We will not receive any ticket revenue to help fund performer fees. All performances at Miller Outdoor Theatre are free to the public, supporting the notion that art is for all! We are so proud to be a part of that mission!

Your donation will help to offset the lack of ticket revenue FrenetiCore would normally receive for a performance. Donations will go directly to help pay the artists involved in the project for their time, effort and artistry.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every contribution helps. And so does sharing the event with friends and family. Please help us spread the word via Facebook, Twitter, email, actual conversation and whatever else you've got! The staff, cast and crew thanks you!

story:
Short Summary

Accidentally On Purpose Productions is a new self funded theatre company set up by students from Loughborough University. 

The companies key aim is to produce exciting and innovative theatre giving students of all ages a place to apply their skills whether that be acting or backstage.

This year we will taking on the Edinburgh Fringe Festival with a two week run of Jim Cartwright's Road. A gritty page set in 1987 which tells the stories of the inhabitants of a Lancaster street. Guided by Scullery we dip in and out of their lives exploring their struggles and stories. We are performing for two weeks right in the centre of the action. We will be performing at Greenside Venue just of Prince's Street. For information on the Venue please follow the link to the webpage http://www.greensidevenue.co.uk. We are performing in the last two weeks of the festival from the 12th-17th of August performing at 12.35 then from the 17th-24th of August at 13.45.

All the money we make from this campaign will go straight towards the development of this project. All the team have worked so hard in Loughborough for the last six months and we need as much funding as possible to enable us to be successfull. 

We hope you have enjoyed our words and remeber to check out our very exciting perks for pledgeing...(like everything in Accidentally On Purpose Productions there is cake)

Thank you for taking time to check out out page. Lots and lots of love from everyone at Accicentally On Purpose :)

story:
Why we wrote a musical

As music industry and musical theatre professionals with over 70 years' experience in the team, we felt a little disillusioned that theatres all over the world are being filled with 'jukebox' musicals. These are musicals loosely based around a collection of pre-existing pop songs, sometimes with only the flimsiest pretext of a story to thread them together.

These shows can be great — Mamma Mia, We Will Rock You, and so on — but surely there should be room for musicals where the music only exists because it is helping in the telling of a great story; in developing characters about whom we care. Characters we laugh with, cry with; people we fear for, who we cheer for as they overcome their struggles in life.

And so we selected a cracking story — Ivanhoe, by Sir Walter Scott — and added an interesting new twist to make it even more appealing to today's audiences.

All the music is specially composed and orchestrated by a team who have been involved in many blockbuster shows and productions over the years.

A brand new show on a classic theme

We're getting ready to take it to producers and theatres around the world, and we need some help with the launch phase. We are:

  • Mike Sheppard [composer/lyricist], 
  • Phil Edwards [composer/lyricist], and 
  • Will Hammond [playwright]

We have worked hard on this show for almost three years and now it's ready to be shown to the world.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise $15,000 to fund a website and the promotional campaign to make producers aware of the show.
  • Contributors will receive a range of goodies, including signed CDs, signed copies of the script, invitations to the rehearsals and, of course, those all-important opening night tickets.

The Impact

Your contribution will enable us to create a website and start building a community of fans; it will also help us to promote the finished show to producers around the world:

  • This is a brand new musical loosely based on an updated version of Sir Walter Scott's classic tale of medieval knights and damsels in distress.
  • We are industry professionals with solid track records in theatre and tv.
  • This show has been our passion for the last two years — we have poured over 30 years' experience into the making of it, and we're really excited by its potential.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, there are other important ways in which you can help help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about Ivanhoe, and about this Indiegogo campaign in particular.
  • use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out!

story:
Short Summary

"Woman Before a Glass" is an amazing one woman show about the outrageous, courageous life of Peggy Guggenheim.  With an unfailing eye for great art, Peggy lived through some of the most tumultuous events of the 20th century.

Genesis Theatrical Productions presents powerful premieres that empower and educate through dynamic theatrical works.  

This play is the first in our series called Athena's Wisdom, empowering women through theater.  We are planning a two week run in mid January, 2014 at The National Pastime Theater at the Preston Bradley Center, 941 W. Lawrence, 4th Floor, Chicago.

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $5,000 to help defray the costs of this important theatrical series.  We are offering wonderful perks to those who can help us.

The Impact

Genesis is working to fill in the gap of plays featuring strong women characters and scripts written by women and our series of Athena's Wisdom will fill those gaps.

Genesis has a strong track record of powerful new works including works dealing with PTSD as well as the Holocaust.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help us by getting the word out and share out page with your friends.

story:
Help us bring this successful show across 3,500km of Canadian highway, to the largest Fringe Festival in North America - with an unprecedented CAST OF 10!

It is the ninth of November and on one ill-fated flight, well-meaning Suzie is taking matters into her own hands. Ten jet stream-crossed passengers have roughly thirty thousand feet to live as Suzie saves the world.

So please, return tables and trays to their upright positions and fasten your seatbelts as Suzie and her fellow commuters take to the skies.

I Will Not Hatch! has been in development since 2004. It was presented at:

  • York University’s playGround Festival in 2005 
  • The Berkeley Street Theatre (The Hank Marvin Theatre Company) in 2006 
  • The Toronto Fringe Festival in 2009

Hatch! has been praised for its creative staging, dark tone and unique perspective. In 2009 it played to full houses at the Toronto Fringe and was named for “Outstanding Ensemble” and “Outstanding Direction” in NOW Magazine’s Fringe Wrap-Up. The 2009 production also received FOUR STARS from EYE Weekly. In 2006 NOW called the piece “A WINNER” that “provided a good share of laughs and a couple of shivers.”

The Ask

A tour of this size, with a cast of 10, is almost UNHEARD OF for an independent production. The cost of transportation and gas alone prevents all but the smallest of shows from taking the trip. Getting this proven show to the international audiences of the Edmonton Fringe is going to be an unprecedented challenge.

And that's why we need you…

I Will Not Hatch! has a long way to travel – 3,734km each way – and we need your help on the journey. Come be a part of an ambitious production – get updates from the road, signed paraphernalia, private receptions. (Note: The One-Night-Only Performance in Toronto was a smashing success! Thanks to all our donors and patrons!. (Please note: Tickets to the event are no longer included in our Perk Packages - because it already happened.)

Check out the $5000 Package for  THE GREATEST PERKS on all of IndieGoGo!

Your Help

Just so you know where your donations will be going:

  • PRODUCTION COSTS:
    • Set/Costumes/Props = $500.00
    • Rehearsal Space = $1,370.81
    • Fringe Festival Fee = $682.50
    • Marketing & Publicity (printing, ad space, photography) = $1,000.00
    • Fundraising (events, campaign fees) = $1,000.00
  • TRAVEL COSTS:
    • Car Rental = $1,750.26
    • Gas = $1,600.50
    • Travel Expenses (lodging, food, maintenance) = $2,000.00

TOTAL COSTS: $9,904.07

We can’t wait to show you the exciting perks available to you when you donate. Just click the video links (on the right) to see what we’re offering.

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to find another way to help us? You can:

  • Provide gifts-in-kind (vehicles, Petro Points, places for us to stay on the way to Edmonton, food or drinks for our one-night event in Toronto).
  • Spread the word about our campaign!

 I Will Not Hatch!

Director/Playwright - Maya Rabinovitch
Producer - David Levine
Assistant Director - Sandra Crljenica
Cast -  Michael Bedford, Glyn Bowerman, Simon Esler, Erin Fleck, Laura Anne Harris, Kat Letwin, Duncan McCallum, Liam Morris, Kristina Schartmann, Jaclyn Zaltz
