story:
Project

Shakespeare in the Square Presents: Twelfth Night

Where: Washington Square Park

When: April 30 at 1:00 and 4:00

Admission is FREE

Our Story

Shakespeare in the Square is a student-run organization that offers free performances of Shakespeare's work. Like “Shakespeare in the Park,” our goal is to bring Shakespeare to the public. Sure, we don’t have Pacino, but we hope that our productions will bring classical theater straight to the Village community. Our company provides the only opportunity to watch and perform Shakespeare as he intended it: under the sun and in front of a loud, standing, possibly distracted audience. Seen in this context, the power of Shakespeare’s language to captivate a crowd will become clear. We hope that this project will alter the way people of all ages view Shakespeare.

 

"You can bring absolutely anything to Shakespeare and the plays will light it up, far more than what you bring will illuminate the plays." 

-- Harold Bloom, Shakespeare: The Invention of the Human

What We Need & What You Get

Our first production, Julius Caesar, had a modest budget of $650. This was made possible in part by Tisch Profunds. This time, there's no Profunds and we're aiming for a block-buster budget of $800. We have some elaborate plans for the props and costumes of Twelfth Night. Most of them involve diamond rings and drinks for Sir Toby. 


See the sidebar for the list of gift we offer to our donors.


Other Ways You Can Help

Post this link on your facebook or twitter and we'll love you forever.

story:
Short Summary

Know what it sounds like when doves cry? Andrew Fafoutakis does. He's taking his journey of growing up gay, bi-racial, and stuck with a big imagination to the first ever Fringe Festival Atlanta, and he needs your help! 

Funding this project will assist Andrew as he brings a labor of love to the 2012 Fringe Festival Atlanta from New York. All proceeds will be used for production costs and travel expenses.

The Impact

Andrew has been graciously invited to bring his one-man show to the first-ever Fringe Festival Atlanta in 2012. By supporting this show, you are supporting live theater, local artists, and a brand new theater festival starting up in Atlanta, Georgia! 

Prince & a Pauper has garnered rave reviews at the 2010 Minnesota Fringe Festival and at successful runs at the Magnet Theater here in New York City.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $2,000 so Andrew and his show can get to Atlanta! Your donations will cover basic housing, travel, food, and production costs. Some of these costs include publicity postcards/posters, financial compensation for technicians and staff, and basic survival costs for Andrew. Afterall, doing a one-man show all by yourself is a lot of work , time, and money!

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are definitely tough, but any way you can give is helpful to our show! Even $2 from you, a friend, or a friend of a friend can make a huge difference. That's less than the price of a cup of coffee! In the end, if you can't donate, spread the word! Your donations and word-of-mouth is the only way we can get this show off the ground and down to Atlanta!

story:
At this point, the world is no stranger to the plight of the ongoing Syrian conflict. The Syrian Civil War began in 2011, and it has been noted by the UN as one of the worst humanitarian disasters to have occurred in recent times. There have been an estimated 100,000 casualties, and 6 million Syrians have been internally displaced. Almost 2.79 million refugees have fled the country, many of them being housed in densely populated refugee camps such as Zaatari, a camp located in the north of Jordan that has housed over 140,000 refugees. Its maximum capacity was set to be 60,000.

After Syria sets out to create a documentary theater piece that will serve as a medium and mouthpiece for those who have been affected by the Civil War. We will carry out a series of interviews with refugees and humanitarian workers in and around the Zaatari refugee camp, which will be condensed into a full-length theatrical performance exploring displacement, collective identity, resilience and uncertainty. Alongside our interviews, we will also collect documentary footage as well as audio recordings, which will be incorporated in the theater piece.

After Syria offers to deepen into the emotional landscape of a conflict that is often lost in numbers and names: what is it to live in between worlds, suspended between past and future? Is it possible to successfully translate that experience onto the stage?

At the same time, the material gathered during the process - the document- will be explored and questioned during and after the play. We will further expand the material that we gather into a series of installations exploring perceptions of sound and image in situations of conflict, interrogating the nature of the mediums as transmitters of experienced struggle.

This project will take place during the summer of 2014.

 


We have already received a generous grant for $3,000 to make this project happen, but we need more in order to actually make it come alive. While the money we received helped us cover the costs of airfare, accommodation and food provisions, we still need your help.

Your contribution will directly fund the following:

  • A local fixer: someone who helps arrange permits, access and interviews, and helps as well as a driver and in-person translator.
  • Transportation once in Jordan
  • Equipment rental
  • Arabic translator and transcriber: once the interviews are recorded, the material needs to be transcribed and translated for the creation of the piece.



It goes without saying that we are deeply thankful for anyone who offers their support for this project, whether it is through donations or spreading the word. Rather than viewing this "perk" system as a reward-based thing, we want to take it as a collaboration. We want to share with you the process behind this project, making you part of it. 

This means sharing with you various processed material gathered during the documentation: photographs or stills from our footage, poems and sketches, a compilation of select footage, or the texts and audio from our interviews.


As an occurrence that appears to be far beyond most of our tangible reach and comprehension, one of the most dangerous and common responses is a feeling of immobility: the paralyzing belief that the events are beyond our means to influence. While artistic projects often seem futile in situations of conflict, they have very often proven to create a more aware understanding of situations that were previously simply seen as tragic news stories, hidden behind alienating statistics. After Syria is an effort to overcome that distance, to surpass the impression of ‘distant people suffering beyond our own worlds’ and understand the urgency of an issue that is of concern for the global community. It is only through a deep consciousness of what has happened, and what continues to occur, that we will learn how to help the lives of those who suffer.




NEST Transmedia: http://nesttransmedia.com/ 
A collective of young artists and academics.  

Joi Lee has spent the last three years learning and living in the United Arab Emirates, the United States and Argentina, experiences that have left her thirsty for investing in projects across disciplines and across borders .  With a passion for utilizing multimedia tools as not only an artistic expression but also as a sociopolitical exploration, she has turned to documentaries and transmedia as her weapon of choice.  In 2012, she worked with and assisted Chelsea Clinton and Linda Mills in the making of Of Many, a documentary on multifaith dialogue that premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival in 2014.  Her experience living in Abu Dhabi has led her to grow a deep and invested interest in issues surrounding the Middle East, and she is also currently developing a docuvmentary about the transient lives of immigrants living in Abu Dhabi.  



Originally from Barcelona, Spain, Oscar has lived around the globe for the past four years. With a formation in Theater and Social Psychology, his collaborative projects have ranged from data analysis to theatrical performance. In 2012, he spent several months analyzing group-based prejudice in the US, selecting the adequate variables in order to generate a state-level index of discrimination towards African-Americans with Dr. PJ Henry. At the same time, he assisted in Theater Mitu’s research for their documentary theater piece ‘Juárez: A Documentary Mythology’, exploring the personal experience of conflict in what is known as the murder capital of the world. He has performed in several theater pieces in New York and in Abu Dhabi, and is now developing Preliminaries, an experimental work that attempts to widen the limits of theatrical narrative.


Notes on our 'Westernness'

One of the biggest potential problems to consider here is the fragility of the situation due to the fact that we are completely foreign to the conflict. Dwight Conquergood, an ethnographer who was at the frontier in exploring the ethics and utility of performance argued that there is a clear danger in the outsider-researcher appropriating the expressions of the refugee as an instrument for domination (Conquergood, Health Theatre in a Hmong Refugee Camp 181). The first step is to recognize this as a valid and legitimate point of contention. It is our responsibility to remain actively conscious about the issue and collaborate with already-existing local organizations.

We, as Westerners entering a zone of alien conflict, must arrive as a way of encounter. This project is a means for mutual exchange, an opportunity for mutual learning and understanding. The last thing we intend is to capitalize on victim’s stories for their dramatic content.
story_txt:
At this point, the world is no stranger to the plight of the ongoing Syrian conflict. The Syrian Civil War began in 2011, and it has been noted by the UN as one of the worst humanitarian disasters to have occurred in recent times. There have been an estimated 100,000 casualties, and 6 million Syrians have been internally displaced. Almost 2.79 million refugees have fled the country, many of them being housed in densely populated refugee camps such as Zaatari, a camp located in the north of Jordan that has housed over 140,000 refugees. Its maximum capacity was set to be 60,000.After Syria sets out to create a documentary theater piece that will serve as a medium and mouthpiece for those who have been affected by the Civil War. We will carry out a series of interviews with refugees and humanitarian workers in and around the Zaatari refugee camp, which will be condensed into a full-length theatrical performance exploring displacement, collective identity, resilience and uncertainty. Alongside our interviews, we will also collect documentary footage as well as audio recordings, which will be incorporated in the theater piece.After Syria offers to deepen into the emotional landscape of a conflict that is often lost in numbers and names: what is it to live in between worlds, suspended between past and future? Is it possible to successfully translate that experience onto the stage?At the same time, the material gathered during the process - the document- will be explored and questioned during and after the play. We will further expand the material that we gather into a series of installations exploring perceptions of sound and image in situations of conflict, interrogating the nature of the mediums as transmitters of experienced struggle.This project will take place during the summer of 2014.  We have already received a generous grant for $3,000 to make this project happen, but we need more in order to actually make it come alive. While the money we received helped us cover the costs of airfare, accommodation and food provisions, we still need your help.Your contribution will directly fund the following:
A local fixer: someone who helps arrange permits, access and interviews, and helps as well as a driver and in-person translator.
Transportation once in Jordan
Equipment rental
Arabic translator and transcriber: once the interviews are recorded, the material needs to be transcribed and translated for the creation of the piece.
It goes without saying that we are deeply thankful for anyone who offers their support for this project, whether it is through donations or spreading the word. Rather than viewing this "perk" system as a reward-based thing, we want to take it as a collaboration. We want to share with you the process behind this project, making you part of it. This means sharing with you various processed material gathered during the documentation: photographs or stills from our footage, poems and sketches, a compilation of select footage, or the texts and audio from our interviews.As an occurrence that appears to be far beyond most of our tangible reach and comprehension, one of the most dangerous and common responses is a feeling of immobility: the paralyzing belief that the events are beyond our means to influence. story:
Short Summary

I wrote "La Llorona" during the second semester of my first year of graduate school. The play is a modern exploration of the hispanic folktale of the same name (roughly translated as "The Weeping Woman") through the eyes of Andy Walker, a public defense attorney, and her relationship with  Marina Renaldo, a woman accused of infanticide. Shortly after this play was submitted for the Capital Fringe Festival, it  won the 2014 Wichita State University National Playwriting Award - all the more reason we want to see it up on its feet! Nothing improves a script like a production. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $2,000 to pay for:

-Stipends for the actors, director, designers, and stage manager
- Marketing materials
- Sets, props, and costumes

At the end of the day we hope to bring you a quality show! And potentially a few perks! (Check out the details below!)

The Impact

Through this production our company of graduates will learn valuable production skills, have a chance to work on a piece outside of the classroom setting, gain exposure to further our respective careers, and have a chance to network with fellow artists at the Capital Fringe festival. It will also give the play itself greater exposure and hopefully help it secure future productions!

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the show in Washington, DC during the Capital Fringe festival this summer! July 13, 18, 19, 25, and 27 at Fort Fringe in the Bedroom!

story:
My name is Shannon Ivey.  I'm an actor, director, educator, and drama therapist in training.  I tell stories.  I help people tell their stories.  The good ones, the tough ones, and the important ones.  We all have a story to tell. 

I have been flirting with Drama Therapy since 2002.  I had moved to St. Louis after receiving an MFA in Acting from UNCG to work for a children's theatre company.  I was living "the dream" making theatre for children, and yet, I kept wondering if I could do more.  Not Broadway type of "more" but more for people who really need theatre.  I started looking up Drama Therapy programs, but going back to school was not in my cards at that time.  I needed to work...another 12 years.

I left that company and came back to teach and direct in North Carolina, until that lingering thought happened again, and so I avoided Drama Therapy and moved to Washington, D.C.  EIght months later, I auditioned for the Kennedy Center and landed a national tour and an Equity Card.  You'd think I'd be satiated, but no.   After tour, one of my teaching applications got a hit, and so off I went to teach full time at a college near the Outer Banks, NC.

Fast forward 7 years later, to 2014.  I am divorced with a four year old.  And it's time.  Time to put all of these experiences (both professional and personal) into a frame work...and that frame work is Drama Therapy.

Currently, I teach at South Carolina State University, an HBCU in Orangeburg, SC.   Due to lack of funding and support, traditional theatre doesn't work at the school.  Students are overly committed and usually work at night.  Our department is severely under supported and gets no operating budget to make theatre.  Yesterday, the university laid off 90 more staff members,  Both faculty members teach over full time loads with classes over 50.  So, with these restrictions, what do you make?  

I make Theatre of the Oppressed Forum Theatre.

About two years ago, I picked up a copy of Boal's Theatre of the Oppressed that I had lugged from job to job, but never read.  The font on the front was red and drippy like a bad horror film.  Too dark, I thought...until this one day, I brought it home with me.  As I read, I realized that I had to understand this work in order to make theatre at my current job.  I travelled to Memphis to drop of my child, and then flew to NYC to train as a Joker (facilitator) at TONYC in March of 2013.  I came back, on fire to do this work, and have lead a group of students and volunteers to make two performed pieces addressing social justice issues.  I have also lead Theatre of the Oppressed workshops at USC, SCTA Conference, and Omega Arts Festival.  Later this summer, if finances allow, I've been accepted to present my work at Pedagogy and Theatre of the Oppressed Conference in Omaha, Nebraska.

When I get back, I am lead to make a piece of self relevatory theatre with women in my community.  I will continue to do Theatre of the Oppressed Forum Theatre work, hopefully getting some grant funding from South Carolina to create a new troupe in the area along with my student troupe.

Here's the cost breakdown:

Registration with Omega Theatre: $75

Omega Theatre 10 day training: $1,350

Lodging at Omega Theatre studio: $275

Train between RVA/Boston: $78

Materials:  $40

NYC to help TONYC with show (travel and lodging): $100

Conference Membership and Fees: $ 175

Airfare: $467

Lodging: $300

Total need?  $2,860

This is, if you can help.

story:
Talia isn't talking. Felicia funnels whiskey.

Quinn dreams of moving far away.

Peter knocks on the door.

Why is there an elephant in the room?

THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM is a new play by Anna Fox which explores what it is to be coping with trauma today.  Far from realism, this lyrical piece distorts, explodes and crystallizes a moment in the lives of three young women.  They sit on their couch seemingly oblivious of the elephant in the room, but the longer they try to ignore him, the more space he seems to take up.

How You Can Help

THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM will be premiering at the New York International Fringe Festival this August!  We've got our schedule, a great team, and a great script, now here's where you come in.  In order to make this play a reality, we are raising $5,200, all of which will go directly into the production.

Your contributions will go towards:

-  Paying artists

-  Rehearsal space

-  Scenic and Costume design

-  Advertising

-  Insurance and Fringe fees

Help us bring this new play from page to stage!  Every little bit helps, and we can't do this without you. Please consider donating to our campaign. As thanks for your donation, you'll get one of these wonderful gifts (shown on the right) from our creative team.

Come see THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM this August and help spread the word!  Share this campaign with your family and friends on Facebook, Twitter, or wherever else you make yourself known. We're so grateful for any and all help we can get, so thank you in advance for your generous support!

The Elephant in The Room

By Anna Fox

Directed by Molly Clifford

Stage Managed by Gabrielle Heifetz

Produced by Graydon Gund

Starring Emily Altschul, Sam Dash, Leila Teitelman, Samantha Fairfield Walsh


Associate Produced by Christophe Desorbay

Scenic Design by Lily Riopelle

Costume Design by Victoria Gordon

Sound Design by Spencer Lutvak

Lighting Design by Lauren Bremen

Dramaturgy by Charlotte Weber


THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM will be presented at The Kraine Theater

Sunday 8/10 @ 2:15pm

Saturday 8/16 @ 2:00

Monday 8/18 @ 7pm

Tuesday 8/19 @ 2:30pm

Sunday 8/24 @ 4:45pm

story:
It’s Marilyn Monroe, as you’ve never known her before.

This show tells the truth about the woman who made sex fun and innocent, captured our hearts and died right under the public’s nose at the age of 36. It’s about the unveiling of a legend to find the real person behind a facade created by powerful publicity departments. 

Why should you care?

Because it’s relevant to women in film today. We see the industry place these starlets up onto a pedestal and then watch them fall and break when they can no longer handle the pressures of Hollywood. And no one seems to think it’s the fault of the system itself. Instead, the woman is blamed.

Such was the case for Marilyn Monroe.

And her problems are very contemporary ones:

  • She wanted to be respected as an artist, but was admired only for her looks and considered to be the same person as the dumb blonde character that she had created.

  • She wanted to have her work and a family too, but her marriages were all failures because of this imbalance.

  • She wanted to have a baby more than anything, but endometriosis and reproductive problems made that impossible.

This was a woman who wanted it all, but ended up with nothing.

There will never be another Marilyn Monroe, but there always seems to be another starlet who is treated with the same disrespect, as if she were merely a human sacrifice for our entertainment.

Marilyn Monroe, Whoever You Are explores these themes, as well as the duality between Norma Jeane and Marilyn Monroe. Norma not only relives certain moments as her iconic character that she created, but also comments on them to present a cautionary tale about women in society and in film.

We should learn from the mistakes and experiences of others, or else we are doomed to repeat them.

The original production, titled simply Monroe, was very successful. Not only did the show sell out for most performances, but also received an extension from the theatre. Now the show is back with a vengeance - complete with a revised script and a new production team to offer a higher quality show. Plus, it will be at The Den Theatre, which is one of the best venues in Chicago.

The show will run for one week only (May 29-June 1 for Marilyn’s birthday); however, it will also be filmed and placed online.

Still, to make this show a reality, we do need your help.

You should support this project because it is a strong show that not only explores important issues in society, but is also an entertaining work of theatre, complete with musical numbers and audience participation.

Plus, we will be exploring new methods of sharing theatre with this revised production. Audience members will be allowed to use their phones throughout the show to record, tweet, post and share clips. The program for the show will live on our home website (www.monroeshow.com), and people from all over the world will be able to experience this solo performance through the Web.

Who are we?

This show was created by Amber Hargroder, a playwright and performance artist based in Chicago. She also runs a website (www.amberhargroder.com) dedicated to helping other artists produce their own work. You can also follow her on Twitter @ajhargroder or search #monroeshow. She spent over two years researching the life of Marilyn Monroe, digging through documents, pouring over Marilyn’s poetry & diaries and watching even the worst of Marilyn’s films (multiple times). She produced the previous show on her own, but now that the show has grown in its scope and quality, she needs your help. 

Nora Best (co-producer, designer & choreographer) has been involved with Chicago theater for nearly 10 years.  Coming from a background in theater, dance, and music she has done a little of everything in various productions throughout Illinois.  In 2012 she co-founded Plan9 Burlesque.  Their character based burlesque style has allowed her to incorporate dancing, comedy, and intelligence into all her burlesque productions.  Her background in teasing and titillating was her gateway into Monroe.  As the choreographer/movement coach she’s been able to work within Marilyn to explore the iconic sexiness as well as the fragile vulnerability that ultimately proved fatal for the great star.

Other team members include Bill Daniel (a wonderful playwright and performer who has been working with us on this project since the very beginning), David Holcombe (amazing film maker and designer who created our trailer), John Szymanski (kickass musician and songwriter), Rick Schuler (design extraordinaire responsible for our poster), Sammi Grant (brilliant dialect coach) and the Stig (Some say that he's the glue holding this all together and that he's got the hearing of a bat on speed, but all we know is, he's called The Stig). 

Together we have crafted a show that we are extremely proud of, and we know that you will love it too. 

Where your money will go:

So many people have worked on this show, and we need money to pay them for their services so that they can buy things like food and insulin. Plus, we have to pay to rent the theatre, get insurance, buy props and costumes, print posters and postcards for marketing, rent rehearsal spaces, take promotional photos, and film the show for it to go online. We also need money for things like bleach, makeup, hairspray, false eyelashes, lipstick and cover up. 

It ain’t cheap to look like Marilyn.

But it’s worth it because we believe in this show, and in this story.

Check out our fabulous perks, donate to our cause and help us create the show that we are so excited to share with you!

You don’t want to miss this opportunity! Please donate now!

She also runs a website (www.amberhargroder.com) dedicated to helping other artists produce their own work. You can also follow her on Twitter @ajhargroder or search #monroeshow. She spent over two years researching the life of Marilyn Monroe, digging through documents, pouring over Marilyn’s poetry & diaries and watching even the worst of Marilyn’s films (multiple times). She produced the previous show on her own, but now that the show has grown in its scope and quality, she needs your help. Nora Best (co-producer, designer & choreographer) has been involved with Chicago theater for nearly 10 years.  Coming from a background in theater, dance, and music she has done a little of everything in various productions throughout Illinois.  In 2012 she co-founded Plan9 Burlesque.  Their character based burlesque style has allowed her to incorporate dancing, comedy, and intelligence into all her burlesque productions.  Her background in teasing and titillating was her gateway into Monroe.  As the choreographer/movement coach she’s been able to work within Marilyn to explore the iconic sexiness as well as the fragile vulnerability that ultimately proved fatal for the great star.Other team members include Bill Daniel (a wonderful playwright and performer who has been working with us on this project since the very beginning), David Holcombe (amazing film maker and designer who created our trailer), John Szymanski (kickass musician and songwriter), Rick Schuler (design extraordinaire responsible for our poster), Sammi Grant (brilliant dialect coach) and the Stig (Some say that he's the glue holding this all together and that he's got the hearing of a bat on speed, but all we know is, he's called The Stig). 
Together we have crafted a show that we are extremely proud of, and we know that you will love it too. 

Where your money will go:
So many people have worked on this show, and we need money to pay them for their services so that they can buy things like food and insulin. Plus, we have to pay to rent the theatre, get insurance, buy props and costumes, print posters and postcards for marketing, rent rehearsal spaces, take promotional photos, and film the show for it to go online. We also need money for things like bleach, makeup, hairspray, false eyelashes, lipstick and cover up. 
It ain’t cheap to look like Marilyn.
But it’s worth it because we believe in this show, and in this story.
Check out our fabulous perks, donate to our cause and help us create the show that we are so excited to share with you!
You don’t want to miss this opportunity! Please donate now!

story:
Short Summary

Hello Everyone! I'm Maria Riboli, the director an co-producer of the fast paced dark comedy "Panic at the Riverside Motel" written and co-produced by John Pastore. I am extremely excited about bringing to life one of the funniest theater plays I've ever read!

"Panic at the Riverside Motel" will keep you on the edge of your seats wanting more...unless of course you'll be rolling on the floor laughing and there's a pretty high chance that you'll be doing that.

I have over 30 years of theater experience in New York, Italy, England, France and I’m pouring my heart into making this hysterical comedy into a memorable theater production in the heart of the Theater District in NYC!

We need your help in bringing this funny story to life! We are not backed by any company or theater and we are putting this show up from scratch!

Any contribution from you will help us to fund this project. $1, $5, $10 or $50 will be helpful! Anything is appreciated and accepted. Please help us to bring this show to LIFE! 


What We Need & What You Get


We need to raise $20,000 for this show and we know that with your help we can DO IT! You can all be a part of creating magic on stage! 

The money will go to paying for: $12,000 fora 4 weeks run at Stage IV Theater in the heart of the Theater District in NYC (Roy Arias Studios and Theaters 300 West 43rd Street NY), $8000 to be divided among rehearsal space for our amazing actors, costumes and make up, the set, crew and advertising! This is a non-paid gig for all of the actors and the crew but if we can fund all of these things, with your help, then I would LOVE to give our cast & crew something for all of their hard work and passion! 

AND there are some perks for you, the contributor! Check out our perks section to see how you can get a shout out on our FACEBOOK page, a signed "Panic at the Riverside Motel" poster from the cast and crew, your name on our website, free tickets to the show and more!

If we do not reach our goal the money we raise will still go to funding for Theater space, rehearsal space and the costumes/set for the show. But I am confident that we will reach our goal with your help! 


The Impact


"Sometimes the dead guy is the lucky one..."

Soon to-be newlyweds Jake and Kaitlin are in over their heads with their upcoming lavish wedding. At the end of their financial rope, and fresh out of options, this ordinary couple resorts to an unthinkable solution.
With help from Kaitlin’s gangster brother, Billy, the pair finds themselves at the seedy Riverside Motel, where they intend to sell $50,000 worth of cocaine to a potential buyer.
But when this already uneasy plan unravels horrifically, not to mention immediately, their desperation for a payoff pales in comparison to what they now must deal with, including their reliance on the unscrupulous Billy to clean up their mess.

Writer John Pastore teams up with director Maria Riboli to bring New York City a riotous, faced- paced dark comedy about a dead body and all the inconveniences it causes an engaged couple in a seedy motel. This Winter, find out how this misfit pair cope with a corpse, the potential ruination of their lavish wedding, and an idiotic detective.

This uproarious tale of desperation, confusion and ceaseless sarcasm will be brought to life, Off Broadway, with an amazing and versatile cast at the Stage IV ( Roy Arias Studios and Theaters ) in January 2014.

Can this couple survive the aftermath of a plan that has gone horribly awry? Or is the dead guy the lucky one?


***


I've been in this business since I was 6 years old! I've acted and directed in Italy, Paris, London and of course NYC where I also teach acting at my own acting studio.

I was the executive producer, co-director and female lead in the theater production of "BAAAHHH!!!" which was accepted at the 2007 Fringe Festival, and then we extended the show for a full sold out month at the Payan Theater (NYC) and then we went to London at the historic Pleasance Theater! This, amongst many other theater productions, Broadway readings, voiceover projects for Verizon, Rosetta Stone, Barilla and now being the spokesperson and Director of Beauty and Wellness for Borghese on NBC Shopping Network, has given me amazing experience in how to bring things to LIFE! 

My latest productions were “Want & Need”, November 2013.


I was the producer, director and female lead in the play. We had an amazing sold out run in the heart of the theater district in NYC! 

And another successful play followed soon after with another sold out run. I directed “Family of strangers” by John Pastore, in March 2013. 


Meanwhile I was directing (along side Adam Pagdon) the webseries “Catch-30” premiering in the fall 2013. 

Most recently I directed the video portion of the Off Broadway show "Tesla" directed by Sanja Bestic.



Other Ways You Can Help

Times are hard and we know that everyone cannot contribute financially. PLEASE help us to spread the word about the show and this fundraiser!

Share the link to this fundraiser with all your friends and family!

You can also show your support on FB/Twitter and Instagram

www.facebook.com/PanicAtTheRiversideMotel

www.twitter.com/PanicRiverSide

www.instagram.com/panicattheriversidemotel


The panic will start spreading January 15th @ 7:00 pm (Preview)

January 16th @ 7:00 pm (Preview)

January 17th @  8:00 pm (Preview)

January 18th @ 8:00 pm (opening night)

January 19th @ 3:30 pm

January 21st @ 7:00 pm

January 22nd @ 7:00 pm

January 23rd @ 7:00 pm

January 24th @ 8:00 pm

January 25th @ 8:00 pm

January 26th @ 3:30 pm

January 28th @ 7:00 pm

January 29th @ 7:00 pm

January 30th @ 7:00 pm

January 31st @ 8:00 pm

February 1st @ 8:00 pm

February 2nd @ 3:30 pm

February 4th @ 7:00 pm

February 5th @ 7:00 pm

February 6th @ 7:00 pm

February 7th @ 8:00 pm

February 8th @ 8:00 pm

At Stage VI at Roy Arias Studios and Theaters

300 West 43rd Street, New York, NY 10036

story:
Miriam Engel is a gifted Israeli choreographer and teacher who performed with Jerusalem's highly acclaimed Kolben Dance Company. She is now founder and Artistic Director of Engela Dance, a new modern dance company in Jerusalem.

This recent Tel Aviv performance of Miriam's No Hands is based on losing the use of her arm for three months. An authentic and moving work, it is a well-crafted integration of original movement, engaging music, meaningful text and high level performance.

Miriam has invited Lin Batsheva Kahn to be her Visiting Artist-in-Residence in December. As a new company, they are in need of support to fund this 4 week International Dance Project.  

The funds will pay for Professor Kahn's 

. travel

. teaching classes

. setting piece endure inspired by tehillim 13 (photo of Kahn sitting in chair)

. creating a new Jewish work

. videography

You will enable Engela Dance to study with and perform Lin Batsheva Kahn's choreography inspired by Jewish themes in Israel theaters and to create videography from the dance residency.

You will make a positive cultural impact on Israeli audiences who will see work by an American Jewish choreographer on one of their own dance companies. 

You will also invest in the development of artistic dance in Jerusalem to make this beautiful place even more beautiful.


Sincerely,

Jessi Aviv Barnes          

Campaign Outreach Director


click here www.tikvahartistschicago.com 

to see photos, excerpts, reviews, comments and bio

story:
Short Summary

We made this video using young local talent following the philosophy of NNU. David Avtandilyan was our videographer, and the music was provided by Dong Seo, a promising young artist. Other credits include: video clips by Chase Cross, models Rebekah Rochelle and Anastasya Hrabar, Hair by Jeremy Todd Abraham and make up by Alexandra Grigorieva.

What We Need & What You Get

For our show to work, we don't want to make the tickets too expensive, to invite young artists and students, as well as large businesses. Still, we need a way to cover our costs, which include the cost of the venue and the payment of the staff. If we don't get all the money we ask for, the money we do get will go to cover as much of these costs as possible. We need $6,000 for the event, with over $4,500 of it going purely to cover the cost of the venue, the Bellevue Arts Museum.

As a thank you for your donation, please check the perks section. 

The Impact

NNU stands for the Northwest Networking Umbrella.The purpose of this event is to FINALLY give talented people and artists in Seattle the opportunity to meet and to talk and to do business with each other. 

There is such a great modeling, acting, fashion, and art community here and sadly many people never get their lucky break. This is an event for local talent and businesses, so that they can network with each other. We put together all the different talent that we can find to bring as many people as possible together, and to give encouragement to the young artists who often feel like their dreams are impossible to achieve. This event gives them the knowledge and experience of working in front of a large crowd, and energizes the young talent to follow their dreams, as well as giving them the social opportunities to do so. It's important for us to all support the local arts community close to home.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute directly, we would be happy to have you as a guest at our show. :)


Please meet our Team:

Nune Hovhannisyan:          Show Production Director, Fashion Design

Mariam Hovhannisyan:       Graphic Design, Manager of Stage

Anahit Hovhannisyan:         Vandor Manager

Shannyn Towe:                   Backstage Coordinator

Andrew Douglas:                Host from Ratliff Ind.,

Gary Manuel:                       Makeup from Aveda Inst.,

David Avtandilyan:              Video

Sona Atanesyan                  Show Production

story:
THE FIRST PRODUCTION OF

THE ART THEATER OF DAVIS

We are a newly-formed group of theater artists and collaborators who are dedicated to staging artistic theater in the Davis community. Davis has a vibrant arts scene. But it lacks a community group dedicated to staging classics of modern theater. Our plan is to produce three plays a year, working with repertoire such as Chekhov, Ibsen, Brecht and Maeterlinck.

We have chosen Chekhov’s Three Sisters for our first production. Performances will take place at Third Space in Davis (thirdspacedavis.com), and are scheduled for February 28th–March 2nd, March 6th–9th, and March 13th–16th.

Three Sisters is a naturalistic drama, written in 1900 by Anton Chekhov, the celebrated Russian writer. The four-act production follows the lives of three sisters and their brother, an upper-class family living in a provincial town. When the brother of the three sisters marries a petty bourgeois local, the siblings' dreams to move back to the bright lights of Moscow gradually disintegrate and disappear. Three Sisters is a dramatic masterpiece, full of love, comedy, philosophy and frustration. We are proud to participate in its continuing production history.

To make this show possible, we are trying to raise money to help fund the basic production expenses, including the costs of costumes, lights, set construction, and renting the venue. Although all of the work and some of the materials for this show will be donated by our team and local business partners, we cannot make it happen without a limited budget.

Therefore, we appeal to you, theater-lovers!

If you would like to see a fantastic production of Chekhov, right here in Davis, this is your chance to help make that happen. With your contributions, we can add a creative new dimension to the local arts scene. We are passionate about the art of theater and hope, with your help, to share that passion with the community. 

Perks for Theater-Lovers!

We are offering several levels of cumulative perks to help thank you for donating to our Three Sisters campaign. Tickets to the show, signed posters, unique photographs and recognition as a hero for the cause are offered at various levels of donation. Please see the list for details!

What your contribution will fund

Here are the basic costs of production we are trying to cover with this campaign:

$1000 Renting rehearsal and performance space
$600   Costume construction, rental and purchase
$400   Lighting rental and purchase
$500   Set and prop construction
$300   Publicity, programs and printing costs

All funds donated to this campaign will go directly towards these aspects of the production. All proceeds from the box office beyond our production costs for Three Sisters will be put towards the budget for our next show in Spring 2014.

Why Contribute? Because theater matters!

Theater is an important part of our artistic heritage. Davis has a number of excellent theater companies, but none focus on staging modern classics of artistic theater. The Art Theater of Davis aims to change this. Our goal is to stage canonical works that deserve a continuing place in our cultural world. Let's give playwrights such as Chekhov, Ibsen and Brecht the chance to speak to our community in live performance! We believe they have much to say to us.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help our campaign in other ways, too. For one, just getting the word out about the show to your friends will be a tremendous help. We can be found on Facebook, through the link below. Second, we are still looking for extra hands to help with altering costumes, set construction in February, ushering, and help with striking the set after the show is over. Get in touch with us to volunteer! Third, we are trying to recycle, reuse and borrow what we can. We would love to accept any in-kind donations of lumber, construction hardware, fabric, used furniture, or costumes you have hidden in your closet.

Members of The Art Theater

Timothy Nutter (Director) is a Davis native, who has been working in the performing arts here since 2006. He originally studied theater, dance and philosophy at SUNY Purchase and Antioch College, then studied acting at the Terry Schreiber Studio and Theatre, while working on off-off-Broadway productions in NYC. Timothy has recently worked locally as a dance instructor and choreographer for the Winters Shakespeare Workshop, the Davis Community Chorale, the DHS Jazz Choir, and the Davis Art Center ballet program. He is very excited to help bring the work of Chekhov and other modern dramatists to life in Davis.

Ania Mieszkowska (Assistant Director) is a director, teacher and theater practitioner of over 30 years experience both in the United States and England.  She was a founder member and the original Artistic Director of the award-winning Brighton Festival Shakespeare Company. She has often worked as a casting director for theaters in Seattle, Miami and off-off-Broadway. Ania moved to Davis with her husband and two sons nine years ago. Since then she has worked as a drama coach and taught ballet and Pilates at The Davis Art Center, Pamela Trokanski Dance Workshop and at Applegate Studio.

Tyler Shaffo (Stage Manager) has been involved in local media and arts since he moved to Davis two years ago. He has brought his background in film from his studies at Denison University (Ohio) to work with Little Thunder Films on their short film, "Rain". He is also a volunteer with Davis Media Access and a real believer in community driven and controlled media. Tyler strongly feels that the Art Theater of Davis can bring something new and enlightening to our community's cultural landscape.

Sarah Douglas (Costumes) was born in Tampa, Florida and started her acting experience there at the age of seven. From then on, she continued her involvement in acting and theater as her life carried her out to California. During high school, she became involved with Acme Theatre Company as an actor and house manager. She currently lives and works in Davis. Performance experience includes The Wiz, Once on This Island, Snow White, and The Three Musketeers.

Scarlet O'Connor will be playing the role of Anfisa. She has been performing with The Actor's Workshop in Sacramento and recently was awarded the Elly for Leading Actress in Comedy for her work with EMH Productions. She is very excited to be acting in her hometown of Davis!

 too. For one, just getting the word out about the show to your friends 
will be a tremendous help. We can be found on Facebook, through the link below. Second, we are still looking for extra hands 
to help with altering costumes, set construction in February, ushering, and help with striking the set
 after the show is over. Get in touch with us to volunteer! Third,
 we are trying to recycle, reuse and borrow what we can. We would love 
to accept any in-kind donations of lumber, construction hardware, 
fabric, used furniture, or costumes you have hidden in your closet.
Members of The Art TheaterTimothy Nutter (Director) is a Davis native, who has been working in the performing arts 
here since 2006. He originally studied theater, dance and philosophy at SUNY 
Purchase and Antioch College, then studied acting at the Terry 
Schreiber Studio and Theatre, while working on off-off-Broadway productions in NYC. Timothy has recently worked locally as a 
dance instructor and choreographer for the Winters Shakespeare Workshop,
 the Davis Community Chorale, the DHS Jazz Choir, and the Davis Art Center 
ballet program. He is very excited to help bring the work of Chekhov 
and other modern dramatists to life in Davis.Ania Mieszkowska (Assistant Director) is a director, teacher and theater practitioner of over
 30 years experience both in the United States and England.  She was a 
founder member and the original Artistic Director of the award-winning 
Brighton Festival Shakespeare Company. She has often worked as a 
casting director for theaters in Seattle, Miami and off-off-Broadway. 
Ania moved to Davis with her husband and two sons nine years ago. Since 
then she has worked as a drama coach and taught ballet and Pilates at 
The Davis Art Center, Pamela Trokanski Dance Workshop and at Applegate 
Studio.Tyler Shaffo (Stage Manager) has been involved in local media and arts since he moved to Davis two years ago. He has brought his background in film from his studies at Denison University (Ohio) to work with Little Thunder Films on their short film, "Rain". He is also a volunteer with Davis Media Access and a real believer in community driven and controlled media. Tyler strongly feels that the Art Theater of Davis can bring something new and enlightening to our community's cultural landscape.Sarah Douglas (Costumes) was born in Tampa, Florida and started her acting experience there at the age of seven. From then on, she continued her involvement in acting and theater as her life carried her out to California. During high school, she became involved with Acme Theatre Company as an actor and house manager. She currently lives and works in Davis. Performance experience includes The Wiz, Once on This Island, Snow White, and The Three Musketeers.Scarlet O'Connor will be playing the role of Anfisa. She has been performing with The Actor's Workshop in Sacramento and recently was awarded the Elly for Leading Actress in Comedy for her work with EMH Productions. She is very excited to be acting in her hometown of Davis!

story:
Our Story

My name is Josh Wilder. I'm a third year acting major at Carnegie Mellon University School of Drama and proud Philadelphia native. PERFECTION all started as a conversation that I had with my co worker about the gentrification of Harlem, his personal story of over coming gang violence and the hardships he faced being an inner city youth in New York, that ultimately led him to college. In February 2010, I recorded a series of our conversations and with his blessing I had to make his story accessible to everyone who was willing to listen. I transcribed all our our sessions and created the one man show and actually performed in the basement of the FRAME GALLERY on Carnegie Mellon's campus. My great friend and mentor, Larry Powell, who just finished working with the Lincoln Center Theatre in NYC came down to sign on as director. His passion and vision for the piece made it a very important piece of theatre that had to go on for another workshop. 

In the fall of 2010 I edited the piece again and it got accepted in to Carnegie Mellon's PLAYGROUND Festival of new student work. Larry came back from New York to direct the piece again and brought sound designer, Hidenor J. Nakajo on to the project which took it to new heights, I also brought in some colleagues of mine: Adrian Enscoe who added  new elements to the piece through his mask creations and Julie Mallis who provided bold scenic designs to support the vision. Kendra Chapman served as Stage Manager and Alesia Etinoff as Dramaturg. None of this would be possible with our their outstanding collaboration. 

The ultimate goal of this piece is to have the world premiere in Harlem, where the play is based, but we want to try it out in other major cities such as Los Angeles THIS SUMMER and Chicago WINTER 2011. With your help and support we can make this happen and help open the eyes of many people who don't understand the lost lasting effects gentrification has on the inner city, especially the youth. Here's a brief synopsis of the show:


In the midst of Harlem’s gentrification, Perfection, a revolutionary college student, throws a brick into a new 14 million dollar condominium development that stands besides the project building he grew up in. PERFECTION tells the story of a young man trying to save the Harlem he
once knew before it is all buried. PERFECTION is a solo performance art piece, incorporating elements of abstract masks, poetry and video to create the haunting experience of Harlem’s abandoned, yet politically charged atmosphere.
PERFECTION explores the current problem of gentrification as a type of socio-economic cleansing in Harlem. As Columbia University continues to expand downward into Harlem, property value has risen causing rent to rise in subsidized low income housing areas.
PERFECTION is based on the interviews of a college student who discussed his journey from gang life in Harlem to the discovery of his academic potential. 


The Impact

By doing this show I plan to impact the people of my generation to stand up against gentrification and help protect their, neighborhoods, their support system, and most important their cultural identity. If this campaign doesn't receive any support then who will be the theatrical voice to stand up against these issues? How will our voices be heard to save the inner city? Who will tell our stories?


What We Need & What You Get

$2000- Theater/Space Rental

Renting a theater/space isn't cheap wherever you go. Even though this wont give us a guaranteed week of performance we will do our best to sell out every performance! Also this covers the cost for any rehearsal space.

$300- Fight and Transportation

The director is already LA based, so this will help cover any travel Expenses going to LA. The director is doing this FREE OF CHARGE BECAUSE HE HAS BELIEVED IN THE PROJECT SINCE DAY ONE. The best I can do is get to LA and with that I need your help. My tuition is $54,000 dollars.

$300- Advertisements

Though Facebook and Youtube are great mediums to advertise and promote the show, I still want to go into the community and promote via flyers and posters. Maybe even have a salon with local LA based artists telling them about the show.

$400- Design elements

We want the show to be the best designed and the most cost efficient! There will be many elements to this production including mask, scenic, and sound! help our designers to create to their very best. Most of them are doing this FREE OF CHARGE!


If you contribute to this campaign:

You will be supporting a new important voice of American Theater whose giving a fresher perspective to the story telling of unheard voices.

Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT OUR CAMPAIGN!!!!!!!! If you know anyone who would like to sign on as a long term producer or know a theater company that would commission/host this piece tell them about it!

story: Hello my name is David Riojas and I am a senior dance major this year at Arizona State University. I am currently developing my Transitions Dance Project, which is a reflection of what I have learned for the past four years here at Arizona State University. I have been dancing for about 13 years. I have ben trained in Jazz, ballet, Tap, Lyrical and Modern. My project is about myself and the past 25 years of my life. I am stripping the brick walls and layers that I have built up throughout my life due to bad or personal and negative conflicts which have caused me to hold so much in. Throughout the piece you will see a progression from where I have come from to where it is I am going. I am working with a cast of eight female dancers. This has been very challenging due to the fact that I am a man and the audience will be viewing my life through eight female movers. I feel that this will allow and enable my audience to find connections and/or relate to what is being seen. It took me a while in my process to really tell my dancers some of the things I have held inside but in the end Its been rewarding cause surprisingly I am learning that the problems I thought I had are very much so universal problems and others can and are relating. With your help I will be able to take my work outside of the university setting and apply it to the Phoenix area to be seen. This allows my work as well as the dancers to get more exposure but most importantly we will get to continue to promote the art of dance in the Valley of the sun! Through your kind funds I will also be able to hire a lighting designer as well as begin making costumes to enhance my work and story. The effect that you would have on not only me but my dancers as well will be nothing short of AMAZING! We have been working on this project for about a year now and have all grown very close to one another. With your help I feel like I can really present something that is not only entertaining but also most importantly self-therapeutic. So far I have gained so much confidence as an artist and choreographer. I plan on continuing to create and developed more work that people can really relate to and hopefully inspire others.

story:
The Show

DNA Theatre's team of innovative directors and designers are collaborating with some of the region's best actors and aerialists to portray an adaptation of William Shakespeare's classic story of love and betrayal.

Armed with an abridged version of the original text, The Tempest will astound the senses as DNA Theatre's largest production to date. Immersing the audience in a 360-degree experience, performers surround the audience at Baltimore Theatre Project creating a multi-sensory theatrical experience.

Aerialists paired with actors and dancers soar overhead in this 75-minute experience full of DNA Theatre's captivating visual style, and engaging storytelling technique.

The Tempest promises to be an accessible theatre experience not-to-be-missed. Help us bring this new work to the community with a gift today.

Showtimes

  • Opening Night: Thursday 22nd: 8pm
  • Friday 23rd: 8pm
  • Saturday 24th: 8pm
  • Matinée: Sunday 25th: 2pm
  • Sunday 25th: 8pm
  • Wednesday 28th: 8pm
  • Thursday 29th: 8pm
  • Friday 30th: 8pm
  • Saturday 31st: 8pm

Why Us?

DNA Theatre is an aerial theatre company presenting fully-staged theatrical productions in the Baltimore Maryland and surrounding regions.  DNA Theatre collaborates with many types of local talent.  We tap the artistic vein of local colleges, grass-roots organizations, local small businesses, and young professionals.  Bringing these groups together, we collaborate in a highly artistic environment, providing valuable work experience and professional networking in the field of theatre that is often difficult to "break-into."
 
This collective developmental environment benefits all of our team members, from performers to designers and technical facilitators.  Our award-winning internship program, developed with many of the areas local colleges, allows students studying a variety of fields to gain skills and experience in theatrical development, business management, and social media.
 
Though our productions are large and vibrant, our means are small and humble.  Please consider helping us with a donation to support The Tempest. 
 
If a contribution is beyond your means, post this campaign on your Facebook page, Twitter feed, or email to a few friends.  Even though you may not be able to make a financial contribution, spreading the word to others helps DNA Theatre gain valuable social exposure.  

Our History

Daydreams + Nightmares Aerial Theatre (shortened to DNA Theatre) is an aerial movement theatre company which strives to reinvent circus arts using traditional apparatus, imaginative aerial structures, and unorthodox themes and performance compositions. We hope to introduce diverse audiences to our unique interpretation of theatrical arts. By telling stories with movement, music and non-traditional circus arts, DNA Theatre exposes audiences to a new type of theatre that defies definition and traditional performing boundaries. DNA Theatre's style of company collaboration is guided by Artistic & General Director Kel Millionie and Director Elle Brande.

In nine years DNA Theatre has grown from a single person operation to a variable team of over thirty-five creative individuals. Our collective of performers, designers, technicians, artists, and developers are an eclectic team. While some of our company members are gymnasts, dancers, and acrobats, others are ceramicists, Apple Geniuses, dog-walkers, and musicians.  Our team needs your help to continue our successful presentation of astounding and community-engaging theatre.

story:
To raise money for our second festival show of the year, we're not just asking for donations...WE'RE DOIN' A SHOW IN CHICAGO!

 

WIGGERLOVER [whiteboy+blackdad=greyareas]

STRAWDOG THEATRE - 3829 North Broadway

SATURDAY, JULY 6th

The bar opens at 9pm.  The show starts at 10pm.

The party goes on until the DJ stops playing that funky music.

 

HOW DO I BUY TICKETS?

To purchase tickets, click the appropriate amount.  Then, show up on Saturday, July 6th to have some fun!  It's that simple!!

 

WHAT IF I CAN'T BE THERE?

Well, be sure to tell your friends!  Also, if you'd like to make a donation, but can't make it to the show, just throw a couple bucks in the proverbial pot.

Either way, WE THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!

Seriously, you helped us get to the SoloNOVA Arts Festival in New York City this June...& we couldn't have done it without you!

We've been fortunate in every way imaginable - since the debut at Chicago Cultural Center in 2010 through our Summer Festival Tour 2013.

The positive responses we get from everyone everywhere are just a testimony to the fact that the truth is universal...regardless of how personal the story may be.

Plus, it’s a actually quite a good show.  But don’t take my word for it...

 

WHAT THE PRESS SAYS...

“Combines honest storytelling with poignant questions about race and cultural identity.”
- Chicago Reader

“Right now, it could certainly start some useful conversations with kids who are struggling with their own cultural identities.”
- Chicago Tribune

“Deftly strikes a wonderful balance of hilarious-meets-poignant.  Whether you grew up on the South Side of Chicago or the Northern Suburbs, you’ll find something about his story that rings true to you.”
- Chicago Theatre Blog

“Takes us on a courageously personal and entertainingly autobiographical examination of racial perceptions as experienced in an interracial family.  Zoccoli’s precious and enthusiastic childlike warmth is the thread that endears you to his story and overshadows its painful revelations.”
- Chicago Stage Review

“A hilarious myriad of music, comedy, history and memoir, the hour-long retrospective delves into touchy topics with wit and heart.”
- Centerstage Chicago

“Zoccoli’s a gifted storyteller and born entertainer.”
- New City

story:
Short Summary

My name is Laura Roth, and I am a dancer based in St. Louis.  I currently dance with Common Thread Contemporary Dance Company and teach at STAGES Performing Arts Academy.  I recently graduated from Southeast Missouri State University with a BA in Dance and a minor in Religious Studies.

During my senior year at Southeast, I created The Dance on Film Project.  The project gave choreographers and filmmakers from the university the opportunity to collaborate to make dance on film pieces.  The project culminated with a film screening event at which all of the pieces were presented.  After moving to St. Louis, I was thrilled to learn that a great deal of local artists have been experimenting with dance on film as well.  I have been blown away by the exquisite work of theirs that I've seen, and I can't wait to showcase that work in The Dance on Film Project, St. Louis.

For The Dance on Film Project, St. Louis, I will collect submissions of dance on film pieces from local artists and will present them at a public film screening this summer, but I need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

If we meet our goal...

Your generous donations will cover theater and projection equipment rental as well as advertising and printing costs.  Meeting our goal will make it possible for us to rent a theater space that will be tech-ready, centrally located, and able to accommodate a good-sized audience (because we KNOW you'll all be at the event!!).

If we exceed our goal...

Your incredibly generous donations that go above and beyond the set goal will be divided among the artists who submit pieces to the project.  This will partially reimburse the production costs of their individual pieces.

If we don't reach our entire goal...

Your generous donations will still be used to cover projection equipment rental and advertising and printing costs, but we'll have to get a bit creative with the event location.


Check out the perks for donating on the side bar!!

The Impact

One of the most exciting aspects of The Dance on Film Project, St. Louis, in my opinion, is the bringing together of the St. Louis dance community the project will cause.  We have so much wonderful local dance that is showcased individually; I'm excited to see so many of these artists showcased in one event.  My hope is that this project will inspire future collaborations among local artists and that audience members will be exposed to both familiar artists and artists they have not seen before.

Also, as stated in the video above, The Dance on Film Project, St. Louis hopes to create more interest in dance on film among the members of the St. Louis community, showcase and celebrate the artwork of local dance on film artists, and maintain the tradition of experiencing dance as a community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about the campaign, and stay tuned for details on the film screening!

story:
OVERALL GOAL: $4,000

Hello!

I’m Hannah Donovan: California native, actor, world traveler, and wildlife enthusiast.



I was recently chosen to be one of the lucky 18 actors who will be embarking on a month-long immersive theater/travel expedition to Ecuador this June and I would love your help! 

If I can raise the funds…

…I’ll be able to trek through beautiful Ecuador, teaching locals acting/playwriting, exploring all corners of the country, engaging in community service projects, and collaborating with my fellow travelers to create a play to be performed upon our return to New York City!

Too good to be true

This program could not be more perfect in my eyes.  The idea that I’ll be acting while traveling through the Amazon continually blows my mind, and I sincerely hope that your funds and support can help me get there!

My goal is to raise $4,000 by the time I leave.  This is the first of two installments!

If you’d like to learn more about the program I’m going with, here’s the link:

http://www.dramaticadventure.com/action/ecuador

Anything you can give would be amazingly helpful.  I’ve been working like a maniac, but non-paying acting gigs and a full-time bakery job can only take me so far!  So tell you friends, family, enemies, strangers, pets, anyone and everyone who could contribute money or even just spread the word further.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this, and I cannot tell you how much your help means to me :)

OVERALL GOAL: $4,000
Hello!
I’m Hannah Donovan: California native, actor, world
traveler, and wildlife enthusiast.I was
recently chosen to be one of the lucky 18 actors who will be embarking on a month-long immersive
theater/travel expedition to Ecuador this June and I would love your help! If I can raise the
funds…
…I’ll be able to trek through beautiful Ecuador,
teaching locals acting/playwriting, exploring all corners of the country,
engaging in community service projects, and collaborating with my fellow travelers
to create a play to be performed upon our return to New York City!
Too good to be true
This program could not be more perfect in my eyes.  The idea that I’ll be acting while traveling
through the Amazon continually blows my mind, and I sincerely hope that your
funds and support can help me get there!
My goal is to raise

the first of two installments!

non-paying acting gigs and a full-time bakery job can only take me so far!  So tell you friends, family, enemies, strangers, pets, anyone and everyone who could contribute money or even just spread the word
further.
Thank you so much for taking the time to read this, and I
cannot tell you how much your help means to me :)
